articles.title: There are those on the left and right who offer only grievance: Labour is getting on with the job of economic renewal | Keir Starmer
articles.trailText: Judge last week’s budget in the light of our bold plans to sweep away red tape, tackle inactivity among young people and pursue a closer trading relationship with the EU, says prime minister Keir Starmer
articles.summary: Starmer touts last week’s budget: a £150 energy-bill rebate, removal of the two-child benefit cap, protected NHS funding, fairer taxation to lower inflation and debt costs, alongside £120bn of capital investment in infrastructure, planning reforms and airport expansions. He pledges to cut pointless gold-plating regulation, reform welfare to help young people with health or neurodivergent needs via an Alan Milburn commission, and deepen EU trade ties. Rejecting both austerity and unchecked borrowing, Labour’s mission is long-term economic, community and state renewal, to be judged at the next election.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Send crisis: Bridget Phillipson must be tough with the Treasury so children aren’t penalised | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Tory special needs reforms upended council finances, but Labour’s plan to rebuild public provision won’t come cheap if it’s done properly
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that England’s special educational needs and disabilities (Send) system faces a £6.6bn overspend by next March after underfunded Tory reforms forced families into tribunals and councils into chaos. It endorses shifting funding from local authorities to the Department for Education but cautions Bridget Phillipson to resist cost-cutting and champion a nuanced Labour white paper that balances mainstream inclusion with specialist provision. Effective reform demands honest timelines, cross-party support, and sustained investment to secure children’s legal entitlements.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the inequality emergency: why a Nobel prize winner’s warning must be heeded | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Rising economic division is destabilising nations and eroding accountability. Joseph Stiglitz’s G20 blueprint offers a way toward global economic renewal
articles.summary: Joseph Stiglitz’s G20 Inequality Report warns of a global "inequality emergency": the top 1% captured 41% of new wealth since 2000 while the bottom 50% gained just 1%. 90% of the world faces high inequality, 2.3 bn are food insecure and billionaire assets equal one-sixth of global GDP. Rejecting trickle-down growth, he links extreme inequality to democratic backsliding, climate risk and policy capture—citing gold-bar diplomacy with Trump. His blueprint demands a Bretton Woods-style overhaul: IP rule rewrites, trade and financial treaty reform, updated tax and sovereign debt frameworks and an International Panel on Inequality.

articles.title: How can we navigate difficult conversations these holidays? Buddhism offers some guidance | Making sense of it
articles.trailText: Choosing to bring intentionality to our speech challenges our tendency to abandon and disconnect from those we do not agree with
articles.summary: Dr. Nadine Levy draws on Buddhist teachings and modern psychology to frame difficult holiday conversations as opportunities for radical communal care. She warns against hyper‐assertiveness or silent retreat, which avoid vulnerability and foster disconnection. Highlighting Dan Siegel’s interpersonal neurobiology—how tone and co‐regulation shape relationships—and Carol Gilligan’s ethics of care, she urges us to ask “what would a caring response look like?” Drawing on the Eightfold Path’s wise speech, she prescribes communication that is timely, true, gentle, beneficial and loving. Such intentional speech builds trust, softens polarisation and cultivates solidarity rooted in interdependence.

articles.title: Don’t filter your dates by age and hobbies, ask them how they shop | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Big deal-breakers are all very well, but the seemingly small things often tell in the end. How do they feel about sell-by dates? Will they walk out of a bad film? Not asking will come back to haunt you, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson argues that daters should stop filtering by superficial criteria like age or hobbies and instead discuss micro‐level preferences—airport arrival habits, movie‐watching thresholds, shopping style, tolerance for food expiry dates, timing of holiday decorations and background chatter. These little quirks, though trivial at first, can become persistent annoyances that derail long‐term matches. Even with upfront honesty, unexpected dealbreakers—such as one partner’s refusal to buy takeaway coffee—can emerge. Embracing frank conversation on these small issues offers a stronger foundation for lasting compatibility.

articles.title: What Rosa Parks can teach us about resistance today | Jan-Werner Mueller
articles.trailText: Rosa Park’s story is about courage. But, lest one forget, it is also a story about breaking the law
articles.summary: Mueller argues that Rosa Parks’s famed bus protest was no spur-of-the-moment act but the product of her NAACP activism since 1943, coordinated organizing, and a 381-day boycott fueled by pamphlets and private taxis. He draws on John Rawls’s definition of civil disobedience—public, non-violent, conscientious political speech paired with acceptance of punishment—and warns that today’s fragmented media, right-wing distortions, and the Trump administration’s politicized prosecutions and threats against dissent make such principled resistance harder to execute and less likely to persuade authorities or the public.

articles.title: When it comes to alcohol, gambling and domestic violence in Australia, it’s essential we connect the dots | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: What is happening behind closed doors in your street while the game is on, the grog is flowing and the bets are failing?
articles.summary: Zoe Daniel argues that Australia’s domestic violence crisis is exacerbated by the “toxic trio” of sport, alcohol and gambling. With 74 women killed last year and police attending incidents every two minutes, services remain underfunded, forcing survivors into motels. Studies show problem gambling triples intimate-partner violence, especially during major sporting events. Despite a federal review recommending bans on gambling ads, alcohol restrictions and limits on poker machines, political inaction persists amid calls for a conscience vote.

articles.title: Trump keeps insulting female journalists | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Trump has a disconcerting tendency to attack the press – but especially female reporters, whom he holds in particular ire
articles.summary: Over Thanksgiving, Trump used Truth Social to lob an ableist slur at Minnesota’s governor and an Islamophobic jab at Rep. Ilhan Omar, then publicly called a female reporter “stupid” when asked about a DC National Guard attack. In recent weeks he has repeatedly insulted women journalists—calling New York Times reporter Katie Rogers “ugly,” ABC’s Mary Bruce “a terrible person,” and Bloomberg’s Catherine Lucey “piggy”—a pattern echoed by his communications director. Critics, including his niece Mary Trump, say these gendered attacks reveal his comfort with misogyny, growing anxiety, and pose a threat to press freedom.

articles.title: The Russia-Ukraine peace deal is not a loss. Nor is it a victory | Stephen Wertheim
articles.trailText: The conflict is neither a clearcut defeat nor a feelgood victory, but an in-between outcome that contains profound elements of each
articles.summary: Stephen Wertheim argues that a prospective Russia-Ukraine settlement is a mixed outcome: not a defeat nor full victory. He notes the US 28-point plan offers Ukraine strong military autonomy and unprecedented security guarantees but concedes territory. History shows Washington’s refusal to accept partial wins or losses in Vietnam, Afghanistan, Gulf War prolonged conflicts. Ukraine should accept a “dirty deal” preserving its remarkable resilience and deterrence while minimizing further devastation, rather than chasing moral absolutes. Total security via NATO is unrealistic, so Kyiv must rely on its own strength and realistic external support.

articles.title: What Chicago's fight against ICE can teach us all about how to resist oppression | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: A harrowing US podcast documents a community’s struggle against immigration raids – and warns us about herd mentality, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: In Rogers Park, Chicago, residents formed Protect Rogers Park to shield undocumented immigrants from ICE’s new raids on schools, churches and hospitals under Trump. They deploy nonviolent tactics—walking in front of agents, coded whistle alerts and rapid community call lines—to warn and slow deportations. The podcast Criminal reframes the federal government as the true “criminal” breaching law. Columnist Zoe Williams warns against herd mentality and argues that resisting xenophobic policies early is key to preventing authoritarian drift. Drawing on Hannah Arendt’s notion of synchronisation, she connects these actions to broader threats of enforced conformity under authoritarian regimes.

articles.title: What could be putting young women off marriage? It really isn’t that much of a mystery | Naoise Dolan
articles.trailText: Survey data suggests more and more girls can’t imagine getting married, while their male counterparts are keener. That disparity holds a clue, says writer Naoise Dolan
articles.summary: Post-pandemic marriage rates in England and Wales have fallen nearly 9% while civil partnerships rose comparably; US data show similar declines. The Vatican’s 40-page note ‘Una Caro’ defends monogamy. A University of Michigan survey finds only 61% of high-school girls versus 74% of boys hope to wed. Naoise Dolan argues women are deterred by unrealistic male expectations, the proliferation of "situationships," and objections to marriage’s legal coercion—tax incentives, hospital visitation rights and exclusion of non-monogamous or communal relationships. Financial instability, pandemic-era care burdens and the reframing of marriage as an economic capstone further shift young women away from tying the knot.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Ukraine peace talks: Putin is taking Trump for another ride on the Kremlin carousel | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Russia’s president is only interested in a deal on Moscow’s terms. Equipping Kyiv with the resources to fight on is the quickest route to a just settlement
articles.summary: Editorial warns Putin sees Trump’s expired Thanksgiving deadline as leverage to impose a Moscow-centric settlement on Ukraine, demanding further eastern territory and rejecting any ceasefire that secures Ukrainian sovereignty. Kremlin signals show Russia prefers battlefield attrition or a Trump-brokered deal over genuine negotiations. Meanwhile Andriy Yermak’s resignation deepens Kyiv’s vulnerability. The Guardian urges Europe to counter this by swiftly supplying robust financial and military aid—potentially via frozen-asset reparations, EU funds or joint borrowing—to strengthen Ukraine’s negotiating position and dissuade both Putin and Trump from a cynical carve-up.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Turner and Constable: radical in different ways | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Capturing the changing landscapes of the 18th century, the rivals transformed British art. The climate emergency gives new urgency to their work
articles.summary: Marking Turner and Constable’s 250th anniversaries, Tate Britain’s first dual exhibition frames them as rival radicals: Turner, daring with dramatic seascapes, steam trains and abolitionist critiques; Constable, revolutionary for elevating bucolic scenes and common life above classical themes. Both captured technological, political and environmental upheavals of their age—echoed today in works by George Shaw, David Hockney, Emma Stibbon and Olafur Eliasson—and survive reappraisals from abolitionist reframings of Turner’s Slave Ship to Peter Kennard’s anti-nuclear Hay Wain. Their art’s resonance underlines its urgency amid the climate emergency, inviting fresh perspectives on familiar masterpieces.

articles.title: Antisemitism allegations against the teenage Farage matter – look at what he went on to do | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: Farage has cosied up to US figures who espoused conspiracy theories about Jews. That kind of talk is becoming alarmingly mainstream on the Maga right, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland examines allegations from over 20 former schoolmates that Nigel Farage taunted Jewish peers with Nazi chants and gas jokes, highlighting his evasive, shifting denials. Freedland links this troubled youth record to Farage’s adult politics—repeated use of antisemitic tropes (‘globalists,’ George Soros, cultural Marxists), nods to conspiracy theories alongside figures like Alex Jones and Rick Wiles—and recalls rebukes from the Board of Deputies and CST. He warns this mirrors a broader MAGA-era turn toward conspiracy-driven antisemitism and aggressive Christian nationalism, a trend that puts global Jewish communities at risk and haunts Farage’s bid for power.

articles.title: Congratulations everyone! Starmer survives another week, and it’s only cost us £26bn | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Labour can proudly say this was a budget for working people – that is, if your job happens to be prime minister, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde skewers Labour’s latest budget, accusing Starmer’s government of a “buy-one-get-one-free” manifesto U-turn by scrapping day-one unfair dismissal rights for workers while preserving them for MPs until 2029. Deputy PM Angela Rayner, now resigned over tax controversies and rumored ITV stint, watches backbench malcontents extract more concessions. Business Secretary Peter Kyle claims the switch honors a non-existent “compromise” pledge. Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s tax-raising Budget piled on another £26bn, prompting IFS warnings of stagnating growth. Hyde argues the exercise was less about policy than placating backbenchers to keep Starmer safe ahead of May.

articles.title: Juries make baffling, flawed, human decisions. That's why we must keep them | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: David Lammy’s plans for justice on the cheap risk cutting the public out of the legal system – which will only hit confidence even more, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff warns that Justice Secretary David Lammy’s plan to scrap jury trials for all but the most serious offences threatens public confidence in the legal system. While juries can err, their diversity, transparency and peer representation bolster legitimacy and guard against biased judges or politicised courts. The real culprit behind delays is chronic underfunding of courts and allied services, not juries—Leveson’s cost-driven proposals free 20% of sitting time but fail to address backlogs rooted in budget cuts and growing case complexity.

articles.title: David Lammy is right to slash the use of juries – it’s an open-and-shut case | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: Barristers and criminals may not like the idea, but it’s key to reforming Britain’s antiquated and overloaded justice system, says the Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins argues that Britain’s jury system is an archaic drag on an overburdened courts system, with 80,000-case backlogs and two-year rape trial delays. He welcomes Justice Secretary David Lammy’s plan to limit juries to grave offences and shift most cases to judge-only trials, echoing Leveson’s recommendations. Highlighting that most European jurisdictions already rely on professional judges with lower prison rates, Jenkins criticizes the costly, performative rituals of jury service and the outdated barrister-solicitor split. He urges modernizing UK justice, prioritizing expertise, efficiency, and restorative approaches over spectacle and retribution.

articles.title: Why Starmer’s desire to govern as ‘Mr Rules’ is bound to fail | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: In the face of multiple crises, disruptive technology and populism, making Britain orderly again is an impossible goal, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Andy Beckett argues that Keir Starmer’s rule-fixated Labour is failing to lift polls because voters reject its sober, rigid agenda amid fluid crises. Communication gaps, minor scandals and weakened state capacity hinder enforcement of fiscal, immigration and protest rules. Public fears shift constantly—fueled by right-wing rhetoric—and remain drawn to radical or populist figures promising change or entertainment. In a digital, disruptive era, restoring order alone won’t inspire. Labour may need a more agile, less obsessively disciplinarian leadership to reconnect with voters.

articles.title: Germany raised its citizens to hate war. Now it wants us to enlist in the army – but we say no | Mithu Sanyal
articles.trailText: The war in Ukraine is a crime. But European leaders should be working for peace, not preparing young people to fight and die, says German academic Mithu Sanyal
articles.summary: Germany’s anti-war culture has been reversed by Chancellor Merz’s drive to transform the Bundeswehr into Europe’s strongest army, reintroduce conscription—rebranded ‘voluntary’—and even use lotteries if recruit numbers lag. Mithu Sanyal outlines Germany’s journey from post-1945 pacifism through 1999’s Kosovo turn to today’s cognitive warfare propaganda, citing proposals like prostate exams for conscripts and the Bundeswehr Reservists’ 1,000-daily-casualty expectation. She critiques awarding NATO the International Peace of Westphalia prize, the Protestant church’s rejection of pacifism, and feminist debates over gendered conscription. She argues true solidarity with Ukraine demands peace diplomacy, not mass mobilization, amid rising youth refusal and conscientious objection.

articles.title: The Guardian view on restricting trial by jury: a shabby evasion of responsibility | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The criminal cases backlog requires radical action, but the problem has been caused by government cuts, not by an ancient and fundamental liberty
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Justice Secretary David Lammy’s leaked plan would remove juries from most England and Wales criminal cases—limiting jury trials to murder, manslaughter, rape and public interest offences, and raising the non-jury threshold to five years’ maximum sentence. It argues that a 78,000-case backlog and time savings stem from austerity cuts to the Ministry of Justice and under-resourced magistrates courts, not juries. The piece notes Sir Brian Leveson’s more moderate three-year proposal and decries attacking an ancient liberty as a ‘shabby’ evasion of responsibility.

articles.title: The Guardian view on city living: an urban species is still adapting to our new environment | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: UN figures show that four-fifths of the global population now live in major settlements. We’re still figuring out how to cope
articles.summary: A new UN report finds over 80% of people now live in urban areas—up from 30% in 1950—with almost 500 cities exceeding one million residents. Jakarta’s surge to 42 million highlights infrastructure strain, pollution, flooding and inequality. State-planned relocations, like Indonesia’s new Borneo capital, often lag behind organic urban growth driven by rural hardship and economic opportunity. While cities generate unparalleled GDP and innovation—New York’s $1.8 trillion rivals nation-states—they also concentrate health risks, housing shortages and environmental harm. Achieving sustainable, equitable urban–rural integration and climate resilience is crucial as humanity adapts to its own urban ecosystems.

articles.title: How Amazon turned our capitalist era of free markets into the age of technofeudalism | Yanis Varoufakis
articles.trailText: Amazon Web Services owns the basic infrastructure for other businesses to operate online, turning even governments into its serfs, says the leader of MeRA25, Yanis Varoufakis
articles.summary: Yanis Varoufakis argues Amazon has replaced free-market capitalism with “technofeudalism,” owning AWS – the essential cloud backbone for firms (Uber, banks, healthcare), governments (Home Office, HMRC) and public services – and extracting feudal rents (up to 40%), locking customers and businesses into its fief. By fusing logistics, data extraction, algorithmic command and minute-by-minute worker surveillance, plus surveillance tech (Rekognition) and military contracts (Project Nimbus), Amazon binds societies. The Make Amazon Pay coalition of unions, climate, tax-justice, digital-rights and solidarity networks offers a unified, global resistance.

articles.title: I’m always on my phone, my girlfriend would rather communicate via woodland creatures. Somehow we make it work | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: She has read 57 books this year, whereas I have watched all of Selling Sunset. But we listen to each other – and enjoy it
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw, an online obsessive from Queensland, dates a 10-years-younger offline book-lover from Aotearoa who treats her phone like toxic waste, preferring telepathy or woodland creatures. She’s read 57 books this year; he’s binged Selling Sunset and compulsively tweets breaking news, viral gossip and niche memes. She shares emotional insights from her layered reading and craft projects; he relays pop-culture updates and news, acting as her digital conduit. Despite clashing habits—phone-glued versus phone-averse—they listen closely to each other’s worlds and have forged a balanced, joyful relationship.

articles.title: Eating Thanksgiving dinner at dinnertime is ludicrous. Here’s why | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Dining at 3pm allows for an ideal holiday schedule. Let’s retire the term ‘dinner’ from our Thanksgiving lexicon
articles.summary: Dave Schilling argues that holding Thanksgiving dinner at 3pm optimizes the holiday: you can eat a light breakfast, skip lunch, catch a movie or football beforehand, then enjoy the big meal with hours to digest, clean up and socialize without staying up late. He recalls his family’s all-day cooking tradition and ridicules the insistence on a literal 5–7pm “dinner.” He proposes dropping the term “dinner” in favor of “Thanksgiving feast,” scheduled at a sensible afternoon hour.

articles.title: Europe’s housing crisis is fuelling the rise of the far right. Our research shows how to address it | Tarik Abou-Chadi, Björn Bremer and Silja Häusermann
articles.trailText: The mantra of ‘build, build, build’ misses something crucial: that few can afford these new homes, say Tarik Abou-Chadi, Silja Häusermann and Björn Bremer
articles.summary: European housing costs have outpaced incomes, making buy/rent unaffordable and fueling far-right parties that scapegoat immigrants. Research by Abou-Chadi et al. distinguishes ‘housing as asset’ (market-driven price inflation) from ‘housing as social right’ (affordable, secure, non-speculative). They propose a progressive agenda: reinvest in broadly accessible social housing (eg Vienna’s 40% stock), combine new supply with redistribution to tackle under-occupation and overcrowding, and pursue density projects with participatory design, green space and rent protections. Funding should draw on wealth and capital gains taxes plus dedicated levies, while steering private investment via planning and loan conditions. Only by reframing housing as distributional justice can progressives undercut the far right’s politics of scarcity.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani is re-writing the political rules around support for Israel | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: If support for Israel is no longer de rigueur in New York, it may soon not be obligatory in Washington. That is good news for Palestinians
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani’s stunning NYC mayoral win on Nov 4 shattered the norm that successful local candidates avoid criticizing Israel: he labeled its Gaza campaign genocidal, called for equal rights for all Israelis and threatened to arrest Netanyahu in New York, yet won one-third of Jewish votes. Since taking office he’s reiterated these stances in Washington, challenging AIPAC’s influence and inspiring fellow progressives. His victory suggests US pro-Israel solidarity may fracture at the federal level, offering new leverage for Palestinian rights advocates.

articles.title: This was Rachel Reeves’s ‘live now, pay later’ budget. The big question is: what happens when ‘later’ arrives? | Larry Elliott
articles.trailText: The chancellor can only hope for an upturn in the government’s fortunes before tax increases kick in, says Guardian columnist Larry Elliott
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves unveiled a combative “live now, pay later” budget, front-loading spending and back-loading tax rises to shield voters ahead of the next election. Despite leaks and a chaotic OBR early release, forecasts beat City expectations, allowing Reeves to avoid a planned 2p basic-rate rise and boost her rainy-day fund to £22bn. Short-term giveaways—energy bill cuts, rail fare freeze, higher minimum wage—contrast with later tax-threshold freezes that will add £137/year for minimum-wage workers by 2030. Lacking new growth-boosting measures, the government has breathing space, but markets doubt its fiscal commitment and voters may balk at future pain.

articles.title: The two-child limit is abolished at last. Watch out for the narrative that will follow | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: The right is already in a frenzy about the migrant groups it thinks will benefit – and the budget contained other trade-offs, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: From April 2026, Chancellor Rachel Reeves has abolished the two-child benefit limit introduced in 2017, ending support caps that excluded aid for a third child and forced 1.7m children into poverty. The repeal will lift 450k children above the poverty line, overturn the punitive “rape clause” exemptions, and mark a major reversal of Conservative “welfare war” austerity. Labour delayed the change for 16 months, letting 109 children daily remain needy, while critics on the right decry a “Welfare party” and stoke anti-migrant sentiment. The move pairs with pension and disability tax-relief cuts, reflecting political trade-offs and an ongoing welfare debate.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves’s budget has inflamed, not calmed, Britain’s febrile mood | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: The chancellor’s statement will be remembered for the many taxes it raised, rather than the big one – income tax – it did not, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s 2025 budget, heavy on new taxes and stealth duties but holding income tax steady, has inflamed public and party anxiety instead of delivering promised competence, stability or growth. Leaked forecasts, fiscal reversals on child benefit caps and pension contributions, plus complex spending shifts, underscore Labour’s internal fractures and risk alienating swing voters and markets. Media and MPs applaud some measures – notably ending the two-child benefit cap – yet the drawn-out, ill-managed process highlights failures in budget prep and threatens Reeves’s authority and Labour’s electoral prospects.

articles.title: The rewriting of Australia’s nature laws comes as a relief, yet I can’t help feel a sense of foreboding | Georgina Woods
articles.trailText: The minister says quick approvals can happen while protecting the environment, but my experience tells me that haste brings unintended consequences
articles.summary: Greens negotiations spared new environment laws from fast-tracking coal and gas approvals, retaining commonwealth oversight of water-impacting mines, offering relief after the government’s initial bill threatened to hand states sweeping powers, curb community input and grant the minister bespoke regulatory waivers. Yet Georgina Woods warns that the push for quick approvals—even for renewables—risks unintended ecological losses, eroding habitats and public trust. She criticises the absence of mandatory greenhouse-gas or climate-change criteria despite dire national risk assessments and ICJ advisory opinions, forecasting long-term harm to Australia’s natural heritage and communities.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s budget: real gains for children and struggling families are a welcome shift | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Rachel Reeves’s interventions will ease the cost of living and suggest a desire to revive growth and protect public services
articles.summary: Labour’s budget, led by Rachel Reeves, delivers progressive measures—ending the two-child benefit cap (lifting 350,000 children from poverty), higher gambling taxes, frozen rail fares, a mansion levy and a ‘managed transition’ for North Sea energy. Yet the Office for Budget Responsibility warns underlying macro policy is conservative: £26bn in tax hikes on workers, stagnant 1.5% growth, flat wages and looming 3.3% cuts to councils, courts and police from 2029. Treasury optimism clashes with OBR scepticism, highlighting the political nature of fiscal space and calls for wealth taxation alongside social investment.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the peers lobbying scandal: Lords reform is a vital step for restoring trust in democracy | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Although some appointees make valuable contributions, the absurd archaism of the second chamber of parliament has to be addressed
articles.summary: Guardian editorial slams the undemocratic, archaic House of Lords after two peers—Lord Dannatt (ex-Army chief) and Lord Evans (businessman/Labour)—were suspended for four and five months following an undercover Guardian probe. Both offered to lobby ministers on behalf of property developers—Dannatt using his financial stakes, Evans sponsoring his son's company events—in breach of the code banning paid parliamentary services. With 800+ members claiming £371/day tax-free allowances, entrenched outside interests and just 10% of peers contributing half the work, Lords reform—removing hereditary seats and capping paid consultancy—remains stalled, eroding public trust.

articles.title: A budget to save Britain’s finances? More like Operation Save Our Skins | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Only 20% of tax rises will go towards making people better off. The vast majority will be spent meeting Labour’s fiscal rules and paying for U-turns, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty slams Rachel Reeves’s £26 bn autumn budget as a time-buying exercise that raises taxes to historic highs mainly to placate markets and satisfy strict fiscal rules. Only 20% of new revenue funds measures directly improving living standards—scrapped two-child benefit cap, energy and transport subsidies—while most offsets U-turns and shore up bond investors. Loose-change reforms look insufficient against rising food costs, stagnant wages, a real-income rise of just 0.25% annually until 2029, and creaking public services. The budget offers a short breather for Starmer’s government but fails to deliver a clear vision or durable growth strategy.

articles.title: At last, TV about influencers that isn’t cringe – I Love LA is my show of the year | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: It gets into its twentysomething characters’ heads in a way that’s fresh and real. You either get it, or you don’t, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: I Love LA, HBO’s eight-episode comedy by Rachel Sennott, is hailed as 2025’s standout series for its authentic, insider portrayal of Gen Z influencer life in East LA. Centered on Maia, a rookie entertainment manager, it tracks her efforts to launch friend Tallulah as a social-media star while bonding with uber-gay stylist Charlie and nepo baby Alani (True Whitaker). Unlike earlier clumsy influencer shows, it’s driven by sharp dialogue, confidence, and event-TV momentum—fan transcripts, Vulture recaps and obsessive viewership. Despite a slow start, its fresh sensibility and lived-in world outclass more stagey, youth-obsessed comedies.

articles.title: Has Rachel Reeves made the right calls in this budget? Our panel responds | Polly Toynbee and others
articles.trailText: After a tumultuous run-up to a make-or-break moment for the government, has the chancellor struck the right balance?
articles.summary: Labour chancellor Rachel Reeves’s first budget abolished the two-child benefit cap, expanded childcare, nurseries, breakfast clubs and free school meals, froze prescription, fuel and rail fares, and shifted green levies from bills to the exchequer. It raised £400m via a £2m-plus council tax surcharge and higher investment rates, but kept income tax thresholds static. Panelists praise child-first measures but deplore piecemeal wealth taxes, missed property-tax reform, looming stealth taxes on young savers, scant support for growth, and a lack of bold green or structural tax overhaul.

articles.title: Teenage dreams are never practical. But where would we be without the people who chased theirs? | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: It can feel wrong to encourage young people to shoot for the stars – yet if no one did, our world would be empty of the artists, actors, athletes and visionaries who give it so much pleasure and meaning, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles reflects on the tension between discouraging impractical teenage ambitions in crowded creative fields and celebrating those who defy the odds—like a Black Country head boy who, unlike starry-eyed peers, chose drama teaching, and Michael Sheen, who was scouted by Arsenal at 12 yet pursued acting. He warns that odds for success in media, sports or acting are astronomically long, but argues that artists, athletes and actors enrich culture precisely because they once placed wild bets on themselves. He urges us to salute these ‘deluded’ dreamers.

articles.title: Why on earth would Meghan still want to be called the Duchess of Sussex? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: She and her husband seem keen on their titles and accolades, and less enthusiastic about putting in the work that ordinarily goes with them, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Meghan still uses the title “Duchess of Sussex” despite stepping back from monarchy, raising questions about privilege vs responsibility. Despite residency in California and criticisms, Meghan and Harry cling to aristocratic honorifics, shrugging off why they don’t renounce them. Recent Harper’s Bazaar cover highlights Meghan demanding the title even among friends. While acknowledging the couple’s mistreatment by palace and press, Mahdawi argues they relish titles and accolades without fulfilling associated commitments. The duo accept accolades like Humanitarians of the Year while eschewing hands-on duties, prompting debate over entitlement versus genuine public service.

articles.title: Is Queens the new political belleweather of America? | Michael Massing
articles.trailText: National news organizations have treated the borough like flyover country. It’s time to change that
articles.summary: Queens, home to 2.3 million and 140 languages, epitomizes middle/working-class America’s diversity. Historically a Democratic stronghold, its 2024 shift saw Biden’s margin drop from 45 to 24 points as Latino, Chinese and South Asian voters reacted to pandemic crime and migrant influx. Simultaneously, insurgents Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Zohran Mamdani won big on programs like universal childcare and rent freezes, drawing diverse working-class and young professional support. Donald Trump’s Oval Office meeting with Mamdani underscored Queens’s new bellwether status. Yet national outlets like the New York Times have long overlooked these blue-collar communities, missing the borough’s rising political clout.

articles.title: If Epstein’s survivors don’t receive justice that is a ticking time bomb | V (formerly Eve Ensler)
articles.trailText: Millions of sexual violence survivors will not live a day longer with this torturous injustice
articles.summary: Playwright-activist V (formerly Eve Ensler) describes a visceral ‘corporeal attack’ triggered by Virginia Giuffre’s memoir, reviving her own childhood rapes and exposing how survivors are dehumanized, silenced and blamed. She decries media myths—’Why didn’t she leave?’—and a justice system that protects traffickers within a $200bn international sex-trafficking industry. Framing survivors’ pent-up trauma as a looming ‘time bomb,’ V warns that without accountability for Epstein and Maxwell, collective rage at this torturous injustice will inevitably explode.

articles.title: This French judge approved Netanyahu’s arrest warrant. Now Trump is targeting him | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Three ICC judges have been put on a sanctions list with terrorists after approving an arrest warrant for Israel’s prime minister. This is the charade of the ‘rules-based order’, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: French ICC judge Nicolas Guillou, who co-signed arrest warrants for Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu, ex-defence minister Yoav Gallant and Hamas commander Mohammed Deif over alleged war crimes and Gaza siege tactics, has been sanctioned by the United States, blacklisting him alongside terrorists and freezing his banking, travel and online access. The U.S., which never ratified the ICC treaty to shield itself and allies, brands the court “illegitimate” when it targets Israel, despite U.S. agencies finding deliberate aid blockades and genocide scholars deeming Gaza operations genocidal. Owen Jones argues this Western hypocrisy corrodes the rules-based order and signals geopolitical decline.

articles.title: Why do we find our pets so cute? Bold, bin-raiding raccoons may have a surprising answer | Helen Pilcher
articles.trailText: Known for their urban scavenging antics, raccoons are becoming more domesticated – so how they look will gradually change, says science writer Helen Pilcher
articles.summary: Urban North American raccoons are self-domesticating, with bold, bin-raiding individuals surviving and passing on less-skittish genes. A Frontiers in Zoology study by University of Arkansas found their snouts 3.5% shorter than rural raccoons, a hallmark of domestication syndrome—mirroring traits seen in Belyaev’s tame foxes via neural crest cell changes. Over generations, raccoons could develop floppy ears and waggy tails if selection continues, but full domestication needs human-led breeding. Meanwhile, secure trash and embrace these ‘trash pandas’ as nature’s adaptive survivors.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves has many problems. She’s realising that her Brexit bind may be the biggest of all | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: Brutal economic realities are prompting a shift in Labour’s tone on Europe. But will it dare tell the whole truth about Britain’s predicament, asks Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has hesitated to raise income tax in this week’s budget, opting for a succession of smaller levies after backtracking on earlier hints at breaking Labour’s manifesto pledge. Her incremental approach, reflecting tension between fiscal necessities and political authority, underlines the party’s struggle to articulate a compelling moral mission while balancing public service funding and growth forecasts. Meanwhile, Labour’s cautious overtures to the EU—limited customs tweaks and pending market access talks—underscore an unwillingness to confront Brexit’s strategic miscalculations, even as its economic fallout deepens.

articles.title: ‘We’re a bit jealous of Kneecap’: how Europe’s minority tongues are facing the digital future | Stephen Burgen
articles.trailText: What does it mean to lose a language, and what does it take to save it? Those were the big questions being asked in Barcelona recently, says freelance writer Stephen Burgen
articles.summary: At a Barcelona conference, speakers for Europe’s 60 minoritised tongues – from Breton to Welsh – warned that digital monolingualism and purist gatekeeping threaten their survival. Catalan, despite near-universal comprehension, is in decline due to rigid 'correctors' and youth loss of habit, whereas Irish thrives on authentic youth culture thanks to rappers Kneecap. Frisian and Basque cite immersive education and community creativity over strict purity, while Welsh and Gaeltacht regions see declines from depopulation and second-home demand, illustrating how socioeconomic inequality undermines language equality. Ensuring digital presence and flexible use is vital to prevent further language loss.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the carer’s allowance scandal: Liz Sayce’s review is a step towards fixing a broken system | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The DWP’s punitive approach to benefit overpayments has caused unnecessary suffering
articles.summary: The DWP’s handling of carer’s allowance overpayments has inflicted unjust debt and prosecutions on mainly older women. Liz Sayce’s independent review, ordered by Labour, praised raising the earnings threshold to £196/week and recommended compassionate telephone contact, but left unresolved £250m in debts, the benefit’s cliff-edge design, and whether wrongly prosecuted claimants get redress. Historic warnings about flawed rules and automation failures went unheeded. The review marks progress but the real test is swift debt review, rule reform and leadership accountability under the new government.

articles.title: The Guardian view on renewing municipal England: the Tories’ malign legacy lives on | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Labour is putting in place some laudable reforms. But councils need to be given financial sustainability and enabled to move beyond crisis management
articles.summary: Before 2010, councils ran Sure Start centres, libraries and youth services, but austerity under successive Conservative governments has left them financially crippled. Labour’s new local government minister, Alison McGovern, has introduced multi-year settlements, targeted funding for deprived areas and a modest tourist levy to ease pressures. Yet adult social care now consumes over two-thirds of budgets, a delayed SEND white paper masks hidden debt and a planner exodus threatens housing targets. Asset sales and service cuts corrode community cohesion. True renewal, the editorial argues, requires genuine financial sustainability and fiscal headroom beyond crisis management.

articles.title: The majority of doctors supported the recent strike. So why did the Department of Health suggest the opposite? | Peter Kellner
articles.trailText: It would seem that poll data was cherrypicked and then used to brief the Times. Such distortion of facts from a public body should alarm us all, says former president of YouGov Peter Kellner
articles.summary: Peter Kellner critiques the Department of Health’s handling of a Savanta poll on junior doctors’ strike, revealing it concealed Q9 showing 69% support and only 12% opposition and highlighted Q10 conditions for calling off strike. He notes the Times headline falsely claimed majority opposition based on a question about NHS training incentives. Kellner accuses officials of cherrypicking data to spin the narrative in the Times, violating British Polling Council transparency rules. He demands accountability on who suppressed the results, questions internal decision-making and calls for comprehensive publication of government-commissioned opinion research to uphold public trust.

articles.title: JD Vance might want to run in 2028 – but does he have a Palantir-shaped problem? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The VP wouldn’t be where he is today without the patronage of the Palantir co-founder Peter Thiel. But with voters becoming more and more concerned about the firm’s surveillance tech, could that relationship affect his chances, asks Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: JD Vance, eyed as a 2028 GOP contender, faces scrutiny over his ties to Palantir and benefactor Peter Thiel. Thiel’s mentorship and $15m campaign backing, combined with Palantir’s controversial surveillance contracts—from ICE deportation logistics and its “ImmigrationOS” to predictive policing for Israel—have raised alarms about privacy and authoritarian tech. Right-wing influencers like Joe Rogan and Tucker Carlson have publicly questioned Palantir’s profiling capabilities. While Vance can reshape his persona, his deep links to the “AI arms dealer of the 21st century” may prove a significant liability in a presidential bid.

articles.title: Does methylene blue really have wellness benefits or will it just leave you with the blues? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: The fabric dye is popular in wellness circles, with a laundry list of claimed benefits – but it also carries serious risks
articles.summary: Methylene blue, a synthetic textile dye turned medicine, was historically used against malaria and now treats methemoglobinemia and poisoning. Promoted by RFK Jr, Joe Rogan and wellness influencers for cognitive, energy, anti-ageing and antioxidant benefits, its evidence rests on animal and in vitro studies, with no proven gains in healthy humans and failed Alzheimer’s trials. Regulators warn of serious risks—nausea, tachycardia, confusion, skin discoloration and serotonin syndrome with SSRIs; at high doses it can paradoxically induce methemoglobinemia—and Australian poison centres report rising exposure calls.

articles.title: The Comey and James dismissals are a reminder of Trump’s lawlessness | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: A judge tossed indictments against two of the president’s political enemies, standing against politicized prosecutions
articles.summary: Federal judge Cameron M. Currie dismissed indictments against former FBI director James Comey and New York AG Letitia James as “unlawful exercises of executive power,” finding interim U.S. attorney Lindsey Halligan lacked statutory and constitutional authority by evading Senate confirmation. Currie’s ruling—aligned with similar rebukes in New Jersey, Nevada and Los Angeles—marks a judicial pushback against the Trump–Bondi effort to weaponize prosecutions of political opponents. It reaffirms procedural safeguards in federal appointments and, in Comey’s case, precludes refiling due to the statute of limitations.

articles.title: What can we learn from RFK Jr's 'erotic poetry'? That Americans need to get better at enjoying a scandal | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The US health secretary’s ‘digital affair’ with Olivia Nuzzi doesn’t need sombre analysis. Take it from this Brit: sometimes laughter is the only option, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers the US media’s solemn coverage of Robert F. Kennedy Jr’s X-rated “digital affair” with political reporter Olivia Nuzzi, lampooning the grandiose bamboo and wildfire metaphors in Ryan Lizza’s Substack and Nuzzi’s memoir. She argues America needs to lighten up—embrace laughter over scandal, rather than treating salacious poetry as high tragedy—even as outlets like Vanity Fair awkwardly navigate their own ethics dramas. A call to stop the solemnity and start enjoying the spectacle.

articles.title: The shameful attacks on the Covid inquiry prove it: the right is lost in anti-science delusion | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: There is nothing wrong with questioning the mighty cost of the lockdowns, but we can’t let hardline libertarians rewrite Britain’s pandemic history, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee condemns right-wing libertarian attacks on the Covid inquiry, arguing their anti-science tradition—from seatbelts to vaccination—undermined timely lockdowns that likely cost 23,000 UK lives. She highlights Tory figures like Johnson, Hannan, Young and media outlets that branded restrictions pointless, even as comparisons (Norway vs Sweden) show lockdowns halved per-capita deaths. Toynbee urges a sober debate on lockdown trade-offs—£310–£410 bn costs versus QALYs saved—warning that extremist deregulators will never weigh public health against their fetish for “freedom.”

articles.title: Is the Democratic party embracing Bernie Sanders-style politics? | Dustin Guastella
articles.trailText: Maybe. Let’s hope it is not too late for Democrats to win back the working class and Washington
articles.summary: After November’s Democratic victories, moderates, populists, and socialists have coalesced around an affordability agenda, ditching ‘wokeness’ for a populist economic program championed even by centrist James Carville. Proposals include a $20 minimum wage, universal childcare, free higher education, utility investments, and direct attacks on billionaires and Wall Street. Guastella warns progressives against alienating moderates with fringe cultural demands and urges unified populist pressure to reindustrialize America, deglobalize supply chains, rebuild infrastructure, and strengthen labor rights. This seismic shift, echoing Sanders’ crusade, may be Democrats’ last chance to reclaim the working-class base and retake Washington.

articles.title: I went to an M&S opening and it was mobbed. Why are people so weird about shops? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: I thought it would just be big news for me but I had reckoned without the TikTok generation, mums staring at the premixed cocktails and the yoga-mat brigade stalking every aisle, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams describes her shock at the frenzy surrounding the opening of a new M&S in Clapham Common. Avid fans queued the entire high street, joined by TikTok influencers hunting limited-edition biscuits, local mums inspecting premixed cocktails, and the yoga-mat set scrutinising healthy aisles. Despite two nearby branches, shoppers embraced this launch as a communal ritual—a “cathedral” of quality where everyday treats like crisps become a statement of deserving the best.

articles.title: An uncomfortable truth for our leaders: there’s a limit to how ‘human’ we want you to be | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Bleary-eyed in pyjamas in a new film, Jacinda Ardern’s pleas for compassion are hard to ignore. But in real crises, the fallibility of politicians can be terrifying, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: In her Guardian column, Gaby Hinsliff uses Jacinda Ardern’s upcoming documentary and memoir to explore the paradox of humanising political leaders. While showing Ardern juggling motherhood and premiership fosters empathy, it also risks obscuring accountability during crises. Hinsliff contrasts Ardern’s praised pandemic strategy—early border closures and targeted lockdowns—with its social costs, and notes UK politicians’ similar personal outreach. Ultimately she argues that voters’ discomfort with leaders’ fallibility reflects a demand for near-superhuman performance in existential emergencies.

articles.title: Is British politics immune to US-style rightwing Christianity? We’re about to find out | Lamorna Ash
articles.trailText: Nigel Farage and Tommy Robinson are increasingly espousing Christian ‘values’, and a wealthy US legal group is becoming influential – this could have dire consequences, says author Lamorna Ash
articles.summary: Author Lamorna Ash warns Britain’s right is adopting US-style evangelical politics: figures like Nigel Farage, Reform MP Danny Kruger and ex-extremist Tommy Robinson invoke Judeo-Christian values. Advisors like James Orr and US legal group Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF) are boosting Christian culture-war tactics—litigating abortion-clinic protests as free speech, lobbying on campus speech, and shaping public debate on abortion and LGBT rights. This trend reframes Islam as an existential threat and exploits generational divides over abortion. A struggle for Christianity’s meaning on the hard right could reshape UK politics.

articles.title: Australia doesn’t need another migration ‘debate’. We need leaders brave enough to tackle inequality for all | Giridharan Sivaraman
articles.trailText: Taking the easy but misleading route of blaming migrants for economic insecurity only serves to stoke the already smouldering fires of racism
articles.summary: Australia’s recurring migration debates wrongly scapegoat migrants for economic insecurity, housing stress and low wages, fueling racism and division. Giridharan Sivaraman argues policymakers must shift focus from cutting migrant numbers to addressing structural inequality—ensuring affordable housing, robust social security, fair wages, strengthened workplace protections and anti-racism frameworks. Rather than pitting workers against each other, leaders should hold corporations and the wealthy accountable, reinforce migrant rights and positive duty in employers, and tackle root causes of poverty to build a fairer society for all. She highlights migrants’ net contributions and urges endorsement of the national anti-racism framework to protect all workers.

articles.title: The Guardian view on a viable peace framework for Ukraine: with Europe’s help, Zelenskyy can have better cards | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The 28-point plan outlined last week by the US would have delivered peace on Putin’s terms. EU leaders must help Kyiv resist the bullying
articles.summary: Condemning Trump’s 28-point peace plan as a repackaging of Putin’s maximalist demands—territorial concessions in Donbas, sovereignty curbs and army limits—this editorial urges EU leaders to take a proactive role, using frozen Russian assets to underwrite a €140 billion reparations loan, boost arms and financial aid, and apply economic pressure on Moscow. Only by strengthening Zelenskyy’s negotiating hand and upholding Ukraine’s sovereignty can Europe help secure a just, sustainable peace.

articles.title: The Guardian view on UN climate talks: they reveal how little time is left | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A fragile Cop30 consensus is a win. But only a real bargain between rich and poor nations can weather the climate shocks that are coming
articles.summary: At COP30 in Belém delegates secured only a fragile consensus, lacking a fossil fuel phase-out, postponed climate finance and no deforestation roadmap. The talks barely held, highlighting the need for a fair bargain between rich and developing nations. The global south demands grant-based funds to build flood defences, resilient agriculture and disaster recovery; rich countries, hampered by populism and geopolitics, resist. With the US absent and China-West tensions rising, Least Developed Countries left with stalled promises will press for meaningful finance at COP31 in Turkey and COP32 in Ethiopia. Annual adaptation needs of $310bn by 2035 outstrip the $26bn delivered in 2023.

articles.title: It was my late mother’s birthday – and I spent it exactly as she would have wanted | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: I worried about nuclear war throughout my childhood, partly because it was the 80s, and partly because we were always demonstrating against it. On this important day, I knew where I needed to be, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: On her late mother’s birthday, Zoe Williams honored her lifelong anti-nuclear activism by attending a Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament meeting. She recalls childhood protests—‘Protest and Survive’ stickers, Greenham Common camps and Tony Benn speeches detailing bomb effects. Today Prof Mary Kaldor argues cold-war deterrence is obsolete against hybrid threats, urging investment in democratic resilience. Patricia Lewis warns nukes’ true deterrent is democracy itself. Williams leaves feeling bittersweet—missing her mum while renewing her commitment to opposing nuclear annihilation, just as her mother would have wanted.

articles.title: Trump’s ‘peace plan’ was a pro-Kremlin abomination whose failure is a glimmer of hope for Ukraine | Rajan Menon
articles.trailText: Following criticism, the president accused Ukraine of ingratitude but also added the plan was ‘not my final offer’. Which parts of it will survive?, says Rajan Menon of the City College of New York
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s 28-point Ukraine peace plan, crafted with Putin confidant Kirill Dmitriev and advisers Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff, heavily favours Russia. It caps Ukraine’s army at 600,000, forces constitutional abandonment of NATO aspirations, recognizes Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk as Russian, freezes frontlines with Russian gains, demands “de-Nazification” to validate Moscow’s propaganda, grants Kremlin war-crimes immunity, and offers sanctions relief and G8 readmission to Russia. Negligible Russian concessions contrast with sweeping Ukrainian sacrifices. Critics say its collapse would be a rare win for Kyiv; Trump insists the plan isn’t final.

articles.title: Sure, people tell you about sleepless nights. But why does no one mention the hell that is a parent WhatsApp group? | Sean Szeps
articles.trailText: You wake up to messages, you go to sleep to messages, you duck into a meeting and come back to 64 unread notes about sunscreen
articles.summary: Sean Szeps likens parent WhatsApp groups to hell: a relentless, always-on digital micro-community that transforms simple school updates into 24/7 noise. Group chats overflow with reminders, reposts and performance signaling—everyone scrambles over sunscreen alerts, heritage dress notices and bake-sale pleas. What began as coordination has morphed into a theatre of parenting confusion, short-circuiting boundaries and real attention. Szeps, now unwitting WhatsApp rep, misses the quiet confidence and offline trust of backpack notes or pickup chats. He argues modern parenting needs less connection and more space: stepping back isn’t failure but freedom from the tyranny of constant reminders.

articles.title: The ‘war on terror’ has killed millions. Trump is reviving it in Venezuela | Daniel Mendiola
articles.trailText: After decades of terrorizing civilians in the name of fighting terror, the White House is trying to do it with even less oversight
articles.summary: Under Trump’s second term, US forces have massed off Venezuela’s coast, killing over 80 civilians in pre-emptive strikes on “narco-terrorist” boaters authorized with minimal oversight. Drawing on a state-terrorism framework, Mendiola highlights Brown University’s estimates of 400,000+ direct and 3.5m indirect civilian deaths in the post-9/11 era, plus 500,000 annual deaths from sanctions, to argue that Trump is reinvigorating a lethal “war on terror” while eviscerating judicial checks. By asserting the president’s prerogative to define “rebellion” and “terrorist,” backing unverifiable claims that each strike saves 25,000 lives, the administration side-steps constitutional limits, risking a new wave of unchecked violence against Venezuelan civilians.

articles.title: Horror stories of a ‘feminised workplace’ mask the real crisis in male identity | Finn Mackay
articles.trailText: Stereotypes that centre men’s worth in their work are strangling sensible debate, and letting down women too, says author Finn Mackay
articles.summary: Finn Mackay critiques the “Great Feminisation” thesis that blames women’s presence at work for eroding masculine values, arguing it rests on limiting gender stereotypes. She traces how paid employment has long defined men’s worth, generating a “masculinity burden” that intensifies male economic anxieties. UK data show 88% of men equate manhood with breadwinning, yet many struggle financially, while women face similar precarity plus caregiving roles. Mackay insists universal solutions—secure wages, affordable housing, flexible care and shared domestic duties—benefit all and reflect feminist, not “feminised,” workplace reform.

articles.title: I endured an English public school. But that’s not the only reason I’m unsurprised about the Farage allegations | Musa Okwonga
articles.trailText: Let’s put aside the schooldays accusations and look, instead, at the Reform leader’s path since then. I think a pretty clear picture of the man emerges, says author and podcaster Musa Okwonga
articles.summary: Musa Okwonga reflects on Nigel Farage’s alleged schoolboy racism at Dulwich College as symptomatic of entrenched bigotry among England’s elite public schools. Drawing on his Eton experience, he argues school-era prejudice persisted and evolved into Farage’s adult xenophobia, driving Brexit, embracing Germany’s far right, and influencing harsh immigration policies that fuel NHS shortages. Okwonga warns social media algorithms and elite complicity have amplified his rhetoric: closed borders for the many, open doors for the super-rich, while the UK remains underestimating his enduring, transformative influence.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood is an avatar of open Britain – that’s what makes her fable about immigration so seductive | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: ‘She is the daughter of immigrants,’ supporters of her cruel asylum policies say. ‘How can she be wrong?’ Let me put them straight, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik argues that home secretary Shabana Mahmood's asylum crackdown is cloaked in a personal immigrant narrative to justify punitive policies—deportations of UK-born children, tougher removal of refugees and asylum seekers, cuts to support and extended settlement, and linking racism to excessive immigrant rights. Malik deems this cynical identity politics akin to Suella Braverman's gambit, a move by Labour to outflank the right that distracts from economic and social failures and legitimises xenophobia under a moral veneer. She warns this narrative muffles criticism and masks political convenience, appeasing right-wing sentiment while abandoning vulnerable migrants.

articles.title: We delivered a clear message at Cop30: the delayers and defeatists are losing the climate fight | Ed Miliband
articles.trailText: For all its flaws, the Brazil conference underlined the wish by a global majority for clean energy and climate action – and the UK will keep leading the way, says Ed Miliband, secretary of state for energy security and net zero
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, Brazil, over 190 nations reaffirmed the Paris Agreement and the 1.5°C target, signaling a global majority behind clean energy. The UK, responsible for just 1% of emissions, announced major investments in renewables, nuclear and home upgrades while co-leading coalitions like an 83-country fossil fuel transition group and the Belém Mission to 1.5. Key deliverables include Brazil’s roadmap to phase out fossil fuels, the Tropical Forest Forever Facility to end deforestation by 2030, $300bn annual climate finance targets for developing countries and the Global Climate Action Agenda. Ed Miliband asserts that multilateralism prevails as delayers and defeatists lose ground.

articles.title: The Guardian view on animal testing: we can stop sacrificing millions of lives for our own health | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: New technologies can reduce our reliance on animal experiments. This isn’t just morally right, it could have scientific and economic benefits too
articles.summary: An editorial endorses the UK government’s new strategy to phase out animal testing—2.64m procedures occurred in 2024—by banning cruel protocols like the forced swim test and eye/skin causticity trials. It highlights £60m funding and a timeline to validate alternatives such as organ-on-a-chip and machine-learning toxicity models. Emphasizing moral, scientific, and economic benefits, it argues these methods can match or outperform animal tests, tapping global markets and ending the needless suffering of rodents, birds, and fish.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the young person’s benefit trap: Rachel Reeves must fix this flaw in the budget | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The system discourages young homeless people from earning more – that’s the very opposite of Labour’s aim to make work pay
articles.summary: This Guardian editorial warns that UK benefit rules penalise 16-24-year-olds in supported housing, who lose 65p of benefit for every £1 earned over a £5 allowance (versus a 55p taper for private renters). It creates a ‘cliff edge’ that deters extra work—losing over £100 for an 11th hour—undermining Labour’s ‘make work pay’ pledge. Campaigners call to raise the allowance to around £57 and cut the taper to 55%. Chancellor Reeves should seize the budget to extend fair incentives and boost both employment and housing stability.

articles.title: Homesickness is a form of loss which may never grant closure. But a heart in two places can still find joy | Gaynor Parkin
articles.trailText: For those who live far from home, feeling a mix of grief and gratitude is not as contradictory as it may seem
articles.summary: Suzanne, who splits her life between two countries, finds extended visits deepen her homesickness as she grieves everyday ordinary moments with loved ones abroad. Clinician Gaynor Parkin frames this enduring ache as ‘ambiguous loss,’ drawing on Pauline Boss’s research and Lucille Wong’s idea that living between two worlds carries both sorrow and gratitude. Therapy and grief expert Lucy Hone’s advice—to oscillate between confronting and momentarily avoiding grief—help Suzanne cultivate mixed emotions of sadness and joy. By making space for both, she and many migrants learn to hold connections in two places without closure but with ongoing hope.

articles.title: Pub quiz cheating may not be a matter of life and death - but it can feel that way | Janice Hallett
articles.trailText: Weeks before the Manchester cheating story broke, I published a murder mystery novel with almost the same plot. It’s no coincidence
articles.summary: In this column, Janice Hallett draws parallels between a real-life Manchester pub quiz cheating scandal—where a team used voice-activated smartwatches to win a £30 bar voucher—and her new crime novel, The Killer Question, in which quiz-night sabotage leads to murder. She explores the surprisingly high emotional stakes of pub quizzing, showing how knowledge, identity and social status intertwine with the quizmaster’s final authority. Through personal anecdotes of hostile venues, narrow defeats and fierce competitiveness, Hallett argues that quizzes offer an inclusive, egalitarian test of honesty and intellect, driven by trust as much as facts.

articles.title: With a million young people locked out of work, the UK’s hidden jobs crisis is only growing | John Harris
articles.trailText: Held back by Covid and then phased out by AI, Britain’s so-called Neets are desperately seeking a secure future. Who will offer them hope? asks Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: ONS figures show roughly 946,000 UK 16–24-year-olds are Neets—neither in education, employment nor training—exacerbated by Covid lockdowns and AI-driven recruitment. Government reviews led by Alan Milburn and budget focus from Rachel Reeves propose youth guarantees and mandatory placements but risk punitive benefit conditionality. Charity Rise Up CEO Roman Dibden highlights anxiety, social-skill gaps, complex benefits traps and 170,000 under-25s job losses via “last in, first out.” IFS and Resolution Foundation experts warn systemic failures in schools, underfunded FE colleges and AI replacing entry-level roles deepen this hidden jobs crisis, fuelling youth insecurity and political risk.

articles.title: Four ways AI is being used to strengthen democracies worldwide | Nathan E Sanders and Bruce Schneier
articles.trailText: The dangers of artificial intelligence and its potential to consolidate power are clear. But used fairly, it can be a boon for good government
articles.summary: Sanders and Schneier highlight four global examples of AI boosting democratic processes: in Japan, Takahiro Anno’s AI avatar and the Team Mirai–built Mirai Assembly app engage voters; in Brazil, AI handles judicial research, case routing and backlog reduction; in Germany, AI chat-based tools like Wahlweise and Wahl.chat personalize non-partisan voting advice; and in California, CalMatters’ AI Tip Sheets surface accountability leads for journalists. They argue trustworthy “public AI” (e.g., Switzerland’s open-source Apertus) can amplify civic participation, distribute power, and safeguard democracy if deployed under democratic oversight.

articles.title: Maga is in meltdown over a preppy pink sweater for men. So, what exactly is the problem? | Ellie Violet Bramley
articles.trailText: The outrage a J Crew jumper has provoked shows that the US right’s sense of masculinity is far more fragile than it would care to admit, says freelance writer Ellie Violet Bramley
articles.summary: J Crew’s $168 pink Fair Isle wool crewneck jumper has sparked a MAGA meltdown on X: conservative commentator Juanita Broaddrick asked, “Would you men wear this?” and followers replied with threats of emasculation—“something a sorority girl would wear,” “not gay,” “I’m a man, not gay”—even Photoshopping Gavin Newsom’s head onto the model. The uproar reveals Trump-era right-wing factions clashing over fragile masculinity, despite pink’s century-long association with men’s fashion, and probably grants J Crew unplanned culture-war publicity.

articles.title: Who can tame Trump? An unlikely candidate is emerging: the Catholic church | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: Inequality, immigration and civil rights are the battlegrounds on which the church, and some other Christian denominations, are fighting, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall argues that US institutions—the conservative Supreme Court, partisan Congress and compliant media—have failed to curb Donald Trump’s “rolling constitutional coup.” Into this void steps Pope Leo XIV and the US Catholic bishops, who have issued a landmark message condemning mass deportations, ICE abuses, widening inequality, cuts to healthcare and food assistance, and climate-denial policies. From New Jersey to California, parish priests and grassroots activists are organising protests, legal aid and boycotts to defend migrants, civil rights and voting protections. With 22% of US adults identifying as Catholic, Leo XIV could uniquely mobilise moral authority to shame and restrain Trump’s authoritarian agenda—if backed by “all men and women of good will.”

articles.title: Party season is coming – and I am the tense, sweaty, shrill hostess with the leastess | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Whether it’s panicking about the mess, forgetting drinks orders or frantically asking if people are having fun, I’m no fun at parties. How do the bon vivants do it, asks Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson confesses she’s the nervous, detail-obsessed hostess who panics over mess, drinks orders and coat piles, fretting in high-pitched ’helicopter-host’ mode to ensure everyone’s having fun. She contrasts herself with ‘effortless bon vivants’ who calmly mingle amid chaos, then traces her own awkward pedigree—from a pyjama-clad dad who signalled parties were over, to a mother’s rigid lunch timings. Concluding she’ll never be a natural entertainer, Hudson decides her best gift to friends is simply never hosting again.

articles.title: Australia’s unconventional Cop31 deal puts Chris Bowen at the helm of the world’s most complex negotiations. It’s a huge opportunity | Thom Woodroofe and Dean Bialek
articles.trailText: Australia may not be hosting Cop31, but the unprecedented Turkey partnership is a real chance to secure global influence and turbocharge a new green zeitgeist
articles.summary: After missing out on hosting Cop31, Australia’s partnership with Turkey elevates climate minister Chris Bowen to president of negotiations, positioning him to shape global net-zero language. Strategies include enshrining benchmarks to triple renewables, double efficiency and bolster electrification; anchoring Pacific priorities via a high-profile pre-Cop gathering targeting a 100% renewable Pacific, resilient financing and a just fossil-fuel transition; and launching early diplomatic, industry and investment drives—from green-steel pilots to an Adelaide green trade fair—to turbocharge Australia’s green export economy and global influence.

articles.title: Five theories to explain the Donald-Zohran meet-cute | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: Why was the president so pleased to hang with the democratic socialist? Perhaps we’ll never know
articles.summary: Dave Schilling dissects the surprising Oval Office “meet-cute” between President Trump and NYC’s newly elected mayor Zohran Mamdani, once a self-declared anti-Trump democratic socialist. Schilling proposes five tongue-in-cheek theories: a mutual grasp of New York’s attention economy; Trump’s affinity for winners; Mamdani’s status as a non-threatening millennial; shared enthusiasm for the Knicks; and Trump’s hypothetical fondness for filmmaker Mira Nair, Mamdani’s mother. Despite these speculative explanations, the author concludes the real motive behind their unexpected camaraderie—and Trump’s sudden praise—remains a mystery.

articles.title: Why is Ghislaine Maxwell getting the Club Fed treatment? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Her privileges in America’s two-tiered legal system reportedly range from from unlimited toilet paper to puppy playtime
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi critiques Ghislaine Maxwell’s VIP treatment at the federal prison camp in Bryan, Texas—unlimited toilet paper, puppy playtime, custom meals and tech access—after a July visit from DOJ deputy AG Todd Blanche. Rep. Jamie Raskin and others decry this ‘concierge’ approach, noting most inmates get just two rolls weekly and women endure harsher conditions or await trial in local jails due to unaffordable bail. Maxwell’s cushy confinement illustrates America’s two-tiered justice system.

articles.title: Trump’s Ukraine peace plan is a gift to Putin | Kenneth Roth
articles.trailText: The plan would leave Ukraine’s democracy in jeopardy and its sovereignty compromised
articles.summary: Trump’s 28-point Ukraine peace plan, crafted by US and Russian officials without Ukrainian or European input, rewards Putin by freezing Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, forcing Ukraine to abandon Donetsk, and cutting its armed forces to 600,000 while placing no limits on Russia. It bans NATO membership and troop deployments, offers only vague intelligence and logistical aid in lieu of direct defense, proposes lifting sanctions and G8 readmission, and extends amnesties for Russian atrocities, jeopardizing Ukraine’s sovereignty, democracy and frontline defenses.

articles.title: Republicans will be left holding the bill for Trump’s policies in the midterms | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: The abject obedience of GOP members and the 4 November election results do not augur well for Republicans in the midterms
articles.summary: After Trump’s hollow “mandate” collapsed following failures on inflation and court battles, Republican election performance on 4 November exposed voter repudiation: GOP turnout plunged, Democrats led generic ballots by 11–14 points, and Dems swept New Jersey, Virginia, plus flipped state legislative seats, projecting a 60-seat gain in 2026 midterms. Congressional Republicans, terrified of Trump’s reprisals, fell silent on issues like the Epstein files, severing ties with their base. With Trump’s unpopularity dragging down candidates and polarization favoring Democrats (81% strong disapproval among independents), GOP faces a punishing midterm reckoning for abetting his agenda.

articles.title: My schoolmates mocked me for being a UPF-free, ‘weird lunchbox’ kid. Turns out my mum was right all along
articles.trailText: In the 90s my mum embarrassed me with her rejection of ultra-processed foods – but the growing body of evidence about them is vindicating her, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett recalls being teased as a ‘weird lunchbox’ kid in the 1990s because her mother refused ultra-processed foods. Recent studies linking UPFs to harm across every organ have vindicated her mum’s early advocacy for cooking from scratch. Cosslett now cooks fresh for her own family but warns against shaming individuals who lack time or resources, stressing that systemic change is needed to tackle processed food’s health risks and economic barriers to healthy eating. She reflects on her own mix of guilt and gratitude as a parent now upholding the same principles.

articles.title: Who knew it would take an American pope to remind us of the value of art and good taste? | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: Anti-AI and pro-beauty, Leo XIV has proved an unlikely custodian of culture – and a patron of meaningful work in a world of algorithmic slop, says Guardian assistant newsletter editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: In his early papacy, American Pope Leo XIV, hailed for anti-MAGA and pro-migrant stance, has emerged as a patron of culture, championing cinema and beauty against algorithmic sameness. He released a list of favorite films, hosted Spike Lee, Darren Aronofsky, Cate Blanchett and Greta Gerwig at the Vatican, urging filmmakers to explore violence, isolation and poverty and embrace “beauty” beyond predictability. Critiquing AI’s artless slop, he positions art as a call to transcend algorithms. By blending Catholic ritual with modern creativity—from Rosalía’s Lux project to potential Vatican–Hollywood collaborations—he reframes faith as a beacon of aesthetic wonder.

articles.title: The ‘Danish model’ is the darling of centre-left parties like Labour. The problem is, it doesn’t even work in Denmark | Cas Mudde
articles.trailText: This week’s local elections are the latest reminder that when social democrats move rightwards, they’re making a mistake, says academic and author Cas Mudde
articles.summary: Cas Mudde argues that centre-left parties like Britain’s Labour have mistakenly emulated Denmark’s Social Democrats’ hardline asylum stance—the so-called “Danish model”—hoping to win back far-right voters. He shows that in Denmark this shift failed: the Social Democrats stagnated around 20%, far-right factions resurged, and progressive urban electorates defected to the Greens and new left parties like SF. By abandoning socio-cultural leftism, ageing social-democratic bases erode and youth voters flee. Mudde urges social democrats to stop chasing nativist positions, reaffirm a bold progressive agenda, and rebuild trust with younger, diverse supporters.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Covid-19 inquiry: the UK did too little, too late. Lessons must be learned | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The latest report on the pandemic shows that grave failings were not limited to Boris Johnson. The government needs to prepare for the next crisis
articles.summary: The latest public inquiry finds all four UK administrations flawed: Northern Ireland hampered by political wrangling; Scotland’s Nicola Sturgeon sidelined colleagues; Wales under Mark Drakeford delayed autumn 2020 curbs.
