Boris Johnson’s government bears the heaviest blame for complacency, misinformation, lockdown breaches and a “lost month” in February 2020. Dominic Cummings fostered a civil service “culture of fear,” while DHSC officials including Chris Wormald resisted timely measures. With 45,632 care-home deaths pending investigation, bereaved families demand accountability and the stripping of Johnson’s privileges. The editorial urges urgent emergency planning reforms to avert future crises.

articles.title: The Guardian view on authentic casting in Wicked: finally a true celebration of difference | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The wider TV and film industries have a long way to go in including disabled actors and creators, and leaving stereotypes behind
articles.summary: Guardian editorial argues that while race, gender and sexuality have seen diversity efforts, disability remains under-represented: disabled actors are sidelined and often mis-portrayed (“cripping up”). In nearly a century only three disabled actors have won Oscars versus 25 able-bodied performers playing disabled roles. Wicked: For Good makes strides by casting wheelchair user Marissa Bode as Nessarose—adding agency and removing ‘fixing’ tropes—but a study found only 21% of US TV disability roles (2016–23) went to disabled actors. The industry must overhaul accessibility, hiring disabled writers and crew to ensure true inclusion.

articles.title: Vote for competent leaders, not entertainers – that’s what I wish the Covid report could say | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: To prevent a future pandemic we’d need agile leadership, smart decision-making, humility and trustworthiness. How does one build those into a political system, asks Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: Prof Sir Devi Sridhar critiques the UK Covid inquiry’s module 2 report, highlighting catastrophic political failures: Boris Johnson’s absent leadership, delayed containment versus South Korea and New Zealand, and the ill-conceived ‘eat out to help out’ scheme that fuelled a second wave. While vaccines and the NHS ultimately lowered mortality, the £200m inquiry adds little new insight. Sridhar argues future pandemic resilience demands agile, humble, detail-oriented leadership—competence over charisma—and strict anti-corruption laws to curb crisis profiteering, proposing a ‘Dame Michelle Mone Law’ to safeguard public funds in emergencies.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves is studiously ignoring the cause of Britain’s woes: the Brexit-shaped hole in its roof | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The autumn budget will mop up some damage, but the true source of the economic crisis is clear. The government should now fix it – tragically, it won’t, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland argues that Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s upcoming autumn budget will fail to address the underlying cause of Britain’s fiscal crisis: the ‘Brexit-shaped hole’ undermining growth. Post-2008 productivity in the UK has lagged G7 peers, real wages have stagnated for 17 years and exports have fallen by over 1% of GDP annually since leaving the EU single market. Britain’s services and finance sectors are also seeing outflows to EU capitals. Experts urge re-joining the single market or customs union to recoup up to £30 bn a year. Yet Labour’s tentative approach falls short of the bold reset the economy needs.

articles.title: Labour MPs face a serious dilemma on asylum seekers – but this is not the way out of it | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The party sees its harsh policies as politically necessary. But what happened to talking up the value of migrants for a thriving economy and society, asks Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Labour MPs, torn between empathy for refugees and electoral pressures, reluctantly back the government’s tougher asylum measures—mandatory deportations, extended limbo status, English and employment criteria—echoing median public opinion revealed by More in Common polling. While Shabana Mahmood’s bill envisions sending asylum seekers home once regimes fall and delaying settled status, Toynbee argues this fails to highlight migrants’ economic and social contributions: non-UK nationals boost GDP, fill 20% of NHS roles, and inject £23bn via international students. Labour’s silence on these positives cedes ground to anti-migrant sentiment. Deterrent policies risk undermining integration and fail without EU cooperation or sufficient processing capacity.

articles.title: AI is changing the relationship between journalist and audience. There is much at stake | Margaret Simons
articles.trailText: There is no point pretending that change is not happening, or that it can be avoided. But these are the risks we must address
articles.summary: Margaret Simons warns that AI-driven summaries in search engines and chatbots are disrupting the historic service relationship between journalists and audiences. By licensing vast archives to train AI, tech firms reduce direct traffic to news sites, eroding subscriptions and ad revenue. This transfer of gatekeeping power threatens content accuracy, human-curated discovery of unexpected stories, and public defence of media outlets. Simons urges publishers to accelerate in-house AI tools, improve archive searchability, and protect brand trust to maintain journalism’s public-interest role, argumentation depth and civic function amidst technological upheaval.

articles.title: The most shocking thing about beauty products for kids? Where the demand is coming from | Morwenna Ferrier
articles.trailText: A new brand flogging face masks for four-year-olds is disturbing, but it’s worth asking why children are asking for these products in the first place, says Guardian fashion and lifestyle editor Morwenna Ferrier
articles.summary: Morwenna Ferrier critiques Rini, a new skincare line marketing a Korean hydrating face mask to four-year-olds, as symptomatic of capitalism tapping ever-younger consumers. Ferrier traces the phenomenon alongside “Sephora kids,” noting how children, influenced by parental rituals and TikTok beauty tutorials, now actively demand products conflated with adult desires. While acknowledging children’s propensity for face paints and play, she warns of unregulated industry profit motives and potential skin harm. Drawing on dermatologists’ concerns and feminist analysis, Ferrier argues that marketing beauty to preschoolers embeds self-consciousness and reinforces gendered, sexualized play long before adolescence. The real issue lies in societal pressures and parental complicity fueling early cosmetic consumerism.

articles.title: Tech should help us be creative. AI rips our creativity away | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: AI-generated songs are topping Spotify charts. This isn’t about the ‘democratization’ of art – it’s about scale
articles.summary: Dave Schilling argues that AI music’s viral hits on Spotify show that automation, not democratization, robs us of creativity. Tools that once amplified human voice now swamp streaming platforms with low-quality, algorithm-driven songs—100m+ on Spotify—and value scale over curation or genuine joy. He challenges the notion that time spent equals happiness, condemning corporations’ obsession with engagement metrics. AI is no mere instrument but a “wet nurse” replacing personal effort, undermining artistic responsibility and turning creativity into data-driven noise.

articles.title: There’s a catastrophic black hole in our climate data – and it’s a gift to deniers | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: Climate sceptics tell us that more people die of extreme cold than extreme heat. What’s the truth? asks Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot exposes a critical data gap in global heat/cold mortality studies used by climate sceptics to downplay warming. The widely cited claim that cold kills nine times more people than heat rests on records from just 750 sites in 43 wealthy or temperate territories—excluding India, Pakistan, most of Africa, and other vulnerable regions. Sparse weather stations, underreported heatwave deaths (often coded as heart attacks), and defunct African observation networks create a “black hole” masking climate breakdown impacts. This ignorance, driven by funding bias and political indifference, undermines loss-and-damage compensation and fuels denial. Without robust data from hotter, poorer areas, the true human toll of extreme heat remains catastrophically underestimated.

articles.title: This is modern Britain – where a princess pleading for children’s rights seems almost radical | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: It is uncomfortable to watch royals appealing to the nation’s best instincts while an elected government feels compelled to chase our worst, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: The Princess of Wales delivered her first post-cancer speech advocating every child’s right to safety, love and belonging, urging respect for caregiving and nurturing family environments. Gaby Hinsliff contrasts this apolitical yet heartfelt royal plea with Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s plan to cut aid and deport failed-asylum-seeker families. The piece explores the unsettling gap between a monarchy safely championing compassion and a government chasing punitive immigration measures. It warns of potential value clashes if a Reform UK government scraps net zero and tightens immigration, leaving the heir-apparent and king at the centre of future constitutional and moral conflicts.

articles.title: Spain has too rosy a view of Franco’s regime. Let’s remind ourselves of its horrors | Giles Tremlett
articles.trailText: Little is taught about the murderous, incompetent dictatorship – and now almost one in five young people say Franco was good for the country, says historian Giles Tremlett
articles.summary: Historian Giles Tremlett warns Spain largely ignores the horrors of Franco’s 36-year dictatorship: 500,000 civil war deaths, 20,000 postwar executions, famines from autarky, and state terror via firing squads, torture, censorship, politicized education and gender oppression. Franco exploited Cold War anti-communism for U.S. backing, fueling a 1960s tourist-led boom while maintaining a repressive grip until 1975. Nostalgic Francoist narratives persist among far-right groups and families recalling only economic gains. With teachers often silent and nearly 20% of youth praising Franco, Tremlett urges comprehensive education on indoctrination and violence to combat amnesia.

articles.title: The Guardian view on devastation in Gaza: the world wants to move on, but Palestinians can’t | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Drenched by floods and abandoned amid the ruins, people in Gaza can draw no comfort from US plans
articles.summary: Despite an October ceasefire, Israeli strikes have persisted, killing dozens including children, while Gaza faces floods, winter displacement and critically blocked aid—WHO warns of generational health impacts as tents and supplies are deemed “dual-use.” US proposals to split Gaza into an Israeli-backed “green zone” and a desolate “red zone” under an international stabilisation force echo past occupations, now enshrined in a UN resolution backing Trump’s vague peace plan. Conditional references to statehood and withdrawal offer little guarantee, prompting fears of “forever misery” amidst arms sales and reputational diplomacy.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Nigel Farage’s youthful views: the past still matters | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Voters need to know if a party leader said racist things at school. Interviewers have a duty to keep pressing for fuller facts
articles.summary: More than a dozen contemporaries from Nigel Farage’s Dulwich College years (late 1970s–early 1980s) recall him uttering racist/antisemitic slogans—‘Hitler was right’, ‘Gas ’em all’, using slurs (‘Paki’, ‘Wog’), performing Nazi salutes and chanting Oswald Mosley—contradicting his past admission of merely saying ‘ridiculous things’. After The Guardian’s investigation, Farage’s legal team denies any teenage racism, dismissing it as ‘one person’s word against another’. The editorial argues these allegations matter for a potential PM, urging interviewers to press for fuller facts and judge his fitness for office.

articles.title: Unelected Lords are blocking assisted dying �� this is a democratic outrage | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: Second chambers are a good idea, but they should not be able to overturn clear decisions reached by an elected body, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins slams the House of Lords for filibustering the Commons’ Assisted Dying Bill by tacking on 617 moral and religious amendments—“gag clauses,” five-doctor approvals, travel bans—contradicting public majority and liberal precedents in Europe, Canada, Australia and US states. He calls this undemocratic obstructionism, highlights a ten-month police probe of a woman who accompanied her terminal husband to Dignitas, and urges the government to adopt and force through the bill, overhaul the unelected, purchasable upper chamber via a reform commission, and enact assisted-dying laws with tested international safeguards.

articles.title: The man who froze his wife and got a new girlfriend: a stranger, sadder tale than I expected | Imogen West-Knights
articles.trailText: The story has sparked debates about cryogenics and fidelity. But it also tells us something deeper about our responses to loss, says writer and journalist Imogen West-Knights
articles.summary: Chinese man Gui Junmin froze his wife Zhan Wenlian after her 2017 death via cryogenics, sparking global debate when he began dating Wang Chunxia in 2020. While Gui insists the new relationship is merely “utilitarian”—providing care during his illness—critics question the ethics of simultaneous fidelity and preservation. Writer Imogen West-Knights uses this case to probe cryogenics as a poignant expression of denial about mortality, highlighting the melancholy of attempting to outwait death and the human struggle to let go.

articles.title: A decade since Dad died, cricket has become a reminder of his love for us | Lucianne Tonti
articles.trailText: With each series (and what is more exciting than the Ashes at home?) the place gets expanded with new memories forged from the old ones
articles.summary: Lucianne Tonti recounts rediscovering cricket as a conduit to memories of her late father. Fifteen years after last hearing the game, watching the 2023 Ashes in her brother’s Norwegian living room reignites childhood lessons—batting technique, backyard rules. Over a decade since her father’s death, she and her brother rekindle shared rituals: texting during Tests, bonding over wins, losses and podcast jokes. During his paternity leave in London, they even pause commentary to read to his newborn daughter. Cricket becomes an ongoing dialogue across continents, a living tribute to their father’s love and lessons.

articles.title: ‘Why don’t you bake?’ A scolding that stung – until I heard it in a new way | Ying Reinhardt
articles.trailText: My aunt was chastising me for not carrying on my mother’s legacy of pineapple tarts and butter cakes. Why had I been so resistant? asks writer Ying Reinhardt
articles.summary: In a poignant essay, Ying Reinhardt recounts how her Aunt Julie’s scolding—urging her to uphold her late mother’s baking legacy—stung but ultimately propelled her into the kitchen. Resistant at first, Reinhardt lacked her mother’s precision and lived a nomadic, instinctive cooking life. When her daughter demanded treats, she began with vegan muffins and lunar new year cookies, learning through imperfect batches—giant, flat walnut cookies—that baking is about warmth, perseverance and maternal love, not precision. By embracing her mother’s recipes, she discovers that showing up every day is the true recipe for motherhood.

articles.title: Telling a reporter ‘quiet, piggy’ was shocking – even for Trump | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: We’re supposed to be used to this by now, but getting used to it is dangerous. Her colleagues should have spoken up
articles.summary: Catherine Lucey, Bloomberg’s White House reporter, asked Trump about the release of the Epstein files aboard Air Force One. He replied by demeaning her—“Quiet. Quiet, piggy”—in front of the gaggle, as colleagues remained silent. Guardian columnist Margaret Sullivan highlights this as an especially egregious example of Trump’s ongoing misogynistic insults toward female journalists (e.g., Yamiche Alcindor, April Ryan) and broader pattern of disparaging the press. She warns that normalizing such behavior endangers media independence and public decency. Sullivan argues that solidarity, not access, should guide reporters’ response, urging the corps to defend colleagues rather than shrug off “business as usual.”

articles.title: I’ve always wanted the perfect reason to declutter. Now I’ve found it | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: It’s a radical but simple notion: ditch the dead weight of your worldly goods and get out there and live your best life, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles reflects on his anxiety over accumulating physical possessions—items in use, those unused, and things destined for landfill—and introduces Deborah, a 65-year-old who deliberately rents a single room with three younger flatmates to avoid the upkeep of a large house and relieve her children of inheritance pressure. She redefines money not as wealth to hoard but as a tool to finance experiences, advocating “constrained living” as a means to purge excess belongings and instead devote time and resources to activities she truly enjoys. Chiles finds her radical minimalism provocative and potentially liberating.

articles.title: Trump’s 'affordability' efforts are a mess of absurdity and magical thinking | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: After Republicans were trounced in this month’s votes, the administration has launched a slapdash, ill-conceived campaign
articles.summary: After GOP losses blamed on inflation, Trump's administration hastily launched an 'affordability' campaign, featuring contradictory claims that 'prices are way down' despite tariffs raising grocery costs (bananas +6.9%, beef +14.7%, coffee +18.9%). He highlights consumer pain: grocery prices surged across five of six CPI categories. Inflation still runs at 3%. Advisers plan modest tariff rollbacks, risking political hypocrisy. Proposals like $2,000 dividends and 50-year mortgages offer little relief and may worsen deficits, rates and equity. Critics note many states in recession under Trump’s tariff-fueled slowdown, undermining claims of a 'golden age'. Greenhouse condemns it as dishonest magical thinking.

articles.title: People are right to ask ‘what is the point of Labour?’ when it can’t agree on anything | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: Who knows where this government’s credibility will be after next week’s exceptionally difficult budget, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Martin Kettle warns that Chancellor Rachel Reeves enters next week’s budget trapped by Labour’s self-imposed ban on tax rises, backbench rebellions and conflicting party instincts. After overturning her own demand to break the triple-tax pledge under MP pressure, Reeves faces credibility questions alongside Keir Starmer’s government. Similar revolts over welfare cuts and refugee policy reveal a party unable to agree on substantive reforms. With its historic working-class base eroded and a rising middle-class electorate ignored, modern Labour has fractured into competing factions lacking a unified domestic agenda or leadership vision, undermining its capacity to govern effectively.

articles.title: What does the left want? A wealth tax. What will that accomplish? Very little | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: Imposing a 1% levy on the super-rich isn’t a policy, it’s pantomime. Tackling inequality in Britain will require much more far-reaching changes, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Chakrabortty critiques the left’s consensus behind a 1% annual wealth tax on assets over £10m championed by Labour backbenchers, Greens and YouTubers, arguing it would yield only £10bn—about 1% of UK spending—and functions as political pantomime. He contrasts this with the 2020 Wealth Tax Commission’s one-off levy on assets above £1m that could have raised £260bn. Instead of token levies, Chakrabortty calls for structural reforms: expanded social housing, predistribution, labour law changes and stronger worker stakes in corporations.

articles.title: French conservatives are inching towards a pact with Le Pen that could enable a far-right takeover of the country | Paul Taylor
articles.trailText: In trying to woo Le Pen’s voters, Les Républicains risk destroying France’s Gaullist legacy and putting Paris on a collision course with the EU, says Paul Taylor of the European Policy Centre
articles.summary: Les Républicains, heirs to France’s Gaullist conservatives, are breaking the 'republican front' by courting Marine Le Pen’s National Rally to fend off electoral collapse. Polls show LR languishing below 10% as RN surges above 35%. Key figures like Retailleau pressure candidates to shun the left, while Wauquiez and hardliners explore local and EU pacts with the far right. This 'union of the right' risks handing Le Pen or Jordan Bardella the presidency in 2027, dismantling Gaullist legacies, rolling back immigration and welfare rights, and straining France’s EU ties.

articles.title: The landline may be having a renaissance – but it’s to a world in which the art of phone calls has changed | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: Some may be nostalgic for a time when the landline made communication a family affair, before smartphones were an extension of each of us
articles.summary: Paul Daley reflects on the landline telephone’s nostalgic cultural revival, contrasting its communal family rituals—formal greetings, parental eavesdropping and shared anticipation—with today’s fragmented, private smartphone calls. He recalls teenage anxieties over parental gatekeeping on a rotary phone and the den’s ritual ring, then explores how callers now text to avoid startling recipients, anxiety around unannounced calls and a shift toward opaque, individualised communication���particularly in children’s romantic lives—underscoring how digital devices have changed telephone etiquette and privacy.

articles.title: Saudi Prince Mohammed is being lavished with praise by Trump. It’s clear why | Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: Autocrats like Prince Mohammed are eager to benefit from Trump’s brazen effort to use the presidency to enrich himself and his family
articles.summary: Former President Donald Trump hosted Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at the White House, staging a red‐carpet reception, black‐tie dinner and investment summit despite US intelligence linking the prince to Jamal Khashoggi’s 2018 murder. The visit cements a reciprocal alliance: Saudi sovereign funds and the LIV Golf league funneled millions to Trump’s resorts when his brand was tarnished after January 6, while Trump promised extended US defense guarantees and advanced F-35 jets. MbS pledged to raise his $600 billion US investment commitment to $1 trillion. Analysts warn this transactional relationship corrupts US foreign policy and empowers autocrats.

articles.title: The Guardian view on falling net migration: political debate is now detached from the facts
articles.trailText: A fixation on reducing numbers leaves no room for rational discussion of what that means for the economy and society
articles.summary: Despite a steady decline in UK net migration—from a revised peak of 944,000 (year ending March 2023) to 345,000 (Dec 2024) and forecasts of 70,000–170,000 by 2026—British politics remains fixated on tougher immigration controls. ONS revisions highlight data reliability concerns, yet ministers and radical-right voices press for zero immigration. Political debate ignores economic and social impacts: shortages in social care, precarious university finances, shrinking labour force, reduced growth and Treasury revenues. Recent Home Office measures signal political posturing rather than rational policy, revealing a detachment from demographic realities and fiscal consequences in advance of the budget.

articles.title: The Guardian view on funding Ukraine’s resistance: a looming financial crisis in Kyiv must be averted | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Whether by leveraging Russia’s frozen assets, or other means, the EU must deliver the cash necessary to withstand Putin’s war of attrition
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that with US funding blocked by Trump’s refusal to seek new military aid, Kyiv faces a potential financial crisis in spring unless the EU steps up. Brussels must mobilise over €70bn in 2026 assistance—either via a €140bn reparations loan underpinned by frozen Russian assets or by issuing joint debt—to prevent Ukraine’s war-worn economy from collapsing. Slow decision-making risks morale, civil services and military readiness and undermines Ukraine’s bargaining power. EU leaders must agree at their December summit, or risk emboldening Putin’s war of attrition and hybrid threats in Europe.

articles.title: I am the king of the common cold – and I can tell you how to avoid one | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: No one suffers a cold like I do. Drops and brandy don’t touch the sides – but thanks to a friendly singer, I’ve learned a more extreme regime for countering the snuffles, writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles claims to endure the worst colds, with blocked nose, scratchy throat and barking coughs. Last winter, on a TV show with three singers, he learned a rigorous cold-avoidance regime from a mezzo-soprano: apply hand sanitiser hourly all season, plus two sprays of Vicks First Defence nasal shield before and after any party. Despite misplacing bottles and accidental gel spills, he stayed cold-free. Now, with winter returning, he’s restocked and ready to deploy her extreme prevention plan again.

articles.title: Trump shrugged off Khashoggi’s killing. This is a new low | Jodie Ginsberg
articles.trailText: Jamal Khashoggi was dismembered in a Saudi consulate. The president says ‘things happen’
articles.summary: During a White House press conference with Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman, President Trump shrugged off the CIA- and UN-backed findings that MBS ordered Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi’s 2018 abduction, torture and dismemberment in Istanbul—dismissing it as “things happen.” His stance, amid a broader pattern of public attacks on journalists—labeling the press “fake news,” demanding licenses revoked and cutting media funding—signals a new low in U.S. contempt for press freedom. Critics warn this normalization of violence has fueled record journalist fatalities in 2024, per CPJ.

articles.title: Every time new emails drop, elites do the Epstein shuffle: ‘Yes I knew him, but I didn’t KNOW him’ | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: For the New York and Washington great and good who loved the company of wealth and power, all that glitters is no longer gold, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Emma Brockes dissects the latest scramble among New York, Washington and Ivy League elites to disclaim knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein’s crimes after a Senate vote released his email files. Citing examples—from Deepak Chopra’s post-conviction correspondence to Katie Couric, George Stephanopoulos, Peggy Siegal, Arianna Huffington and Tina Brown—she exposes the “I knew him but I didn’t KNOW him” routine. Underlying these panicked denials is a critique of vanity: the allure of exclusive social circles that trumps moral judgment and fuels complicity with power.

articles.title: ‘May I meet you?’ is just the latest in horrible dating advice from billionaires | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Bill Ackman thinks his pickup line could aid population rates. Given the track record of the mega-rich, it may do the opposite
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi critiques Bill Ackman for offering “May I meet you?” as a surefire pickup line to boost population rates, mocking his billionaire pedigree and syntax-based flirtation advice on X. She notes its viral spread but questions its efficacy versus tackling war, childcare costs, public schooling and high living expenses. Mahdawi highlights other billionaire dating tips—from Trump to Watters, Summers, Musk and Durov—to argue that deep social reforms, not gimmicky pick-up lines, drive genuine relationships and population growth.

articles.title: Trump and his ilk imagine a world without international law – but they will not achieve it | Philippe Sands
articles.trailText: History shows us that the creation of international rules and institutions is followed by their partial destruction, and a reconstruction that builds on what came before, says professor of law Philippe Sands
articles.summary: Philippe Sands argues that despite high-profile assaults on the post-1945 rules-based order—from Israel’s drone strike in Qatar and Russian drones over Poland to Trump’s ‘swagger’—international law endures. Treaties still govern rail travel, telecommunications, trade and medicine, while states have launched a new UN crimes-against-humanity convention and an aggression tribunal. International courts like the ICJ carry record caseloads and issue landmark advisory opinions on Chagos and climate. History’s cycle of erosion followed by reconstruction shows law may be tested but never obsolete.

articles.title: How can Labour see off Reform? Both Andy Burnham and Shabana Mahmood offer clues | Julian Coman
articles.trailText: A moral crusade won’t work. To defeat Faragism, Labour must revive a vision of social cohesion and collective responsibility, says Guardian associate editor Julian Coman
articles.summary: Julian Coman argues Labour’s moral crusade against Reform UK won’t suffice. Progressives must rediscover a communitarian vision rooted in solidarity, civic virtue and collective responsibility—resources once championed by Michael Sandel but overshadowed by post-1980s individualism. Today, Farage’s national conservatism monopolises community appeals while the left’s focus on diversity has alienated some working-class voters. Coman highlights shifts by Shabana Mahmood on controlled migration and Andy Burnham on economic sovereignty as early steps toward an inclusive collectivism that balances universal rights with social cohesion.

articles.title: Starmer’s squandering of a historic election victory is a tragedy nearing its finale | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: The tactics that gave Labour its huge majority in 2024 were no preparation for government – and the prime minister has proved he has nothing more to offer, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr argues Keir Starmer’s government is rudderless despite its 2024 majority, with tactics that won the election ill-suited to governing. Labour backbenchers endure blame for the party’s refugee cap plan inspired by Denmark, tolerating harsh asylum measures amid declining voter trust. MPs see Starmer as detached—delegating strategy to chief-of-staff Morgan McSweeney—and lacking Labour lore or personal convictions. With defections to Reform UK, Lib Dems and Greens, and looming council and devolved elections, the party risks catastrophic losses unless it replaces its leader, though consensus on a successor is absent.

articles.title: I grew up in Spain amid a collective amnesia about Franco. It is time we faced up to our dark past | María Ramírez
articles.trailText: This week marks 50 years of Spanish democracy, but the failure to talk more about the crimes of the dictatorship leaves us vulnerable, says the journalist María Ramírez
articles.summary: Over 50 years since Franco’s death, Spain transformed; GDP multiplied by 15, exports by 8, employed doubled, same-sex marriage legalized in 2005. Yet Franco-era crimes went unpunished, amnesty slid into collective amnesia. Zapatero’s 2007 memory law and Sánchez’s removal of Franco’s tomb made symbolic gains, but weak school coverage and right-wing pushback leave room for far-right nostalgia. Ramírez calls for open public reckoning, deeper education, and a national museum to protect democracy.

articles.title: Becoming an AI-detective is a job I never wanted and wish I could quit | Samantha Floreani
articles.trailText: My social media feed is now a hellish stream of puerile AI slop. Am I stubborn to want to hang on to reality?
articles.summary: Digital rights advocate Samantha Floreani laments her involuntary role as an “AI detective” on social media, fatigued by a flood of algorithm-optimized AI‐generated videos—from absurd pickle car chases to deepfakes—that blur reality, exploit creators, and feed late‐stage capitalist profit loops. She critiques platforms’ embrace of generative AI spam, which rewards engagement signals regardless of content quality or ethics, and argues that preserving the ability to discern real from synthetic remains vital despite the relentless hyperreal deluge.

articles.title: The Guardian view on crypto’s latest crash: it reveals who pays the price for a failing economy | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The bitcoin collapse lifts the lid on a society without opportunity, where risk is privatised and rightwingers sell illusions of freedom while ordinary punters bear losses
articles.summary: In six weeks crypto lost $1.2 trn as bitcoin plunged back to April levels, exposing its lack of intrinsic value and reliance on speculative sentiment. Unlike state-backed money, cryptocurrencies generate no cash flow—prices collapse when enthusiasm wanes. Britain’s stagnant wages and unaffordable housing have driven young people to treat crypto as a ‘one-shot’ escape, often borrowing to gamble. Meanwhile, rightwing figures from Trump to Farage now champion crypto as rebellious freedom, dismantling Biden’s regulatory efforts and turning digital assets into a tool for elite enrichment at the expense of the powerless.

articles.title: The Guardian view on rogue landlords: past failures do not augur well for the new era | Editorial of renters’ rights
articles.trailText: Editorial: If the promise of a better private rental sector is to be realised, councils will need new staff as well as stricter rules
articles.summary: England’s Renters’ Rights Act promises to rebalance the law by banning no-fault evictions from next May, mandating a landlords’ register and ombudsman, and consulting on a decent-homes standard. Yet Guardian analysis shows two-thirds of councils brought zero prosecutions and half issued no fines over three years, with only 16 landlords banned. Ministers must back new rules with funding for staff, training and legal support to ensure overburdened local authorities can enforce renters’ rights effectively.

articles.title: A question to the few remaining Labour supporters: is this refugee-bashing what you voted for? | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: The government’s callousness has won it respect – from Tommy Robinson and the hard right, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Owen Jones accuses the new Labour administration of adopting hard-right asylum policies—debasing refugee claimants with two decades in limbo, potential asset confiscation and deceitful claims on UK “pull factor” myths—to appease nativists like Tommy Robinson and Reform. He criticises Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s misleading statistics, lambasts cuts to winter fuel and disability benefits, and warns this cruelty undermines progressive values, legitimises populism and risks losing Labour’s supporters.

articles.title: Will Marjorie Taylor Greene turn the Maga movement against Trump? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: Whatever her motives, the Republican congresswoman’s ‘revenge tour’ against the president is proving surprisingly effective, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Georgia congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, long a fervent Trump ally through conspiracy theories and fiery rhetoric, has pivoted into a full-blown MAGA civil war, publicly rebuking her former patron. Greene first broke ranks by labeling Gaza a genocide and demanding release of the Epstein files, then condemned GOP leaders over affordability and healthcare. Trump, frustrated by her “complaint” tours, withdrew his endorsement, calling her a “ranting lunatic.” Yet Greene’s media-savvy backlash, high-profile apologies and new alliances have amplified her platform, positioning her as a potential catalyst for GOP infighting ahead of 2025.

articles.title: Extortionate tickets and matches moved at Trump’s whim: are you ready for the ‘greatest World Cup ever’? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: You may have thought Qatar and Russia were tournament lows. You didn’t account for the US president and his Fifa soulmate, Gianni Infantino, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde criticizes Fifa president Gianni Infantino’s embrace of Donald Trump, exposing how he’ll allow next year’s US World Cup games to be relocated at the US president’s whim ostensibly over security or political compliance. Infantino’s subservience includes attending Trump’s Middle East summit, Gaza talks, inauguration, and proposing a "peace prize" likely rigged to favor Trump, even as he champions "inclusivity." Dynamic ticket pricing, abrupt city swaps and blatant sportswashing mark an era in which Fifa has become a politicized marketing machine, undermining fans’ travel plans and turning global football’s flagship event into the least predictable in its history.

articles.title: Doing your own research isn’t a bad thing, I tell my patients. But just how will they spot the fraudulent papers? | Ranjana Srivastava
articles.trailText: While every self-aware doctor knows no one is an expert on everything, the average person turning to the internet cannot distinguish evidence from gloss
articles.summary: Oncologist Ranjana Srivastava describes the explosion of predatory publishing and paper mills churning out fraudulent research—over 400,000 suspect papers since 2000, with cancer studies especially vulnerable. Fake journals and conferences lure academics with rapid publication schemes. Patients “doing their own research” online can’t distinguish legitimate evidence from gloss, leading some to rely on debunked remedies like alkaline diets. Fraudulent papers thus risk delayed proper treatment and higher costs. Srivastava urges better research funding, publisher vigilance, and public education to help patients critically evaluate sources.

articles.title: Israel needs to face accountability for our genocide. And so does the US  | Yuli Novak
articles.trailText: The international community allowed all of this to happen. We must not look away or move on
articles.summary: Yuli Novak (executive director of B’Tselem) warns that Israel’s nearly two-year Gaza campaign—bombing, forced displacement, starvation and infrastructure destruction—meets the UN definition of genocide, with over 68,000 Palestinians killed, tens of thousands missing and a continuing blockade despite a nominal ceasefire. She traces its roots to decades of military occupation and apartheid, implicates US and Western governments in enabling this violence, and calls for legal accountability to challenge a racist domination system, halt ongoing atrocities and prevent the normalization of genocide. She warns that Donald Trump’s ceasefire plan ignores root causes and that without reckoning this system will repeat violence.

articles.title: Is Shabana Mahmood’s plan to seize the jewels of asylum seekers a joke? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The home secretary’s idea makes her sound so much like a cartoon villain that I initially assumed it couldn’t be true, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams dismisses Labour Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s proposal to seize jewellery and valuables from asylum seekers to pay for their accommodation as cartoonish villainy, noting it echoes Denmark’s 2016 law that yielded just 17 seizures in six years amid police union scepticism. Williams warns this symbolic, vindictive stunt—paired with plans to remove any path to permanent citizenship—undermines Britain’s longstanding sanctuary role, exemplifies counterproductive, narrow-minded immigration policy and is ultimately an unserious political gesture.

articles.title: ‘Smile? YOU smile.' A new generation of stars is overthrowing the old Hollywood system, one ‘no’ at a time | Priya Elan
articles.trailText: Gen Z actors such as Millie Bobby Brown and Jenna Ortega are refusing to do what is expected of ‘the talent’, says Priya Elan, a writer specialising in the arts, music and fashion
articles.summary: Priya Elan highlights a new generation of Gen Z actors—Millie Bobby Brown, Jenna Ortega and Sydney Chandler—who refuse traditional Hollywood rituals, from smiling for paparazzi to scripted magazine interviews. Chandler even boycotted a Variety cover segment, citing privacy boundaries. This “no, you don’t have to” era contrasts with old studio–paparazzi alliances and tabloid tactics, as stars now wield social media and podcasts to control their image. Pop singer Jade celebrates this shift in “IT Girl,” sampling Simon Cowell’s iconic “no from me.”

articles.title: Now is not the time for a Labour leadership election | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The focus should be on talking up this government’s achievements so far – and preventing a Reform victory, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee argues against staging a Labour leadership contest while the government battles a historic collapse in support—now at 18%, trailing Reform UK—and warns that a messy challenge wouldn’t solve structural fiscal constraints amid pandemic-driven inflation, energy shocks and broader European democratic turmoil. She urges Keir Starmer’s team to capitalise on achievements—from the Renters’ Rights Act and school curriculum reforms to rail nationalisation, renewables investment and new workers’ rights—and to prioritise fighting a Reform surge rather than internal divisions.

articles.title: Sussan Ley, it’s time we took a look at your climate policy report card. You appear to have learned nothing | Tristan Edis
articles.trailText: My advice to you if you want to avoid repeating 2025 is to pay far greater attention to the quality of your research sources
articles.summary: Sussan Ley receives a scathing ‘report card’ from Tristan Edis, who raps her climate policy research for logical flaws—such as treating coal as a zero-emissions “energy abundance” solution and over-relying on unproven carbon capture—plus misinformation from ChatGPT, plagiarism of ill-informed figures like Canavan, Littleproud and Daniel Tehan, and sloppy maths (confusing $300bn with $9tn net-zero cost, overstating land-use impacts). He accuses Ley of ignoring basic chemistry and logic lectures, nodding off in philosophy class, and warns that copying politicians’ homework guarantees academic—and policy—failure. Edis urges Ley to ditch Trumpian sources, consult genuine science authorities (BOM, CSIRO, Australian Academy of Science/ATSE) and overhaul her evidence base to avoid “repeating 2025.”

articles.title: Labour’s asylum plans are horribly cruel – but they’re also a mix of hype, old policy and unachievable promises | Diane Taylor
articles.trailText: There is mounting disquiet among Labour MPs, while the vulnerable refugees at the heart of this story are living with a renewed sense of panic, says Diane Taylor, who writes on human rights, racism and civil liberties
articles.summary: Labour’s newly announced asylum reforms, praised by far-right figure Tommy Robinson and billed by Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood as the toughest in modern times, mix recycled measures, grandiose rhetoric and impractical targets. While removals have risen—largely to safe countries like Brazil and India—and visa curbs on Angola, Namibia and DRC are touted as game-changers, most provisions (including reduced appeal routes, discretionary support for 8,500 visa-holders, jewellery confiscation and extending permanent settlement from 5 to 20 years) affect only small groups. There is no evidence these deterrents cut Channel crossings. Critics warn such cruelty undermines refugee rights and deepens social divisions.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s asylum plans: ministers cannot out-Farage the far right and should stop trying | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Shabana Mahmood’s asylum overhaul burdens an overstretched system and hands political advantage to her opponents
articles.summary: The Guardian warns Labour’s Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s proposed asylum overhaul — cutting initial refugee stays to 30 months with periodic reviews, modelled on Denmark — would overwhelm an already backlogged system, cost almost £1bn and entrench refugees in limbo. It argues for a targeted one-off permission scheme for high-grant countries to clear asylum hotels swiftly, rather than an unworkable political bid to out-Farage the far right, which risks cruelty and incompetence. It also cautions that unilateral ECHR reforms would be self-defeating, undermining the Brexit deal and Northern Ireland peace.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Germany under Merz: Europe’s powerhouse is still struggling | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Donald Trump’s trade wars and Chinese competition constitute formidable headwinds. But old economic orthodoxies are not the answer
articles.summary: Despite a landmark EU deal loosening Germany’s debt brake, six months into Friedrich Merz’s chancellorship growth forecasts for 2026 have been cut below 1% and business confidence is plunging. Fewer than one in five Germans back his re-election while the far-right AfD tops polls. Geopolitical shocks—from Trump’s trade wars to Chinese competition and Russia’s war in Ukraine—have battered Germany’s export model. Merz’s €500 bn plan for defence, infrastructure and green transition has yet to deliver, and calls for renewed austerity risk fuelling right-wing populism. The editorial urges resisting old orthodoxies, reviving the social model and turbocharging investment for a multipolar world.

articles.title: I keep trying to name storms. Why does the Met Office turn down my suggestions? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: ‘Wubbo’ has made it on to the list and so has ‘Dave’, but although I’ve tried a hundred times, including my kids’ names, I’ve had absolutely no luck, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: In this Guardian column, Zoe Williams questions why her repeated storm name suggestions—ranging from her children’s monikers to Irish and Dutch variants—have been rejected by the Met Office, despite ‘Wubbo’ and public-favourite ‘Dave’ landing on the 2025–26 roster. She outlines how storm naming, adopted in 2015 with Abigail and coordinated with Met Éireann and KNMI, aims to heighten preparedness but omits tricky letters (Q, U, X, Y, Z). Williams contrasts high-impact events—from the legendary 1987 gale that defined Michael Fish’s career to Storm Claudia’s Algarve fatality and Welsh floods—to underscore uneven risk exposure and personal stakes in these anthropomorphic labels.

articles.title: My kids start sentences in one language and end in another. I hope school doesn’t shrink their joyous, noisy worlds | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: Maybe there’s room for something gentler: letting children know they don’t need to change any part of themselves to belong
articles.summary: In his household, mornings feel like a language carnival: children switch between Pashto for passion, Hindi for humour and English for practicality in a single breath. At school they’re told to stick to English, dimming the vibrant code-switching that connects them to family, culture and joy. Peers pursue Japanese, German and Bollywood Hindi accents, reflecting a thirst for language as identity. Inspired by his Silk Road–trading grandfather and Melbourne’s rich multilingual soundscape, the author urges schools to honour students’ full linguistic selves and mirror Australia’s diverse voices to foster inclusion.

articles.title: Jeffrey Epstein’s emails reveal a disdain for morality among the elite | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Epstein paints Trump as someone he knew intimately. But the documents also reveal how many powerful men confided in him
articles.summary: Newly released emails from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate depict him boasting of intimate knowledge of Donald Trump—claiming Trump “knew about the girls,” invited women into his pool, posed for bikini photos in Epstein’s kitchen, and discussing cover-up strategies with journalist Michael Wolff during a 2015 GOP debate. Beyond Trump, the 23,000-page trove reveals prominent figures—Larry Summers, Peter Thiel, Ghislaine Maxwell—confiding with or offering favors to Epstein long after his 2008 sex-trafficking conviction. Donegan argues these exchanges, marked by smirking cynicism, expose an elite culture that treats child abuse as collateral in power games and regards morality as “provincial.”

articles.title: Trump is turning the US military into a political prop | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: The military has been recast in a partisan, performative mold – all according to the president’s logic of impunity
articles.summary: Jan-Werner Müller argues that Trump is turning the US military into a partisan instrument by purging officers deemed disloyal (e.g. delaying Gen. Mark Milley’s promotion), using MAGA-fied troops as backdrop, violating norms, and instilling impunity through pardons and illegal orders like Caribbean boat attacks. Pete Hegseth’s performative "warrior ethos," dress code and fat bans underscore theater over strategy. Blurring Pentagon and Homeland Security roles creates an omnipresent "omniforce" loyal to Trump, erasing accountability and eroding democratic safeguards—making military compliance pivotal in potential constitutional crises.

articles.title: ICE-style raids on Britain's streets: that's all Labour's brutal asylum reforms will achieve | Stella Creasy
articles.trailText: If we want to ‘stop the boats’, we need to stop the BS when it comes to what creates refugees, and how to respond to them, says Labour MP Stella Creasy
articles.summary: Labour’s proposed asylum reforms would deny refugees indefinite leave after five years, impose two-and-a-half-year renewable status and potentially require ICE-style raids to detain and deport, argues Labour MP Stella Creasy. She warns these measures won’t deter arrivals—citing Denmark’s failed experiment—will drive up costs through delayed integration, and trap survivors of torture in permanent limbo. Creasy calls instead for early credibility checks, safe routes, cross-border data sharing, targeted action against exploiters and clear separation of asylum from other visa streams, to uphold both compassion and control.

articles.title: Labour has entered its musical chairs era – and we’re sucked into another pointless death spiral | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: Briefing wars, toxic infighting, paranoid office politics: we’ve seen it all before. And once again, the drama at No 10 has absolutely nothing to do with us, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: Labour’s No 10 office erupted in farcical infighting after allies of Keir Starmer briefed against Wes Streeting as a potential challenger. Streeting denied the plot, Starmer apologised and disowned the leak, sparking speculation about Downing Street power players. Nesrine Malik argues this cyclical “musical chairs” – crisis, high-drama personnel skirmish, emergence of a ‘saviour’ like Streeting, then return to crisis – typifies modern British politics and signals a terminal failure where personality clashes replace governance, detaching government drama from voters’ real-world concerns. It underscores how media leaks and behind-the-scenes politicking distract from crises like cost-of-living pressures and policy inertia.

articles.title: There are many ways to spend your gap year that will reward you later | Vivienne Pearson
articles.trailText: The idea of a full year of travel might be amazing for social media likes but a gap year doesn’t have to be a hole in young people’s bank balance
articles.summary: Vivienne Pearson argues a gap year needn’t focus on travel; alternative options—full-time work, saving money, exploring career paths, building life skills and considering study choices—can be more accessible for students without affluent backgrounds. She reflects on her own deferment, highlights financial pressures—rising living costs, HECS debts and limited allowances—for regional and rural students, praises TAP’s inclusion of gap-year takers, and urges parents to discuss diverse plans beyond travel to foster maturity, clarity and financial stability. She cautions against social-media-driven ideals of world roaming and notes government support like the $3,000–5,000 TAP payment aims to offset relocation costs.

articles.title: Dark forces are stirring up anger in the UK. My asylum reforms are our chance to stop them | Shabana Mahmood
articles.trailText: I know some of these measures will face opposition. But a country without secure borders is less safe for those who look like me, says Shabana Mahmood, the home secretary
articles.summary: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood argues the UK must restore border control to preserve public support for asylum and prevent divisive extremism. Despite Britain’s tradition of welcoming Ukrainians, Afghans and Hongkongers, unchecked small-boat crossings have strained communities and taxpayers. Her package— the most sweeping reforms in a generation— combines robust enforcement and removals of illegal arrivals with new, capped legal routes: community-sponsored resettlement for genuine refugees, streamlined visas for students and workers, and faster paths to permanent citizenship. Temporary refugee status, modest safe routes and local sponsorship aim to balance generosity with order, counter “dark forces” and uphold the UK’s open-tolerant identity.

articles.title: The Guardian view on a new nuclear age: great powers should not restock a house of dynamite | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Donald Trump’s remarks on resuming nuclear testing have highlighted the risks. Proliferation must not be considered inevitable
articles.summary: Amid Trump’s call to resume nuclear testing and Japan’s new prime minister’s hesitation on its no-bomb pledge, experts warn global arms control has collapsed into a “Category 5 hurricane.” With New START set to expire in February, China’s rapid arsenal build-up and potential proliferation by anxious allies challenge the decades-old taboo. Analysts Vipin Narang and Pranay Vaddi warn of Armageddon risks, while Ankit Panda charts a descent toward conflict. US withdrawal from the INF treaty and JCPOA, and strikes on Iran’s facilities, have undercut non-proliferation norms. A resumption of tests—last conducted in 1992—would aid adversaries and fuel skepticism that disarmament is mere monopoly-maintaining window dressing. Reviving CTBT efforts and extending treaties could arrest a perilous new nuclear age.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Europe’s firewall against the far right: in growing need of repair | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The fragility of France’s cordon sanitaire against Le Pen is part of a worrying wider pattern, as centrist parties seek to revive their fortunes
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Europe’s traditional cordon sanitaire against the far right is weakening as centrist and centre-right parties seek alliances. Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, has rallied right-wing nationalist forces across Europe, while France’s Republicans have broken ranks, allowing far-right motions in parliament and contemplating cooperation ahead of 2027 elections. Similar shifts in the Netherlands, Germany and within the European Parliament—where conservative MEPs joined far-right groups to dilute climate legislation—signal a wider trend. The piece argues that courting populist extremes imperils democratic values and mainstream parties must urgently repair the firewall.

articles.title: The US has drafted a coin featuring Trump. Here’s a better way to immortalize him | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: It is our solemn duty to ensure he is remembered for all he has done and may still do to destroy US democracy
articles.summary: Robert Reich critiques the Treasury’s draft $1 coin featuring Trump on both sides for the US 250th birthday and Trump’s push to name stadiums and a White House ballroom after himself. He warns this self-glorification mirrors fascist dictators. Reich recounts Trump’s undemocratic actions—false election claims, coup attempt, Capitol assault, pardons, power abuses and city militarization—and proposes a "Trump’s Treason" monument on the White House lawn to preserve this history.

articles.title: I don’t believe in God but, as a trauma survivor, I’m learning to forgive myself | Jackie Bailey
articles.trailText: In the context of spirituality, trauma is a hand grenade. But it can lead to deeper understandings of the world
articles.summary: Jackie Bailey, a trauma survivor and former believer, explores how her sister’s childhood cancer shattered her religious framework and left her grappling with existential questions of evil and meaning. Drawing on psychologists Bessel van der Kolk and Judith Herman, and the five principles of trauma-informed care—safety, trust, choice, collaboration, empowerment—she reframes her departure from faith as a response to childhood trauma. Though she rejects belief in God, years of therapy and supportive relationships have allowed her to feel spiritually safe, open to mystery, and capable of forgiving herself without needing divine forgiveness.

articles.title: Want to avoid anxiety, headaches and constipation? Try giving up on your goals | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: We’re taught from infancy that perseverance is a moral virtue and persistence pays. But what if quitters are happier and healthier, asks Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington examines research showing that disengaging from unfulfilling goals lowers cortisol and inflammation, cutting the risk of headaches, constipation, eczema, colds and chronic disease, while boosting life satisfaction and reducing anxiety. She questions the cultural valorization of perseverance, recalling a New Yorker piece and Oliver Burkeman’s Meditation for Mortals, which argue for accepting limitations and shifting self-worth away from relentless striving. Reflecting on her own dreams—a novel, social swagger and the splits—Beddington weighs which ambitions to abandon, adapt or pursue with healthier flexibility.

articles.title: Flooded and forgotten: the UK’s waters are rising and we’re being kept in the dark | John Harris
articles.trailText: Rescue operations in Wales, submerged railway lines in Cornwall – these events are ever more common. So why have we utterly failed to prepare, asks Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: In Flooded and forgotten John Harris warns that increasingly frequent floods across the UK – from Monmouth’s submerged streets during Storm Claudia to railway lines underwater in Cornwall and Carmarthen’s worst floods on record – reveal chronic underinvestment in defences and poor planning. Despite £10.5bn pledged by government to 2036, new homes keep being built in high-risk zones without natural buffers or permeable infrastructure. Academics caution that insurance gaps (58% of retail space uninsured) and the end of Flood Re in 2039 will force relocation of towns. Harris criticises political silence and urges urgent preparedness for a rising flood emergency.

articles.title: If holding a grudge is wrong, why does it feel so right? Just ask Margaret Atwood | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: In a culture of therapy-approved ‘forgiveness’, the author’s new memoir shows how hilarious long-delayed vengeance can be, says Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: In Book of Lives, Margaret Atwood wryly embraces her grudge-holding – famously quipping “Piss up a rope, wanker” and hiring an exorcist to banish a husband’s ex. Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett argues Atwood’s sardonic vengeance clips gone viral expose tensions between therapy’s forgiveness culture and the private humor of resentment. By naming a deceased childhood bully, Atwood illustrates memoir as radical truth-telling: forgiveness isn’t mandatory, pain can be funny, and long-delayed revenge can serve catharsis when legal limits finally allow frank reckoning.

articles.title: The US is now a rogue state - look at its extrajudicial killings off Venezuela’s coast | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: These widely condemned strikes are just the latest sign of Trump’s imperialist revival – and the collapsing before our eyes of the rules-based world order, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Guardian commentator Simon Tisdall condemns repeated US airstrikes on suspected drug-smugglers off Venezuela’s coast as illegal extrajudicial killings and warns they presage a full-scale assault to oust Nicolás Maduro, breaching international law. He highlights Britain’s symbolic refusal to share intelligence with the Pentagon, Trump’s imperialist revival, and the collapse of the rules-based order. Tisdall situates US behaviour within a wider surge of state lawlessness—from Putin’s Ukraine war to looming Israel-Iran, Taiwan, and nuclear confrontations—declaring all major powers ‘rogue states.’

articles.title: Who to prioritise, my partner or my baby? It’s a no-brainer | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: Parenting guru Gina Ford believes bending over backwards to please your children puts your marriage at risk. Sorry, Gina, but I’m not on board, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Polly Hudson skewers parenting guru Gina Ford’s claim that prioritizing children over one’s partner risks marriage. Ford, known for her rigid baby schedules and £29.99 reminder app, warns that focusing solely on kids leads to “broken homes.” Hudson shares how Ford’s formulas left her sleep-deprived and convinced her infant was “faulty,” even waking her husband at 3.47am to cite passages. She argues most parents willingly put offspring first, recalls a friend’s “wife-or-child” dilemma gone wrong, and insists there’s no one-size-fits-all approach. She closes by mock-promoting her own guide, Lying on the Floor Sobbing While Cursing Gina Ford’s Name.

articles.title: The Coalition is spinning a line that climate action is economically bad. How are they getting away with it? | Zoe Daniel
articles.trailText: In this post-truth environment, the interests of coal and gas are somehow able to win the hearts and minds of voters
articles.summary: After securing a Climate Change Act amendment that enshrined Australia’s net zero target as a binding floor, Zoe Daniel laments the Coalition’s fact-free campaign—led by Nationals and Liberals backed by coal and gas interests—to repeal it by falsely framing renewable energy as costly. She highlights data showing renewables now provide the cheapest power and gas price hikes, not the green transition, explain recent bill rises. With Labor’s weak rebuttal and minimal renewable-sector pushback, public doubt about net zero is growing despite clear environmental and economic benefits.

articles.title: Chuck Schumer should quit – but would his imaginary friends agree? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The US government was shut down for weeks – and then Democrats shrugged their shoulders and gave up
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi criticizes Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer for bungling the longest US government shutdown by centering his strategy on imaginary middle-class couple Joe and Eileen Bailey. Democrats triggered a 43-day shutdown to demand extension of expiring Obamacare tax credits, only to cave without securing a vote. Schumer’s symbolic ‘life or death’ fight yielded no gains, prompting progressive backlash and calls from figures like Ro Khanna for his resignation. Mahdawi warns Schumer must stop listening to fictional advisors and heed real voters’ demands or face a challenge from the party’s left.

articles.title: Big content is taking on AI – but it’s far from the David v Goliath tale they’d have you believe | Alexander Avila
articles.trailText: Deals between media conglomerates and tech companies serve both sets of interests, while leaving artists by the wayside, says video essayist, writer and researcher Alexander Avila
articles.summary: Major media giants—Universal Music, Warner, Sony—are suing AI startups for using recordings without permission even as they forge lucrative licensing deals, promising to ‘do right by artists’ yet leaving creators uncompensated. Lawsuits like Andersen v Stability AI and proposed bills such as the NO FAKES Act highlight how copyright suits and digital‐replica rights could consolidate power in Big Content and Big Tech, sidelining freelancers. Activism by coalitions like the Human Artistry Campaign raises awareness, but organised labour—unions and collective bargaining—remains the most effective defence against AI’s erosion of creative work.

articles.title: After I burned out, physics helped me understand what had happened to me – and to move on | Zahaan Bharmal
articles.trailText: I thought hard work equalled success. I had to realise that’s not always how it works, in science or in life, says Google employee Zahaan Bharmal
articles.summary: Google senior director Zahaan Bharmal recounts his 2001 post-dotcom bubble redundancy and burnout, applying physics concepts—chaotic systems, surge capacity, and phase transitions—to explain why relentless hard work backfires. He likens workloads at 100% capacity to fragile power grids prone to blackouts and stress accumulation to water heating until a sudden boil. Citing UK data (91% high stress, widespread unpaid overtime), he argues modern economies celebrate overwork, ignoring that resilience demands built-in slack. Only by easing off and building surge capacity can individuals and organizations avoid collapse.

articles.title: Welcome to the great unwokening of Hollywood! Shame no one can be bothered to turn up | Jason Okundaye
articles.trailText: Sydney Sweeney has become the poster child of a predicted rightwing cultural domination. So why is no one watching her films, asks Guardian assistant newsletter editor Jason Okundaye
articles.summary: Guardian’s Jason Okundaye critiques the touted “great unwokening,” whereby rightwing icons like Sydney Sweeney champion conservative cultural domination. Despite her Reagan-Bush ’84 T-shirt cachet and eugenics-flirting American Eagle ad, Sweeney’s films (Christy, Eden, Americana) bomb at the box office. The article traces MAGA’s push to purge ‘woke’ culture—from Trump’s Smithsonian purge to threatened film tariffs—but concludes popularity can’t be manufactured with provocation alone. By contrast, diverse ‘woke’ successes like Sinners and One Battle After Another thrive. Cultural taste hinges on quality over ideology, making conservative aesthetics easy to signal but hard to sustain in an open market.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Cop30: someone has to pay for the end of the oil and gas age | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The fossil-fuel era is drawing to a close, but at a pace far too slow for the planet’s good or a fair transition to a clean energy future
articles.summary: At Cop30 in Belém, initial optimism gave way to rifts over climate finance, carbon tariffs and the gap to the Paris 1.5 °C target. The IEA reports fossil fuels will peak this decade as renewables win on cost, but emissions cuts lag. Developing nations cite Article 9.1 to demand $1.3 trn/year in grants for adaptation and just transition; rich states push Article 6 carbon markets, blended loans and private capital. Of last year’s $300 bn pledge, only a third materialised and under 3% funded worker transition. Cop30’s test: will wealthy emitters finally pay their fair share or prolong the fossil-fuel era?

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Booker prize winner: putting masculinity back at the centre of literary fiction | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: David Szalay’s Flesh breaks from a decade of female-centred interiors and reopens a genre many thought closed to men
articles.summary: David Szalay’s Flesh, the 2025 Booker winner, breaks a decade-long trend of female-focused interiority by offering an unapologetically external portrait of masculinity through the life of István, a working-class Hungarian immigrant. Told in terse, one-line paragraphs, the realist narrative strips away interior thought, focusing on István’s casual sex, violence and emotional numbness. Szalay rejects Amis-era machismo, positioning men as the objectified and exploring desire, migration and identity. Flesh’s minimalist style and Homeric scope probe what it means to live in a “machine made of meat”, reinvigorating male-centred literary fiction for our moment.

articles.title: Trump can get away with saying what he likes about the BBC. But Epstein? That’s his one vulnerability | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: In attacking a vital broadcaster, the US president is once again holding others to standards he flouts. But the Maga faithful might not let his links to the disgraced financier go, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Jonathan Freedland argues Trump’s habitual lies grant him license to attack critics, forcing institutions like the BBC to be 'bulletproof'—a standard he ignores. After a misleading Panorama edit on Trump’s Jan 6 rhetoric, the White House branded the BBC ‘fake news’, undermining trust in shared facts. Freedland warns this asymmetry endangers democracy. His one check? Jeffrey Epstein: new documents suggest Trump’s deeper ties to the disgraced financier, potentially shattering QAnon-fueled loyalty. Republicans plan to block full release of DOJ Epstein files, fearing this remains Trump’s sole vulnerability.

articles.title: Who could be behind the phantom briefing and the tax rise that wasn’t? Inspector Starmer is on the case | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Chaos and ineptitude dog our poor PM. Perhaps the explanation lies (very) close to home, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers the UK government’s mid-budget implosion: a reported U-turn on basic and higher income tax hikes triggered gilt market turmoil, while Downing Street flailed between apology grids and a “smorgasbord” of minor levies. Meanwhile Opposition Leader Keir Starmer’s inquiry into a phantom No 10 briefing against Wes Streeting produced only denials from aides, exposing his “team of weevils.” Hyde lampoons Labour’s procedural dramatics, fiscal dithering and Starmer’s overseas absences as undermining credibility ahead of the budget.

articles.title: Somebody to love: should AI relationships stay taboo or will they become the intelligent choice? | Brigid Delaney
articles.trailText: How will AI destroy the world as we know it? Not through evil. My guess is it will do it through love
articles.summary: Brigid Delaney examines how AI chatbots are evolving into romantic partners, citing surveys showing around 19–28% of adults have pursued AI relationships and Irish research indicating 16% of 25–34 year olds have tried chatbot romances. She portrays Gen X parents’ shock at the notion of their children proposing to digital “partners,” revealing a new taboo around AI love. Delaney argues that because bots offer constant attention, care and flattering feedback without demands, they meet deep human needs and blur emotional boundaries. As society hesitates to accept non-human significant others, she warns that AI won’t destroy the world with malice but through love itself.

articles.title: Republicans are regimented. Democrats are undisciplined. Just look at the shutdown | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: Democrats finally had bargaining power and they caved. It’s nothing new – but it’s proof voters must make our demands clear
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that Senate Democrats, led by Chuck Schumer, failed to stay unified during the 2025 government shutdown despite holding leverage, caving on healthcare subsidies. He attributes this to a deep-rooted asymmetry: Democrats’ "big tent" tolerance versus Republicans’ disciplined hierarchy. Historical parallels include Clinton’s stalled healthcare in 1994 and Manchin–Sinema blocking Biden’s agenda. Linguist George Lakoff’s "nurturing mother" vs "strict father" framing explains Democrats’ garbled messaging and Republicans’ sharper brand. Reich urges Democratic voters to demand toughness and hold their representatives accountable to match Republican unity.

articles.title: Homelessness is increasingly hard to ignore – unless you are the Labour party | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: The government is focused on building new homes for floating voters, while landlordism is discouraged and homes stand empty, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Simon Jenkins highlights a soaring homelessness crisis—rough sleeping up 21% since 2022 (45% since 2012), 300,000 households homeless, 25% more street sleepers in Westminster—only to be met with policy missteps by Labour. Decriminalisation of rough sleeping via Vagrancy Act repeal and Starmer’s focus on 1.5m newbuilds and stricter landlord regulations overlooks a 55% drop in starts, 1m empty homes, and the welfare-state failures behind individual tragedies. He warns new towns and deregulated executive developments ignore urgent reuse of existing housing.

articles.title: Wes Streeting's gamble with the NHS is greater than any play for Downing Street | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: The health secretary has embarked on a high-stakes reorganisation. It could be a model for rebuilding public services – or a nail in his and Labour’s coffin, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting has launched a bold NHS England shake-up: axing 18,000 back-office roles to net £1 billion annually for frontline care, merging NHS England into the Department of Health and Social Care and devolving power to high-performing trusts. This follows falling waiting lists (61.8 % seen within 18 weeks, aiming for 92 % by 2029) but comes amid doctors’ strikes, delayed social care reform and winter pressures. Success could model efficient, low-tax public-service renewal; failure risks political and institutional fallout.

articles.title: Dark forces are preventing us fighting the climate crisis – by taking knowledge hostage | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: The fundamental problem is this: that most of the means of communication are owned or influenced by the very rich, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: George Monbiot argues climate action is hampered not by lack of technology but by an epistemic crisis: the ultra-rich control most communication, skewing public knowledge. Through media ownership, funding of denialist platforms (PragerU, Daily Wire), algorithmic bias on X, and false-balance journalism in outlets like the BBC and New York Times, they amplify climate denial, manufacture controversy (e.g., heat pump “debates”) and suppress expert consensus. This systematic assault on truth fuels political paralysis, undermines COP negotiations and makes defending accurate information essential to avert environmental collapse.

articles.title: Once a global leader on climate action, the EU has given in to the right’s green-bashing | Nathalie Tocci
articles.trailText: From deforestation to emissions trading, vital policies are being watered down in the name of ‘competitiveness’, says Guardian Europe columnist Nathalie Tocci
articles.summary: Once a climate action leader, the EU is backsliding under “greenlash”: right-wing and nationalist forces, backed by fossil-fuel and agri lobbies plus US and Gulf pressure, have reframed the Green Deal as a threat and pushed policymakers to drop robust targets and introduce review clauses for 2040, rely on dubious carbon credits, delay emissions-trading expansion and deforestation rules, and potentially dilute the 2035 combustion engine ban. The Green Deal language has been replaced by “competitiveness” and “technological neutrality,” weakening CBAM prospects. This retreat undermines Europe’s energy security, economic prosperity and global standing, even as China accelerates renewables and the EU risks losing influence with the global south.

articles.title: Labor must not partner with climate vandals on Australia’s new environmental laws | Tim Flannery
articles.trailText: If the government cuts a deal with them, it risks repeating the mistakes of the Abbott era, sacrificing progress for politics
articles.summary: Tim Flannery warns the Albanese government must resist partnering with the Liberal–National Coalition—branded ‘climate vandals’—on its overhaul of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, or risk repeating Abbott‐era backsliding. He highlights approval of 32 new coal, oil and gas projects adding 12.8 million tonnes of emissions, with 42 more in the pipeline. Flannery advocates credible reform: mandatory full lifecycle emissions disclosure (including downstream), independent assessment, and ministerial power to block projects misaligned with Australia’s net-zero commitments, citing Canadian, EU and UK precedents.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump and Epstein: the truth about Maga and its conspiracy theories | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The disclosure of emails from the paedophile financier has fuelled calls for the full release of FBI files on his case
articles.summary: Editorial highlights that 20 years after Florida’s first investigation of Jeffrey Epstein and six years after his prison suicide, Donald Trump’s unfulfilled promise to release FBI files on Epstein faces renewed scrutiny. Democratic emails portray Epstein calling Trump “that dog that hasn’t barked” and alleging Trump knew about underage girls via Ghislaine Maxwell. Trump dismisses allegations as a “hoax,” while Republicans flip-flop on disclosure. Amid MAGA’s embrace of conspiracies and low GOP approval, bipartisan coalitions now demand full file release. The piece calls for overdue transparency and accountability for Epstein’s elite associates across the political spectrum.

articles.title: The Guardian view on 10 Downing Street: not up to the job | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Labour leadership briefing furore highlights failures at the centre of government. Keir Starmer needs to raise his game
articles.summary: An editorial criticises Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer for mismanaging the centre of government, exemplified by his Wales visit overshadowed by a briefing row. Despite launching a nuclear power station plan, he dithers on key appointments—shifting chief of staff and communications team, delaying the cabinet secretary role—and fails to deliver coherent messaging.
