The piece argues that structural reforms, such as redefining No 10 and Cabinet Office roles and separating civil service leadership, are urgent. Starmer’s inability to build a stable, effective team undermines public confidence; he must 'up his game’ to restore credibility and governance.

articles.title: This week’s doctors’ strike is another test of Wes Streeting’s mettle. He is right not to buckle | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: No one denies their deep grievances – but after seeing improvements and winning generous pay settlements, the BMA is overplaying its hand, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: From Nov 13, BMA resident doctors stage a five-day strike amid early flu surges, 54,000 ED waits over 12 hours and a 7.39 m elective backlog. In 49 strike days over two years they’ve rescheduled 1.5 m appointments. Health Secretary Wes Streeting cites a 28.9% pay rise over three years, 5.4% above inflation this year and promised training reforms giving UK graduates first choice of the 10,000 posts, yet BMA seeks another 29%. Ninety percent backed strikes on 55% turnout, but public support has slipped to 40%. Eight percent of UK-trained applicants still miss posts, fueling calls for more community generalists.

articles.title: Starmer’s backers never meant him to be prime minister – his leadership was doomed from the start | Neal Lawson
articles.trailText: His alliance with the party’s anti-Corbyn faction was a shotgun marriage that totally lacked vision. Now Labour is paying the price, says Neal Lawson of the cross-party campaign organisation Compass
articles.summary: Compass director Neal Lawson argues Keir Starmer’s leadership was always a temporary alliance between Corbyn loyalists and Blairite faction fighters, engineered to secure a win then hand power to Wes Streeting. Unforeseen events – Covid, Tory collapse, SNP decline – turned Starmer from placeholder into accidental prime minister in 2024. Lacking any coherent vision or policy depth beyond internal discipline, Labour now struggles to govern despite a large majority. Lawson warns the party faces structural crisis absent a strategic roadmap, devolved power and pluralist culture. He urges MPs to rethink leadership, policy and culture, pointing to figures like Miliband, Rayner or Burnham to rescue Labour.

articles.title: Trump is pushing 50-year mortgages. Talk about short-term thinking | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: A proposal touting 50-year mortgages could double interest payments and worsen inequality
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi lambasts Trump's proposal to offer 50-year fixed-rate mortgages as a superficial "gamechanger" that lowers monthly payments but doubles total interest and fuels long-term inequality and price inflation. She highlights how pandemic-era 30-year, sub-3% loans advantaged early homeowners—locking in equity and freezing the market—while new buyers struggle with 6% rates and soaring costs. Experts warn extended terms won't solve root issues; instead they bolster housing inequity. Mahdawi argues the plan typifies Trump's flashy, short-term band-aid politics.

articles.title: It soothes my bitter heart to know that no matter how much money Elon Musk has, he will never, ever be funny | Rebecca Shaw
articles.trailText: What the Tesla tycoon wants his billions can’t buy: being able to get a true laugh
articles.summary: Rebecca Shaw skewers Elon Musk’s attempts at humor, arguing that no amount of money or clout—buying Twitter or cozying up to presidents—can buy comedic talent. She dissects his cringe-inducing Joe Rogan joke about economists eating excrement—awkward delivery, forced laughs—and his charm vacuum even next to figures like Trump. Framed as emblematic of his deeper emptiness—obsession with wealth, lack of empathy and curiosity, reliance on sycophantic circles—his endless craving for validation is thwarted by his inability to connect or be genuinely funny. Shaw celebrates this comedic failure as a rare silver lining amid Musk’s broader influence: some things even billions can’t procure.

articles.title: Republicans are scrambling to reclaim affordability. Good luck with that | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Two problems stand in the way of the party’s efforts: their policies and their president
articles.summary: Facing a populist left that won on affordability, Republicans from Vivek Ramaswamy to JD Vance insist cost of living must be their focus—but their record undercuts the pitch. Trump-era tariffs and deportations have driven up grocery bills, HUD cuts threaten rental aid, ACA premium tax-credit lapses will spike healthcare costs for 24 million, and a gutting of the LIHEAP staff imperils winter energy subsidies. Meanwhile, the president’s mixed messages—promising $2-a-gallon gas, tariff dividends and 50-year mortgages—lack detail, even as SNAP recipients endure benefit cuts during a weeks-long shutdown.

articles.title: Ultra-rich media owners are tightening their grip on democracy. It’s time to wrest our power back | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The Guardian has no billionaire or corporate owner: funded by readers, our fierce independence is guaranteed
articles.summary: Robert Reich argues that tech and finance billionaires—Musk (X), Bezos (Washington Post), Ellison (Paramount/CBS), Murdoch (Fox, WSJ)—are consolidating media to shield their wealth and curry favor with Trump, chilling criticism and eroding democracy. He exposes conflicts of interest in editorial decisions—e.g., Post endorsements, CBS newsroom shake-ups—and warns of plutocratic influence over FCC rulings and coverage. Reich calls for full disclosure of media owners’ interests, stricter anti-monopoly review of outlets and support for independent, reader-funded press like the Guardian.

articles.title: How should we tackle Reform and the rise of the far right? Our gen Z panel has some ideas
articles.trailText: Our panelists have seen first hand what happens when you give young people platitudes instead of hope, but they feel a change coming
articles.summary: Generational panelists highlight widespread Gen Z alienation from Labour and Westminster politics—driven by rent, precarious work and cuts to youth services—and warn that Reform’s simple, emotive narrative and media-savvy Farage exploit this disaffection. They argue the left must rebuild from the ground up by organizing in workplaces, universities and community campaigns; telling compelling, empathetic stories like the TUC’s friendship video; exposing far-right policy failures; and investing in public services, social housing and youth spaces. Only a solidarity-rooted, hopeful politics that meets young people’s material realities can counter Reform’s rise.

articles.title: I decided to put my change into a cash-converting machine. Big mistake | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: The machine sought to claim both a transaction fee and a percentage of my change. Why would anyone agree to this, asks Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles begins with a childhood memory of being stopped by police and made to jump up and down on Shoot-Up Hill, which left him hyper-aware of pocket coins. Decades later, he finds a station car park accepting only pound coins, prompting him to hoard change and fill jars. Attempting to convert stray coins at a Sainsbury’s Coinstar machine, he discovers a 39p flat fee plus an 11.75% processing charge (8.9% if donated). Baffled that frugal savers would pay these fees, he’s abandoned the service, instead piling pound coins at home and spending them little by little.

articles.title: New face, same problems: replacing Keir Starmer with Wes Streeting will do nothing to help Labour | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Both share a fixation with process over project and have an absence of values, which can only result in a trail of broken promises, says Guardian columnist Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams argues that replacing Keir Starmer with Wes Streeting won’t solve Labour’s core failings—an obsession with process over purpose and a lack of coherent values. Both leaders courted the left to win support then pivoted right in office, sidelining activists and breaking promises. A 2021 rule change raising the nomination threshold to 20% of MPs was tailored for Streeting, yet internal manoeuvres and ideological vacuity persist. Williams warns that endless U-turns erode trust, fuel Reform and Green challenges, and that Labour needs genuine principles, not another face, to regain purpose and popularity.

articles.title: The real Reform voters have been revealed – it’s a slapdash coalition Farage will struggle to hold together | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: This is no single bloc marching under one ideology, or even a mass of ‘red-wall’ voters. What unites them is a desire for something different, says Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Hope Not Hate’s poll of 11,000 Reform UK supporters finds they’re not a single bloc but a fragile alliance: one in four “red wall” voters who go left-on-economics and right on social, one in five “hardline Conservatives,” plus “reluctant reformers,” “squeezed stewards” and “contrarian youth.” Their drivers range from frustration over NHS waiting lists, housing affordability and cost-of-living pressures to anti-immigration sentiments and environmental concerns. Farage’s hybrid platform of deep tax cuts, selective renationalisation, pro-business entrepreneurship rhetoric and hardline migration policy struggles to reconcile these diverse demands, revealing both his coalition’s fragility and the mainstream’s failure.

articles.title: Sicily deserves better than the looming prospect of a giant bridge that will never get built | Jamie Mackay
articles.trailText: Troubled waters over the world’s longest suspension bridge are no surprise. The Italian government should be funding public services, says Florence-based writer Jamie Mackay
articles.summary: Jamie Mackay argues that Sicily’s famed ferry across the Strait of Messina, beloved for its communal charm, embodies local identity and resilience more than any impulsive mega-project. Despite proposals since the 1960s and a €13.5bn pledge, legal wrangles, seismic risks, mafia fraud, water shortages and failing public services have repeatedly stalled the world’s longest single-span bridge. With 70% of residents opposed over water diversion, home demolitions and ecological harm, Sicilians need urgent investment in schools, healthcare and infrastructure—not a costly steel panacea. Salvini’s U-turn underscores officials’ preference for grandiosity over climate and crisis relief.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour leadership speculation: a symptom of failure to define a governing purpose | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Downing Street briefings to flush out potential rivals have needlessly damaged the prime minister and raised the stakes around the budget
articles.summary: Downing Street briefings have sparked speculation within Labour, as MPs ponder replacing Keir Starmer less than 18 months after a landslide victory. Loyalist leaks aimed at sidelining rivals like Health Secretary Wes Streeting backfired, fueling doubts over No 10’s competence and Starmer’s lack of a clear governing vision. With polls sliding and a tax-raising budget looming, dissident MPs weigh a leadership gamble, while supporters warn of market unrest and diplomatic fallout. Yet without a resonant purpose or persuasive case for change, Starmer risks deeper instability unless he defines a compelling policy narrative.

articles.title: The Guardian view on special Trump treatment for Hungary: roll on the next election | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: As polls suggest that Viktor Orbán’s authoritarian rule is under threat, Brussels can only wait and hope
articles.summary: In a pre-election Oval Office meeting, Donald Trump granted Viktor Orbán an exemption from US pressure to cut off Russian energy imports and offered a murky “financial shield” in exchange for commitments to buy US gas and nuclear power—rewarding Orbán’s 2016 support and undercutting EU unity. With Orbán’s Fidesz trailing in polls against centrist Péter Magyar, who pledges domestic reform and constructive EU engagement, Brussels can only hope its illiberal leader’s obstruction of Ukraine accession and rule-of-law breaches will cost him votes.

articles.title: Celebrating literature is good – but I’m running out of patience with celebrity book clubs | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: Sarah Jessica Parker swept all before her at the Booker prize ceremony, but is fame the best way to encourage reading, asks Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Brockes praises celebrity-driven literacy campaigns – notably Sarah Jessica Parker’s stint reading 153 books to judge the Booker Prize – but grows exasperated by the formulaic glamour of celeb book clubs. From Natalie Portman posing with Virginia Woolf to Reese Witherspoon’s floral onesie and “reading is sexy” tropes, Brockes questions whether hotness is the right hook. She contrasts Witherspoon’s predictable rom-com picks with Dua Lipa’s more literary selections, and notes authors’ enthusiasm for star endorsement. While grateful for raised profiles, Brockes urges healthy skepticism toward hype unmoored from expertise.

articles.title: Labour’s rebuttal to the Green party this week sums up the double standard that dogs our politics | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: Why is it that the politics of hope offered up by the left is dismissed as naive, while the policies of the centre and right are portrayed as all that is possible? asks Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Frances Ryan criticises a political double standard in Britain where leftwing policies are labelled naive and undeliverable, while centre-right ideas are deemed realistic. She highlights Labour’s caution—dubbing Green proposals impractical—and contrasts it with the hard right’s fearmongering on migrants and welfare. The two-child benefit cap, introduced by Conservatives despite evidence of harm, only faces repeal after campaign pressure. Media coverage skews towards Reform over Lib Dems. Ryan argues that popular solutions like rent controls and nationalised energy are dismissed as radical, stifling real change.

articles.title: A word of warning to the hounds circling Starmer: be careful what you wish for | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: With this level of unpopularity, the question of the PM’s future may seem simple. Yet what comes next could be nastily complicated, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Labour PM Keir Starmer faces deep unpopularity, sparking talk of a leadership challenge. No 10’s strategic briefings aimed at deterring rivals like Health Secretary Wes Streeting backfired, exposing Downing Street disarray and Streeting’s media strength. With Labour trailing in polls and internal angst mounting, MPs debate when and how to oust him, yet lack a coherent plan. Options range from a formal contest—requiring 20% of MPs—to a forced recontest of his mandate. Such a revolt, unprecedented under a Labour government, risks market and political turmoil. Ousting Starmer could reshape both his and the party’s future.

articles.title: Boyfriends are cringe. But is the #boysober trend a feminist reclamation or a neoconservative tilt? | Lisa Portolan
articles.trailText: Young women are rejecting the idea of emotional dependence on men. But as with any online feminist movement, it exists in tension
articles.summary: Since 2025, young women on TikTok have embraced the #boysober movement, publicly abstaining from dating and emotional dependence on men as an act of self-preservation against dating-app fatigue, tech-facilitated abuse, and unequal emotional labor. Framed as feminist reclamation, #boysober rejects heteronormative scripts and promotes self-partnership and bodily autonomy. Critics argue it mirrors neoconservative purity culture and risks commodification by postfeminist media. Yet the trend signals a generational shift: de-centring coupledom, interrogating patriarchy, and reimagining intimacy beyond traditional romance plots.

articles.title: Yes, New York will soon be under new management. But Zohran Mamdani is just the start | Carys Afoko
articles.trailText: Lina Khan outraged corporates and conservatives as head of the Federal Trade Commission. Expect more of the same now she’s with the mayor-elect’s transition team, writes Carys Afoko
articles.summary: Lina Khan, former FTC chair, joins New York’s mayor-elect transition team, signaling ambition beyond Zohran Mamdani’s progressive mandate. At 32 she revitalised the FTC: curbing pharmaceutical price gouging to lower inhaler costs, blocking a major supermarket merger and securing over $60m in unpaid tips for Amazon drivers. Despite bipartisan confirmations, she faced corporate pushback—Meta, Amazon and billionaire Democrats sought her recusal or ouster. Her appointment hints at continued aggressive consumer-protection and antitrust measures under the new administration, even against entrenched business and political interests.

articles.title: The BBC’s editing error was serious, but the response is way out of proportion | Margaret Sullivan
articles.trailText: The broadcaster should not cave to Trump’s demands
articles.summary: The BBC’s documentary on Trump incorrectly juxtaposed two clips separated by an hour, suggesting he urged violence at the Capitol—an editing mistake that warranted correction but not the ensuing political and legal firestorm. Trump has threatened a US$1 billion lawsuit, two top BBC executives have resigned, and critics question the broadcaster’s impartiality amid broader coverage controversies. Margaret Sullivan argues that while the error demands transparency and internal review, the BBC must defend itself legally, resist Trump’s demands, and uphold the free-press role it still commands in the UK and US.

articles.title: Covid vaccines may increase the lifespan of cancer patients – this could be a game changer | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: A study suggests mRNA vaccines could help the body fight malignant cells, says Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: An observational Nature study of 884 stage 3/4 lung cancer patients at MD Anderson found those receiving a Covid mRNA vaccine (Pfizer or Moderna) within 100 days of starting immunotherapy (n=180) lived a median 37.3 months versus 20.6 months in unvaccinated controls (n=704), with 55.7% vs 30.8% alive at three years. A similar benefit was seen in metastatic melanoma. Mouse models suggest Pfizer/Moderna mRNA shots act as a systemic immune “flare,” converting cold tumors hot. If RCTs confirm this effect, repurposing these safe, low-cost vaccines could yield an off-the-shelf cancer immunotherapy.

articles.title: Labour is standing on a precipice: if it breaks its election promise on tax, it will never be trusted again | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: Ruling out tax rises in its 2024 manifesto was utterly reckless and will fan the flames of the far right, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Owen Jones warns Labour’s leadership is poised to break its 2024 manifesto pledge not to raise income tax, national insurance or VAT by hiking income tax by two pence, offset by employee NI cuts. This reversal risks destroying public trust more profoundly than the Lib Dems' 2010 tuition fees U-turn, fueling right-wing populism and eroding credibility. He criticises Rachel Reeves and Keir Starmer for sacrificing principle and coherent narrative, ignoring calls to tax Britain’s super-rich (£772.8bn held by 350 households) instead of working people. Jones argues this betrayal will provoke political fury, empower Nigel Farage and fringe parties, endanger democracy’s fragile legitimacy and leave Labour permanently tainted. The belated scrapping of the two-child benefit cap won’t repair the damage.

articles.title: There’s a missing link in British public life – and it underpins crises from the BBC to our prisons | Rafael Behr
articles.trailText: A declining sense of collective identity is corroding trust in our institutions and undermining democratic politics, says Guardian columnist Rafael Behr
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Rafael Behr argues that Britain’s crises—from accidental prisoner releases to the BBC bias row—stem from eroding collective identity. Using the public goods game, he shows cooperation rises when people see themselves as part of a group; without shared identity, taxpayers resent contributing to jails or public broadcasting. Short-sighted politics have boosted sentences without boosting budgets, overwhelming prisons, while attacks on the BBC undermine a key unifying institution. Behr warns that fractured identity fuels mistrust, hindering necessary public investment and risking polarisation unless citizens reclaim a broad sense of community.

articles.title: The EU has let US tech giants run riot. Diluting our data law will only entrench their power | Johnny Ryan and Georg Riekeles
articles.trailText: The GDPR is Europe’s defence against digital oligarchy and child harm. Deregulation plans are misguided, say Johnny Ryan and Georg Riekeles
articles.summary: In this commentary, Johnny Ryan and Georg Riekeles warn that the European Commission, under von der Leyen and backed by Germany, plans to weaken key GDPR provisions—including the purpose-limitation principle and special-category data rules—ostensibly to spur AI growth. This deregulation would legitimize years of data harvesting by US tech giants, cement their digital monopolies, and threaten child safety. Instead, authors advocate strict GDPR enforcement, urging the European Data Protection Board to pressure Ireland’s dismal regulator, eliminate nuisance consent pop-ups, and reclaim EU tech sovereignty. They argue enforcement will break up cascading monopolies, protect democracy against foreign interference, and create space for European startups to scale.

articles.title: The Liberal party’s betrayal of younger voters on net zero isn’t just a moral failure – it’s electoral stupidity | Intifar Chowdhury
articles.trailText: For a Coalition desperate to prove it can govern again, ignoring millennials and gen Z is a curious kind of strategy
articles.summary: Dr Intifar Chowdhury warns that, despite its 2025 election loss, the Liberal party persists in diluting net zero policy, driving away millennials (only 20% support) and Gen Z (27%). Polls show a majority favor a 2050 net zero goal (Blueprint 52%, Guardian 44%, Redbridge 37%), and climate surged to a top-four voter concern (25% in 2022 vs 11.8% in 2010). Even conservative supporters want bolder action. Ignoring issue-driven young voters on climate is both morally wrong and electorally moronic.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Labour’s fiscal stance: it’s time to lay new foundations | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: No chancellor has raised income tax since 1975, but voters may accept it if everyone contributes, the richest most of all, and the money pays for fairer, better services
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial criticizes Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s inflexible fiscal rules—so tight that minor GDP revisions trigger talk of tax rises and spending cuts—and urges her to relax or replace them with a concise, transparent summary at each budget. It argues a modest income tax hike, last seen in 1975, could fund fairer services, including reversing the two-child benefit cap to lift 350,000 children from poverty, without curbing public investment. The piece calls for a positive cost-of-living narrative, richer contributions, and a voluntary gilt-conversion plan to lower debt costs and boost long-term growth.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Fifa’s new ‘peace prize’: Gianni Infantino should concentrate on the day job | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The president of world football’s governing body should abandon geopolitical networking and address criticisms over World Cup ticketing
articles.summary: FIFA president Gianni Infantino’s high-profile alliance with Donald Trump—culminating in public praise at the Gaza peace summit and the launch of a new annual FIFA ‘peace prize’ in Washington—exemplifies his focus on geopolitical networking rather than addressing governance concerns. Critics warn that ahead of the 2026 World Cup’s expansion to 48 teams, FIFA’s aggressive monetisation—via dynamic pricing, uncapped resale mark-ups, overblown Club World Cup tournaments and deals with ‘sportswashing’ states like Qatar and Saudi Arabia—threatens fan access and the integrity of the sport, spurring petitions such as New York’s ‘Game over greed’ campaign.

articles.title: I’ve seen the BBC flat out on the canvas before. Brave journalism is the best way to hit back | Roger Mosey
articles.trailText: The corporation is again being put to the test. Now is its chance to double down on reporting that serves the people of the UK, says former head of BBC TV News Roger Mosey
articles.summary: Former BBC TV News head Roger Mosey warns that after repeated crises—from the Hutton report to misleading edits—the BBC must reassert its public-service remit with fearless, precise journalism that serves all UK audiences. He cites recent managerial lapses—misidentified sources, Trump edit scandals and ‘marketing mania’—and a well-meaning liberal tilt that alienates leave voters, immigration sceptics and others. Funded by a universal licence fee, the BBC should resist political interference, embrace diverse lawful viewpoints, sharpen editorial rigour and accountability, and foster open debate rather than seek extra regulation.

articles.title: Does Britain value culture any more? Ask the striking workers at the British Library | Zadie Smith
articles.trailText: The dispute over pay at this great national institution gets to the heart of our misplaced priorities, says novelist Zadie Smith
articles.summary: In a speech on the British Library picket line, Zadie Smith argues that Britain markets itself as a bastion of literary culture yet undercuts living cultural workers through chronic underfunding and poverty wages. Library staff—71% of whom report salaries below basic living costs—face inflated workloads, verbal abuse after a major cyber-attack, and meagre pay while senior executives earn six-figure bonuses. Smith criticizes government cuts to culture budgets (–1.4%) alongside a £2bn AI plan, warning that a nation’s identity relies on sustaining both its heritage and the workers who preserve it. She highlights the hypocrisy of honouring dead literary icons while neglecting the staff who maintain the library’s collections.

articles.title: It’s the BBC v Trump, Farage and co. Who in their right mind would want to be its new boss? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Public life is a minefield and the best and brightest just don’t want to know. How convenient for foes of the most trusted news organisation in the world, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde critiques the BBC’s current crisis over three impartiality fails—the Panorama edit, transgender coverage and allegations of bias in BBC Arabic—that have provoked high-level resignations and a threatened $1bn libel suit from Donald Trump. She exposes right-wing pressure from Nigel Farage’s conflict-ridden criticism and contrasts Britain’s less polarised, high-trust media market with US distrust. Hyde argues that onerous public-sector scrutiny and low pay repel qualified candidates for director general, debunking calls for a business outsider. Instead, she suggests reappointing veteran insider Mark Thompson for a time-limited stint, warning that public service roles now drive away top talent.

articles.title: Recharging station: can at-home mats provide the same benefits as PEMF therapy? | Natasha May
articles.trailText: People in pain swear by pulsed electromagnetic field therapy. Experts weigh in on the mats that have emerged as a self-therapy tool
articles.summary: Manufacturers pitch PEMF mats—‘fancy yoga mats’ emitting pulsed fields to ‘recharge’ cells—gained traction via biohackers like Gary Brecka on Joe Rogan. Experts note FDA-approved devices (MRI, TMS) use much stronger, focused fields; commercial mats generate fields ~1,000× weaker, with rapid decay and inconsistent body contact. No randomized, controlled human trials validate home mats, though some cell/animal studies and medical-grade devices show bone and pain modulation potential. Combined infrared heating may aid circulation. Chronic pain management should prioritize proven strategies—gentle exercise, sleep hygiene, physiotherapy and psychological therapies—over unproven mat claims.

articles.title: Keir Starmer may be too busy to master the latest dance craze – but he needs to be on TikTok | Carys Afoko
articles.trailText: Yes, there’s a country to run, but the social media platform has 30 million users in the UK. Can the PM afford to abandon them all to Nigel Farage, asks Carys Afoko
articles.summary: With over 30 million UK users, TikTok now drives shopping, trends and political engagement through personalised vertical video. Brands like M&S leverage TikTok Shop as influencer marketing reshapes ad spend. Yet PM Keir Starmer has no personal account and 10 Downing Street’s TikTok hasn’t posted since 2022, while Nigel Farage (1.3 m followers), Zarah Sultana (488 k) and Reform’s in-house studio deliver rapid, authentic clips. Afoko argues politicians must embrace short-form, human content on TikTok to reach younger audiences and control the narrative.

articles.title: A leaked IDF video showing alleged detainee abuse has Israel reeling, but not in the way you might think | Roy Schwartz
articles.trailText: The outrage has been all about who leaked the footage and who is hurting Israel’s image, not what actually happened at the Sde Teiman detention camp, says Roy Schwartz, a journalist at Haaretz
articles.summary: Roy Schwartz argues that Israel’s fury over a leaked IDF video showing detainee abuse at Sde Teiman is aimed at the leak’s source and national image, not the alleged brutality. In July 2024 five soldiers were indicted for beating, tasering and sexually assaulting a Palestinian detainee. IDF legal chief Maj Gen Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi resigned amid a leak probe, disappeared briefly, was found in custody and reportedly attempted suicide. Political elites denounced the footage as a ‘blood libel,’ recast the accused as victims and sidelined the detainee’s suffering.

articles.title: Musk could be paid $1tn. Nvidia’s worth $5tn. Yet America’s poor are struggling to eat | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: We may be in a golden age for the super-rich – but it doesn’t feel that way for the 42 million Americans who use Snap
articles.summary: Tesla shareholders approved a $1 trn pay package for Elon Musk and Nvidia’s market cap topped $5 trn, while the 10 richest US billionaires gained $698 bn in a year. Yet 42 million SNAP recipients faced a 10-day benefit halt under Trump, who claimed lack of funds even though SNAP costs $8 bn/month and he pushed a $1.5 trn tax-cut bill for the wealthy. Voters punished Republicans over affordability in recent elections. New York City mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, a self-described democratic socialist, plans a 2% annual tax on incomes over $1 m to fund free transit, childcare and more, invoking MLK’s call for fairer wealth distribution. The article contrasts Mamdani’s focus on “forgotten Americans” with Trump’s gilded spending, tariffs and broken cost-of-living promises.

articles.title: Arguing about whether or not to wear a poppy misses the most crucial point | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: David Lammy being caught without a poppy sparked a national debate. But there are many ways to honour the fallen, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams critiques the national furore over wearing Remembrance poppies—sparked by MP David Lammy’s suit swap snafu—arguing both wearing and refusing a poppy are equally legitimate gestures to honour the fallen. She invokes veteran Simon Weston’s plea for restraint, warning that today’s rigid, performative 'poppy-mania' stifles nuance and true reflection. Her stance, unchanged for over 25 years, emphasises genuine reflection rather than uncritical celebration of conflict. Williams even forgot it was Remembrance Sunday while cycling through Westminster, highlighting how the debate eclipses genuine unity and collective memory.

articles.title: What happens if the Greens overtake Labour in the polls? All bets are off | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: They may lack Labour’s party machine, but Zack Polanski’s burgeoning popularity could have seismic consequences for British politics, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Since Zack Polanski won Green leadership in September, his blunt messaging and TikTok-worthy soundbites have driven the Greens from a 12-point deficit to near-parity with Labour in recent polls. If they overtake, it would shatter Labour’s assumed left-wing dominance, triggering a herding effect like Reform’s surge under Farage. Despite having only four MPs and limited infrastructure, the Greens’ upbeat coverage and appetite for radical alternatives could transform temporary poll gains into sustained electoral momentum, forcing Labour leftward or upending current assumptions about Britain’s political landscape.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the BBC under siege: Britain must defend its own truth | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: With Donald Trump circling and Labour ministers wavering, defending the corporation’s independence is now a test of national will
articles.summary: Under siege after rightwing bias attacks and Trump’s threatened lawsuit, the BBC has lost its director-general and news CEO, exposing leadership gaps. As Britain’s most trusted national institution faces a 30% funding cut, its civic mission remains unclear amid competition from US tech platforms that monetise outrage. The licence fee’s future is in doubt, risking commercialization. Editorial independence is now a test of national will: UK politicians, particularly Labour’s Starmer, must defend impartial journalism and media sovereignty as a matter of national security.

articles.title: The Guardian view on education reform: Labour risks missing its chance to change schools | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Ministers should encourage teachers who are keen to try new things before the new curriculum’s formal adoption
articles.summary: Labour’s education reforms risk losing momentum as ministers delay a special needs white paper to consult further, despite pressure from councils over funding overspends. The Francis review’s gradual roll-out of new GCSE content and national curriculum from 2028–29, accepted by Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson, aims to safeguard teacher workload but sidelines interim measures like trimmed exam timetables, early oracy modules and media literacy that could boost teacher autonomy and morale now. Urgent attention is also needed on modular “V-levels” in maths and English and reengaging the million 16–24s outside education or training.

articles.title: The first step towards saving our precious BBC: remove Robbie Gibb from the board | Ed Davey
articles.trailText: The BBC belongs to all of us, and it is under attack as never before. The government must defend it from its enemies, within and without, says Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey
articles.summary: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey argues the BBC is under unprecedented attack by Trump and rightwing populists who see it as a threat to their conspiracy-driven platforms. He recounts earlier assaults—from Dominic Cummings’ plan to create a “Fox News equivalent” to Nigel Farage calling the BBC “the enemy”—and criticizes Boris Johnson’s appointment of Robbie Gibb, a former Tory communications chief and GB News adviser, to the BBC board. Accused of editorial interference, Gibb should be removed to safeguard the BBC’s independence, impartiality and democratic mission to inform, educate and entertain. Davey stresses the BBC—the world’s top trusted news source—must be shielded from domestic and foreign political meddling by banning all political board appointments.

articles.title: If you care about the BBC, stand up and defend it: this could be the beginning of the end | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Replacing the TV licence with a means-tested alternative may help disarm the right of one of its most effective weapons, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: After the shock resignations of DG Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness over a spliced Trump segment, Polly Toynbee warns this reflects a coordinated right-wing campaign—led by figures like Robbie Gibb, Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage—to dismantle the BBC by weaponising the unpopular licence fee. She highlights the BBC’s rigorous 436-page editorial charter, its 60% public trust rating and global reach, and urges defending public funding—ideally a fairer, means-tested licence—to safeguard this essential national institution.

articles.title: War and truth-telling warrant reflection this Remembrance Day. That takes more than a minute | Paul Daley
articles.trailText: Remembrance is a conscious act – political, cultural and personal. Today it is worth reflecting on who and what we commemorate, and what we choose to omit
articles.summary: On Remembrance Day, Daley argues that politicians reduce commemoration to empty eulogies, failing to learn lessons beyond tactics and ignoring mass civilian suffering in current conflicts. He critiques Australia's habitual alignment with foreign wars—most recently the $368bn Aukus submarine pact with the unpredictable US—and warns of further entanglement at the expense of service personnel and civilians. He highlights the ongoing mistreatment of veterans, the neglect of frontier wars and Indigenous dispossession in national memory, and the War Memorial's resistance to confronting uncomfortable truths. True remembrance requires sustained, inclusive reflection beyond a minute's silence.

articles.title: Unrwa has the capacity and expertise to support a postwar Gaza. We want to help make this peace work | Philippe Lazzarini
articles.trailText: With a ceasefire in place, rebuilding must begin, justice be delivered and healing seriously addressed by Palestinian and Israeli societies, says the commissioner-general of Unrwa Philippe Lazzarini
articles.summary: With Gaza's fragile ceasefire offering temporary relief, Unrwa warns of urgent needs such as shelter, food, healthcare and education amid winter and pervasive trauma. Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini urges unfettered UNRWA access, an international stabilization force to secure infrastructure and enable Palestinian civil governance, and engagement of local professionals. Citing the ICJ's endorsement of UNRWA's neutrality, he stresses restoring public services, especially for 700,000 displaced children, while avoiding post-2003 Iraq mistakes. Sustainable recovery hinges on durable housing, functional hospitals and schools within a credible two-state framework, justice delivery, reversal of dehumanization, reconciliation and long-term human rights investment for lasting peace.

articles.title: Antidepressants are trendy. That’s a double-edged sword | Tayo Bero
articles.trailText: It’s great the taboo is fading. But as TikTok influencers tout them, it’s a slippery slope to the memeification of disorders
articles.summary: On TikTok, micro-communities (#lexaprotok, #zoloftgang) have catapulted antidepressants into mainstream pop culture, racking up billions of views. While destigmatization is positive, the author warns that non-medical “patient influencers,” some linked to pharma, are memeifying serious disorders and glossing over side-effects. In the US, direct-to-consumer ads and telehealth have made SSRIs easy to access, driving a 66% rise in youth prescriptions (2016–22). Bero argues that this profit-driven marketing risks coercing vulnerable young people and urges a more responsible, clinical approach.

articles.title: Brutish, bullying, imperialistic: the Ugly American is back | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: Donald Trump is using US power to insert himself into other countries’ affairs, treating them as vassals
articles.summary: Steven Greenhouse argues Trump has revived the 'Ugly American' by bullying foreign governments—imposing tariffs on Brazil, Canada and the EU; threatening Colombia, Venezuela, Argentina and Israel; undermining climate and refugee policies; and berating leaders at the UN. His coercive tactics have damaged US credibility, slowed economic growth and pushed allies toward Russia, China and India. Though he occasionally pressured Netanyahu on Gaza and sanctioned Russia, Greenhouse warns Trump’s aggressive diplomacy fuels global tensions and calls on nations and Congress to push back. Polls report plummeting US favorability and widespread distrust.

articles.title: Why I love Martha Stewart – the original unapologetic alpha woman | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: She bites her pets, dumped Hannibal Lecter and claims she was the original tradwife. For anxious, people-pleasing women like me, channelling some of her DGAF energy could do us some good, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington celebrates Martha Stewart as the original unapologetic alpha woman and tradwife prototype, combining homemaking, empire-building and self-promotion since the 1980s. Stewart’s DGAF ethos shows in everything from her obsession with perfect hydrangea tablescapes and rare geese welfare, to tutorials on pomegranate-seed prep and “omelette supper for thirty.” Single, a 4–4:30am New York Times reader, former Anthony Hopkins dumper (Hannibal Lecter scare) and pet-biter, she courts controversy via hemp gummies, thirst-trap pool pics and bold self-branding. Beddington urges anxious women to channel Stewart’s audacity.

articles.title: As a palliative care specialist, I’ve witnessed the human tragedy of our end-of-life care crisis | Rachel Clarke
articles.trailText: While the government debates assisted dying, palliative care is an afterthought. And many more people face death without the care and support they need, says Rachel Clarke
articles.summary: Rachel Clarke, an NHS palliative care specialist, exposes a crisis: the NHS funds only 30% of UK hospice care, forcing charities to cover the rest. In 2023–24, two-thirds of adult hospices ran deficits, leading to staff cuts, reduced beds and slashed home services. This postcode lottery means many of the 580,000 annual deaths face avoidable pain and indignity—150,000 lack palliative support and some die in A&E. Demand will rise over 25% by 2048, yet palliative care appears just once in the NHS 10-Year Plan. As parliament debates assisted dying, Clarke warns political underinvestment drives needless suffering.

articles.title: In New York, Zohran Mamdani showed how it’s done: ‘identity politics’ can win elections | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: New York’s newly elected mayor rooted his campaign in the personal while, ironically, exemplifying the tradition of the American ‘melting pot’, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: New York’s newly elected mayor Zohran Mamdani built a broad, multiethnic coalition by reimagining identity politics as intersectional organising rooted in shared material struggles. He framed his campaign around affordability—rent freezes, free buses, universal childcare—then spoke directly in Urdu, Hindi, Spanish and Arabic, quipping about Queens’ knafeh and invoking Yemeni bodega owners, Mexican abuelas, Senegalese taxi drivers and Uzbek nurses. A Muslim who refused to shrink under Islamophobia, he mobilised marginalised groups and white college-educated parents alike, demonstrating that authentic, inclusive identity politics can win elections by uniting voters on justice, not victimhood.

articles.title: In Sweden, online hate and anti-immigrant extremism are driving women out of public life | Martin Gelin
articles.trailText: A leading liberal politician has quit in fear of her physical safety. It is a crushing setback for democracy in one of the world’s most open societies, says journalist Martin Gelin
articles.summary: After a televised debate Anna-Karin Hatt, leader of Sweden’s liberal Centre party, resigned citing death threats, offline stalking and extremist trolling—echoing predecessor Annie Lööf’s exit under neo-Nazi menace. Unregulated social media, Sweden Democrats’ troll farms and Riks network amplify anti-immigrant, misogynistic hate. Conservative leaders shrug off concerns, deterring women, immigrants and minorities from public life. Historical context—from Palme’s and Lindh’s murders to the Utøya massacre—underscores the stakes. Similar violence against female politicians globally threatens democratic diversity and DEI progress.

articles.title: The BBC is facing a coordinated, politically motivated attack. With these resignations, it has given in | Jane Martinson
articles.trailText: The corporation should have stood up to the Telegraph, Trump and the Tories. Now, its enemies know how little it takes for it to fold, says Jane Martinson, professor of financial journalism
articles.summary: Prof. Jane Martinson argues the BBC’s DG Tim Davie and News CEO Deborah Turness resigned under a coordinated right-wing campaign—fired by a leaked 19-page dossier from ex-adviser Michael Prescott accusing bias over a mis-edited Trump Panorama clip, pro-Hamas Arabic coverage and alleged LGBTQ influence. Amplified by the Telegraph, Mail on Sunday, Boris Johnson and Trump’s team, the assault exposes how culture-war tactics exploit a timid BBC response. Weakened by charter negotiations, licence-fee cuts and political meddling (including Prescott’s ties to Robbie Gibb and Ofcom), the corporation risks eroded trust and compromised impartiality.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the assault of Mexico’s Claudia Sheinbaum: when a president is groped, no woman can feel safe | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A shocking incident should become an opportunity to address broader problems of misogyny
articles.summary: Guardian editorial condemns the groping of Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, by a drunken man in public as proof that no woman, regardless of power, is safe from sexual violence. It cites official data: one in five women in Mexico suffer community-based assault yearly and ten are killed daily, with similarly widespread harassment in the US and UK. Critiquing entrenched machismo and political-sexual attacks on leaders like Gillard and Harris, it urges Sheinbaum to criminalize harassment nationwide and partner with grassroots feminists to tackle pervasive misogyny.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Scottish land reform: vast estates remain feudal in scale | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Half of the country’s privately owned countryside is held by just 421 owners. New legislation suggests democrats still fear powerful interests
articles.summary: Land ownership in Scotland remains more concentrated than any other European country, with 421 individuals holding half of all private rural land. The new land reform bill introduces a ‘transfer test’ requiring ministers to be notified of sales over 1,000 hectares and ‘lotting’ powers to subdivide estates, but lacks a veto or public-interest requirement. Experts like Andy Wightman and Common Weal advocate a land-value levy or Nordic-style taxes and stronger public-interest tests. SNP ministers recently voted down ownership caps to avoid deterring investment, maintaining the entrenched feudal-scale estates.

articles.title: I’m a committed introvert – but no AI will take away the joy I get from other people | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: While it might be soothing to think you could replace social interactions like book clubs with ChatGPT, subcontracting human thought out to a bot will never bring happiness, writes Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington, a self-described introvert, argues that replacing human experiences with AI shrinks joy. She critiques using ChatGPT for puzzles, trivia, book clubs and crafts AI essays on Substack, pointing to bland, impersonal generalities. Instead, she finds vivid pleasure in group singing’s social bonding, exploring eccentric secondhand treasures at a car boot sale, admiring textiles in Renaissance paintings, and observing people in cities like a human buffet. Citing photographer Martin Parr’s magpie eye for everyday life, Beddington concludes AI can aggregate masses but fails to capture the beauty of particular, unpredictable human connections.

articles.title: Welcome to 21st-century politics: a bitter revolt against power that will consume Labour and the Tories | John Harris
articles.trailText: A mood of turbulence and insurgency against the two main parties has been building for years, says Guardian columnist John Harris
articles.summary: Guardian columnist John Harris argues that Westminster’s hollow rituals mask a deep insurgency dismantling the two-party duopoly as voters demand more nuanced representation. Rachel Reeves’s veiled announcement of national insurance, VAT or income tax rises reverses a manifesto pledge, intensifying public distrust of traditional politics. Thinktank boss Luke Tryl warns mainstream parties are in their “last chance saloon.” Meanwhile, Reform UK, Greens, Lib Dems, SNP and Plaid Cymru are gaining ground, reflecting voters’ complex identities. Harris cautions that unless Labour and the Tories modernize, they face collapse or an unexpected Reform majority, perpetuating a turbulent political cycle that defies old majoritarian models.

articles.title: A year on from Trump’s victory, resistance is everywhere | Rebecca Solnit
articles.trailText: Americans have shown a tremendous amount and variety of opposition – more than some may realize
articles.summary: Since Trump’s 2024 victory, Americans nationwide—from judges and federal workers to students, clergy and artists—have mobilized in diverse acts of resistance: legal, environmental and human rights challenges, mass protests (7 million at the No Kings rally), boycotts of Tesla, Target and Disney, whistleblowing and walkouts at CDC, sanctuary cities, rapid-response teams tracking ICE and solidarity networks protecting immigrants. State attorneys general and universities sued or defied the administration, religious leaders spoke out, and military and civilian officials resigned in protest. This multifaceted opposition, driven by civil society and non-elites, underscores unpredictable tipping points in the fight for human rights and constitutional norms.

articles.title: Novels I haven’t finished reading are piling up by my bedside. What if that’s a good thing? | Hanna Thomas Uose
articles.trailText: Authors are sounding warnings about the length of the modern attention span, but my series of abandonments is a sign of something else, says author Hanna Thomas Uose
articles.summary: Novelist Hanna Thomas Uose reflects on her habit of abandoning dozens of books and audiobooks, arguing that ‘DNF-ing’ signifies discerning reading in an era of finite time rather than dwindling attention spans. Citing Rankin’s warning, she instead celebrates the glut of accessible fiction and insists readers should direct their focus intentionally. Uose highlights successful short‐form experiments—Lockwood’s tweet‐length prose, Offill’s fragments, Whitaker’s brief chapters—and advocates for novels to evolve through new patterns, serialisation (Wattpad), and authentic narratives that better reflect readers’ lives rather than blaming them for distraction.

articles.title: Does Trump truly care about Nigerian Christians? Of course not – he just knows faith sells | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: In a bid to exercise absolute power, today’s crop of authoritarian leaders is recruiting – and exploiting – believers, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Simon Tisdall critiques Donald Trump’s theatrical threat to invade Nigeria under the pretext of saving Christians as cynical pandering to white evangelical voters, noting Islamist violence harms Nigerian Muslims too and there’s no genocide. He parallels Trump with modern authoritarians—Putin’s partnership with the Russian Orthodox Church, Modi’s Hindu nationalism, Erdoğan’s Islamist populism and Xi’s atheist suppression—who exploit or control religion to cement power. Simultaneously, a global religious revival—fueled by insecurity, digital alienation, conflict and charismatic online influencers like Sister Albertine—is reshaping spiritual engagement, underscoring faith’s political leverage and its enduring appeal as a source of community and hope.

articles.title: Everybody panic – the workplace has become too ‘feminized’! | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: This week, Mexico’s president was groped in public. But a New York Times podcast is fretting about excessive wokeness
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi skewers a New York Times podcast hosted by Ross Douthat that, with guests Helen Andrews and Leah Libresco Sargeant, claims liberal feminism has ‘feminized’ and stained workplaces with ‘wokeness,’ cherry-picking examples from #MeToo to campus culture and labeling gossip and indirect conflict as ‘feminine vices.’ Andrews fails to articulate what she admires about women. Mahdawi contrasts this pseudointellectual misogyny with urgent realities: Mexico’s president groped in public, a widening US gender pay gap, and high-profile sexual misconduct allegations, arguing that while true women’s rights roll back, the debate over excessive feminism is dangerously misplaced.

articles.title: Where is the Gaza ‘peace process’ really going? | Ahmad Ibsais
articles.trailText: Israel turns the violence up and down at will, maintaining full dominion over Gaza and the West Bank, then calls each pause a generous ‘ceasefire’
articles.summary: Ibsais notes attending one Gaza funeral a day since Jan 2025 would last until 3887, underscoring the death toll. He argues Israel orchestrates and breaks ceasefires to justify genocide and colonial expansion in Gaza and the West Bank. He cites a 'Peace 2025' summit excluding Palestinians, at least 100 ceasefire breaches, continued bombardment, home demolitions, 22 new settlements in 2025, and 800,000 uprooted olive trees since 1967. Drawing parallels to US buffalo slaughter and indigenous oppression, he condemns apartheid and demands equal rights 'from the river to the sea,' rejecting any peace that preserves Palestinians as a dependent, disenfranchised population.

articles.title: Caught up in a violent attack, would you be a hero – or would you run? Both can be valuable | Emma Kavanagh
articles.trailText: Last weekend’s Cambridgeshire train attack brought up a question that we often ask ourselves. But the answer isn’t simple, says psychologist Emma Kavanagh
articles.summary: Psychologist Emma Kavanagh reflects on responses to last weekend's Cambridgeshire train attack, arguing that beyond 'fight or flight' humans also 'tend and befriend', drawn to aid loved ones or victims once safe. She explains how pre-existing schemas—seeing oneself as a helper—and prior crisis experience shape instinctive aid. She stresses that fleeing is adaptive, and that survival instincts shift to helping afterward. She notes under high stress the prefrontal cortex recedes, so instinct and learned schemas guide split-second decisions. In the aftermath, traumatic stress is normal; many rebuild a 'survivor' identity, often achieving post-traumatic growth though recovery can be bumpy.

articles.title: I wish we could ignore Bill Gates on the climate crisis. But he’s a billionaire, so we can’t | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: Money talks – and his essay denouncing ‘near-term emissions goals’ at Cop30 mostly argues the case for letting the ultra-rich off the hook
articles.summary: George Monbiot lambasts Bill Gates’s COP30 essay for reducing climate action to a technical choice and ignoring political power and wealth inequality. Gates calls to shift scarce funds from near-term emissions cuts to adaptation, poverty and disease relief, yet omits how oligarchs war on state spending, hoard trillions (Oxfam: top ten US billionaires gained $698bn) and block higher taxes. Monbiot also notes Gates’s fossil fuel holdings, silence on Trump’s climate obstruction and the “billionaire brain” that blinds the ultra-rich to systemic risks and abrupt ecological tipping points.

articles.title: The president is groped in broad daylight, and Mexican women cry: MeToo, MeToo, MeToo | Mona Eltahawy
articles.trailText: After Claudia Sheinbaum was assaulted this week, her opponents claimed she staged it. From their own experiences, the women I met know she didn’t have to, says author Mona Eltahawy
articles.summary: When Mexico’s first female president, Claudia Sheinbaum, was groped by a drunk man in broad daylight while mingling for selfies, it ignited a #MeToo moment in a country where half of women face sexual violence. Sheinbaum filed charges, defying right-wing claims the attack was staged to distract from a mayor’s assassination. Feminists condemn machismo-fuelled street harassment and note critics branded her ‘reckless,’ even ‘deserving.’ Survivors sharing #MosqueMeToo and #IBeatMyAssaulter stories hope this viral incident will finally break taboos, spur accountability and safer public spaces. Academics warn this is a teaching moment exposing normalized assault and demand systemic reforms in policing and public policy.

articles.title: In a world with democracy in decline, we have much to learn from those who rallied against Whitlam’s dismissal | Frank Bongiorno and James Watson
articles.trailText: In 1975, few Australians believed the dismissal of a democratically elected government was business as usual
articles.summary: Fifty years after Sir John Kerr dismissed the Whitlam government, historians Bongiorno and Watson spotlight the mass grassroots response—from rallies, strikes and street theatre to the looming threat of a union general strike—to defend democracy. Although isolated violence and letter bombs occurred, most protests stayed peaceful. This ‘dismissal from below’ foreshadowed Bob Hawke’s consensus politics and illustrates how ordinary Australians’ organised resistance upheld democratic institutions—a timely lesson amid today’s global democratic decline.

articles.title: The Guardian view on worsening extreme weather: the injustice of the climate crisis grows ever clearer | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The increasing ferocity and frequency of tropical storms imposes an unbearable burden on countries including Jamaica
articles.summary: This editorial warns that extreme weather is amplifying global injustice, as Caribbean nations like Jamaica confront Hurricane Melissa’s record five-day rainfall—doubled by higher temperatures—and a death toll of at least 75. Recovery from 2024’s Hurricane Beryl left crucial infrastructure underpaid for; damage now equals roughly one-third of Jamaica’s GDP. Meanwhile Typhoon Kalmaegi has killed nearly 200 in the Philippines and Vietnam, and a second storm looms. At COP30 in Brazil, António Guterres called missing the 1.5 °C goal a “moral failure.” The piece argues loss and damage funding is too slow, UK’s £7.5 m pledge is insufficient, and wealthy emitters must deepen emissions cuts and bolster finance for vulnerable states.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the John Lewis Christmas ad: a modern story of fathers and sons | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: It might be darker than usual, but this year’s festive offering reflects our fears for boys growing up today
articles.summary: In an editorial, the Guardian analyses John Lewis’s 2025 Christmas ad centered on a father–son bond as a lens on today’s ‘crisis of boyhood’—from the ‘manosphere’ to youth mental-health struggles. By gifting his teen son a 1990 Alison Limerick vinyl, the ad bridges generational isolation engendered by social media. It foregrounds white middle-class masculinity amid a cost-of-living crisis, shifting focus from last year’s sisters to male narratives. This motif mirrors broader cultural currents: Booker-shortlisted novels by Szalay and Markovits, Stephen Graham’s father-son letter project, and new men-only literary communities assert the need to hear male voices. The ad’s emotional hug underscores our duty to connect with sons.

articles.title: Leftist and centrist Democrats won on Tuesday. So what’s the party’s lesson? | Dustin Guastella
articles.trailText: Zohran Mamdani, Abigail Spanberger and Mikie Sherrill focused their messages on the economy, but structural problems endure
articles.summary: Democratic victories by socialist Zohran Mamdani in New York City, centrist Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey and anti-socialist Abigail Spanberger in Virginia show that a populist economic focus and distancing from unpopular fringe social-justice stances can broaden appeal. Yet all three are wealthy elites, highlighting Democrats’ structural gap with working-class voters. Mamdani’s compelling long-term vision outshines poll-tested “popularism,” but municipal power and an urban base limit its reach. To retake Congress, Democrats need conviction, coherent policy vision and national appeal beyond deep-blue cities.

articles.title: Democrats should celebrate this week’s victories, but beware: Trump is already plotting his revenge | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: The Maga machine is clicking into gear to ensure that defeat is all but impossible in next year’s midterm elections, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: Riding a wave of off-year wins—from Zohran Mamdani’s historic New York mayoral victory to decisive gubernatorial triumphs in New Jersey and Virginia and a pivotal California redistricting measure—Democrats are buoyant but facing an energized MAGA backlash. Freedland warns Trump, backed by GOP lawmakers and conservative media, is preemptively plotting revenge: gerrymandering Texas-style districts, suppressing votes with ID, curbing early and postal voting, deploying “monitors” and troops, and pushing Supreme Court challenges to the Voting Rights Act. With total control of the White House, courts and Congress, Trump aims to block a Democratic House takeover in 2026 and cement an autocratic stronghold.

articles.title: The right wants to destroy our fragile faith in the NHS – don’t let that happen | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: The service is a symbol of our shared values as a nation. No wonder divisive forces in politics and the press are working to undermine it, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues that the political right and hostile media are undermining public faith in the NHS, now at just 21% satisfaction in the British Social Attitudes survey. NHS England chief Jim Mackey and King’s Fund data show staff morale falling, long waits and growing racial abuse of paramedics. While 91% back free care and 80% support funding by taxation, only 56% 'definitely' want universal access. Local patient experiences (46% good) outstrip national perceptions. Toynbee warns that defending NHS values requires renewed social solidarity against Reform-party scepticism and divisive narratives.

articles.title: Trump is threatening the basic needs of poor Americans. How low he has sunk | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The president has put Snap benefits in jeopardy amid a fight over Medicaid. The nation has lost its moral authority
articles.summary: Robert Reich criticizes President Trump’s threat to withhold Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits from 42 million low-income Americans during the government shutdown fight over Medicaid. A federal court ordered full funding, but the administration seeks to appeal after proposing half payments. Reich contrasts this reversal of FDR’s moral test with the so-called “Big Ugly Bill,” which cuts $1 trillion from poor and working-class programs, slashes Obamacare subsidies, and imposes stringent Medicaid work requirements while delivering $1 trillion in tax breaks to the wealthy. He warns of rising uninsured rates, deeper inequality and calls on Democrats to focus on affordability and fairness.

articles.title: At last, a great institution filled with trusted public figures. Shame the Traitors don’t run Britain | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: The Celebrity Traitors drew to a magnificent close this week – and proved that these lying double-crossers are of a far finer calibre than our MPs, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde lauds the finale of The Celebrity Traitors, arguing its mix of intrigue and authenticity far outshines the antics of British MPs. She recalls how politicians once clung to reality TV—from Gordon Brown’s X Factor letters and a proposed Junior PM show to David Cameron’s Simon Cowell endorsement and Russell Brand’s fleeting political influence—and suggests public votes on Strictly foreshadowed the Brexit revolt. Ipsos polling now rates stars like Claudia Winkleman double the trust of ministers. With a high‐calibre, vote-free format, Traitors marks reality TV’s new prestige era, one politicians can no longer hijack.

articles.title: Airline chaos is coming to America. If only Democrats had less of a backbone | Dave Schilling
articles.trailText: If this stretches to Thanksgiving, we’ll be facing a nightmare. The obvious solution: move back in with your parents
articles.summary: Satirical column warns that the record-length US government shutdown has left FAA staff unpaid, threatening cancellation of 10% of flights (1,800 daily) at 40 airports—escalating chaos just before 30 million holiday travelers take to the skies. Dave Schilling lampoons politicians’ unwillingness—especially Democrats—to fund aviation, even as ICE and military continue to get paid. Amid rising living costs, stagnant wages and soaring layoffs, he jokingly urges a mass move back in with parents to skip travel, cut emissions and relieve airport strain—perhaps letting AI run air traffic when controllers are on “internship” pay.

articles.title: Increase taxes for working people, or make the super-rich pay their fair share? The answer seems obvious – but not to Labour | Dhananjayan Sriskandarajah
articles.trailText: Rachel Reeves has unnecessarily blocked her options of what to include in her budget, says Dhananjayan Sriskandarajah of the New Economics Foundation
articles.summary: Dhananjayan Sriskandarajah of NEF warns chancellor Rachel Reeves, constrained by her own debt rules, sees only three budget options: cut benefits for people unable to work, raise taxes on struggling workers or ask the super-rich to pay more. Despite rhetoric about ‘working people’, Labour previously eyed disability cuts and shuns radical wealth taxes. Rumoured council-tax reforms or exit levies could help tackle inequality, but fears of a rich exodus make an income-tax rise more likely - a costly misstep amid high living costs. He urges a deeper overhaul: dismantle extractive capitalism, equalise capital-gains and income tax, and crack down on tax havens to ensure fair burden-sharing.

articles.title: My verdict on the 'woke' review of England's school curriculum? It isn't radical enough | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: When I heard it was dumbing down education, my heart sank. In fact, it’s outspoken about the chaos of Michael Gove’s reforms and the changes needed, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins reviews England’s new curriculum reform report, praising its candid critique of Michael Gove’s exam-obsessed 2015 overhaul, highlighting its overly academic focus and neglect of arts, oracy and life skills. Drawing on a 7,000-submission survey of parents, pupils and employers, the report calls for relevance—financial literacy, civics, digital media literacy, compulsory arts and music, citizenship and professional autonomy for teachers. Jenkins applauds its emphasis on oracy and misinformation defence but warns its modest 10% exam reduction and retention of GCSEs/A-levels lack the boldness needed to break exam shackles.

articles.title: Meet gen X: middle-aged, enraged and radicalised by internet bile | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: Who is driving the populist insurgency? It’s not grumpy pensioners or vulnerable teenagers – it’s my generation, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff argues that Gen X, once seen as moderate, is driving a populist insurgency by carrying internet-fueled bile into real-world conversations. She describes public exchanges – from threats of political violence in an Aldi queue to racist taunts in hospitals and conspiracy ‘sauna politics’ – as online habits bleeding offline. YouGov data show Reform UK support among 50–64s jumped from 19% to a third. Facing midlife insecurity over redundancy, aging and irrelevance, many are shifting toward Reform or Trumpism, yet radicalization studies for 45–65s remain scarce.

articles.title: Net zero is an insidious loophole that distracts from the scientific imperative to eliminate fossil fuels | Joëlle Gergis
articles.trailText: History tells us that polite incrementalism and political kowtowing will prevail at Cop30 – even as catastrophe unfolds around us
articles.summary: At COP30 in Brazil, climate scientist Joëlle Gergis argues that “net zero” is a political loophole distracting from the scientific necessity of eliminating fossil fuels. Despite record CO2 at 423.9 ppm in 2024 and 90% of emissions from fossil fuels—coal at a record 41%—countries plan to double fossil production by 2030. Nature-based offsets demand 1 bn ha of land, risk wildfires, and let polluters buy credits. Current carbon removal covers <0.1% of emissions. Only immediate cuts and carbon pricing, not tree-planting schemes, can avert runaway warming.

articles.title: For a few dollars, I bought a childhood game from the op shop. Watching my kids play felt like time had folded in on itself | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: It struck me how something so simple – wood, coins and powder – could hold so much joy
articles.summary: Shadi Khan Saif buys a worn carrom board for $10 at a Melbourne op shop, reigniting memories of childhood in Karachi when his cousins and he gathered by candlelight to flick wooden discs, learning patience and teamwork. Introducing the tabletop game—with its striker, carrom men and red queen—to his kids, he rediscovers simple joy and sees how op shops keep past lives and stories alive.

articles.title: The Guardian view on mistaken prisoner releases: a broken system not human error | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Recent cases of prisoners let go by mistake rightly disturb the public. But they reflect the overstretched and underfunded criminal justice architecture
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that recent accidental prisoner releases – notably two inmates from HMP Wandsworth and another from Chelmsford – expose a chronically underfunded, overcrowded and understaffed justice system rather than mere human error. Overcrowding at Wandsworth (166%) and Chelmsford (133%), combined with budget cuts, poor management and probation reductions, undermines prisoner tracking and fuels rising mis-releases (115 to 262 cases in a year). Blame-shifting between Conservatives and Labour fails to address the systemic crisis, which demands sustained funding and leadership for meaningful reform.

articles.title: The Guardian’s view on Gaza’s future: the ceasefire brought relief, but the world must not look away now | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Palestinians are being born amid the rubble. They need not only immediate relief but long-term justice
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Gaza’s ceasefire, while offering respite, conceals deep fragility: over 200 Palestinians killed post-truce, thousands of bodies under rubble requiring years to clear, schools and hospitals shattered, newborns delivered in ruins. Aid resumes but faces Israeli registration hurdles; demolitions continue where forces remain. Mediators debate safe passage for Hamas fighters amid fears of a stagnant “no war, no peace.” Washington seeks a UN stabilization force, but disputes over mandate and troop contributions threaten progress. The world must sustain pressure to secure Palestinian justice and lasting peace.

articles.title: Mamdani’s mayoral race was marred by unhinged Islamophobia. It’s not going away soon | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The racist abuse that Zohran Mamdani is still facing proves how normalized bigotry is. We need to keep calling it out
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani’s historic election as New York’s first Muslim mayor has been overshadowed by virulent Islamophobia from figures like Laura Loomer (warning of “another 9/11”), councilmember Vickie Paladino, actress Debra Messing, and Republicans seeking to denaturalize him. Mainstream media and politicians—including Andrew Cuomo and Eric Adams—have normalized anti-Muslim tropes, while financiers like Shaun Maguire and congressman Randy Fine face no fallout. Studies show US outlets disproportionately portray Muslims as terrorists, underpinning policies from the travel ban to Gaza complicity. Mamdani, whose platform centers on affordable housing and transit, openly challenges this entrenched bigotry.

articles.title: Britain’s two-party politics is fragmenting: what unintended consequences await? | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: On one hand, no more safe seats or long careers could mean less complacency. On the other, no big parties could mean greater corporate influence, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: Andy Beckett observes that Britain’s century-old two-party duopoly is collapsing: Conservatives and Labour now poll under 40% combined, supplanted by a surge in Reform UK, Greens and Lib Dems, triggering unprecedented four-way volatility. Electoral Calculus seat projections range wildly, foreshadowing unpredictable, possibly unfair outcomes. Fragmentation could abolish safe seats and entrenched careers, erode memberships and funding, and empower corporate and civil-service interests. Yet it may also foster voter choice, responsiveness, coalition politics and fuel calls for proportional representation. Alternatively, disordered pluralism could deepen disillusionment or prove transient, as historical shifts have occasionally yielded new dominant orders.

articles.title: Trump is weaponizing the welfare state to attack healthcare | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The proposed withholding of Medicaid and Medicare to restrict gender-affirming care follows the same logic as attacks on abortion care
articles.summary: Moira Donegan argues the Trump administration’s leaked rule to strip Medicaid, CHIP and Medicare funding from any provider of gender-affirming care for minors will function as a nationwide, back-door ban, even in states where such treatment remains legal. She links this tactic to the exclusion of Planned Parenthood from Medicaid after Dobbs, showing how Republicans weaponize welfare programs to restrict abortion and trans healthcare. Donegan warns that perverting Medicare, Medicaid and civil-rights statutes in this way entrenches inequality and undermines the original egalitarian purpose of these safety-net policies.

articles.title: The food stamp fight signals an era of unprecedented cruelty in America | Katrina vanden Heuvel
articles.trailText: US leaders have long shown some responsibility to help poor people meet basic nutritional needs. That era appears over
articles.summary: As the US shutdown drained SNAP funding for 42 million low-income Americans, the Trump administration refused to tap a $5 billion USDA emergency reserve and even sued to block benefits. A federal judge rebuffed that move but the White House then announced a 50 percent cut and allowed 2.4 million people—especially refugees, survivors of trafficking and other legal non–green-card holders—to lose benefits. New work requirements will hit veterans, the homeless and youth aging out of care. States like Virginia and Delaware pledged to backfill payments, but long-term hunger relief awaits broader social reform.

articles.title: A note to politicians hoping to emulate Mamdani’s social media strategy: without the right policies, it’s pointless | Rohan Sathyamoorthy
articles.trailText: Forget the medium and focus on the New York City mayor-elect’s message – centrists can’t compete with rent freezes, free buses and support for Palestine, says writer Rohan Sathyamoorthy
articles.summary: Rohan Sathyamoorthy argues that New York mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s viral success—tens of millions of views on TikTok, Instagram and X—stems less from savvy formats than from unapologetically socialist policies (rent freezes, free buses, Palestinian rights) and authentic, grassroots meme armies. Mamdani’s street-level ads and critics’ screenshots became rallying points online. The UK’s Green leader Zack Polanski echoes this with 12m-view posts on inequality. Centrists lack the radical agenda to galvanize social media; the right similarly forges policies in online subcultures. Ultimately, bold convictions, not optics, drive digital momentum.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani shows how Democrats can defeat authoritarians like Trump | Isabella Weber
articles.trailText: Democrats have two choices: fight to make life affordable again for ordinary people or watch voters embrace authoritarians
articles.summary: After Zohran Mamdani’s historic win in the NYC mayoral race—driven by promises of a rent freeze for stabilized apartments, 200,000 affordable housing units, free bus transit, universal childcare, pilot public grocery stores, funded by higher taxes on millionaires and corporations—Isabella Weber argues that Democrats can counter authoritarian populism by centering an “economics of essentials.” Research shows price shocks in energy, food, housing disproportionately harm the poor and enrich the wealthy. Public options stabilizing prices unite constituencies, curb inflation and inequality simultaneously, and restore faith in democracy. This antifascist economic program contrasts with half-measures and offers a model for democratic parties worldwide.

articles.title: Zohran Mamdani is filling disillusioned Americans with hope and inspiration | Osita Nwanevu
articles.trailText: Whatever he manages to accomplish as mayor, much of potentially national significance can be learned from his candidacy alone
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a Democratic Socialist, won NYC mayoral race by nine points over Andrew Cuomo, defying low name recognition and elite opposition. Starting at 1% in polls in February, he mobilized 90,000 volunteers and one-quarter of self-identified socialist voters. His platform of free public childcare, transit, and wealth taxes resonated with young men and minorities, beating Cuomo by 40 points among under-30s. His grassroots, listening-first approach and balance between reformist and administrative skills offer a potential blueprint for energizing urban turnout in swing states. Now facing a likely federal showdown with the White House, his candidacy alone signals lessons for Democrats on rejuvenating coalitions.
