Williams critiques the lingering social stigma—embodied by her stepmother’s reluctance—and wonders why it’s taken women so long to embrace independent holidays.

articles.title: US universities must reject Trump’s ‘compact’. It is full of traps | Jan-Werner Müller
articles.trailText: The administration is trying to make nine universities an offer they seemingly cannot refuse
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s proposed ‘compact’ offers nine universities preferential funding and White House perks in return for ideological loyalty oaths and government-mandated policies—capping foreign students at 15%, requiring patriotic civics courses, policing ‘incitement’ and engineering a ‘broad spectrum of viewpoints.’ Jan-Werner Müller argues it exceeds presidential powers, threatens academic freedom, and uses vague criteria to entrap institutions. He urges all nine to reject the compact, expose its hidden traps, and defend higher education’s autonomy against autocratic overreach and politically driven bureaucracy.

articles.title: I preached levelling up as the key to Tory success – but Boris Johnson didn’t do it. Now look at us | Justine Greening
articles.trailText: Social mobility and equality of opportunity is crucial to Britain’s success. The party that embraces those things will prosper, says former Conservative minister Justine Greening
articles.summary: Former minister Justine Greening argues the Conservatives squandered levelling up by failing to transform her social mobility agenda—equality of opportunity and ‘talent is spread evenly’—into policy after 2019. Johnson’s government spent two years debating definitions, delivered only superficial town funds and scrapped her successful ‘opportunity areas’ that boosted youth optimism by up to 18 points. Voters punished them for broken promises. As Labour and Reform UK adopt new rhetoric, Greening warns that rhetoric alone won’t suffice: only a coherent, evidence-based social mobility strategy can restore hope and win public trust.

articles.title: Disappearing people, disappearing morals – how two years has changed Gaza and Israel | Orly Noy
articles.trailText: There can be no healing until the world stares into and acknowledges the void torn open by this conflict, says Israeli journalist Orly Noy
articles.summary: Two years after the 7 October massacre, Israeli journalist Orly Noy describes Gaza as a void of disappearance—hundreds of thousands of Palestinians erased without records, morality hollowed, decency and hope obliterated. She decries Israel’s embrace of “total victory,” starvation killing a classroom of children daily, media censorship, and the erasure of opposition under Netanyahu and Ben-Gvir. Normalized genocide, public apathy, and brutal silencing of dissent have severed personal bonds and shattered humanity. Noy warns that true healing requires confronting the abyss this conflict has carved into Gaza and Israeli society.

articles.title: I didn’t think I’d ever say this: let’s hope the Tory party can be saved | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Britain badly needs a grownup party of the centre right. It won’t come from Badenoch – it may come from a new generation of one-nationers, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee argues Britain needs a centrist, ‘one-nation’ Tory revival to counter Kemi Badenoch’s far-right drift. Badenoch’s mimicry of Farage—promising to leave the ECHR, scrap the Climate Change Act and create an ICE-style removals force—alienates moderate and younger Tories, risks deepening divisions and handing seats to Labour or Reform UK. Traditional conservatives like Heseltine, Grieve and new activists such as Cody Butler seek a pragmatic, pro-Europe, pro-business platform to restore competence and social liberalism. Without this, Toynbee warns, the Tory party faces self-destruction under populist extremism.

articles.title: This war of revenge has lasted two nightmare years. There’s only one hope for peace: Israel recognising Palestine | Raja Shehadeh
articles.trailText: Donald Trump’s proposals are in play, but here in the West Bank we live in fear that the devastation of Gaza is coming our way, says writer and lawyer Raja Shehadeh
articles.summary: Palestinian writer Raja Shehadeh reflects on two years of Israeli retaliation since Hamas’s 7 October attack, which killed over 65,000 Palestinians and reduced 92% of Gaza’s housing to rubble. He chronicles decades of dehumanizing walls, checkpoints, house demolitions, settler violence and olive-tree felling, warning that West Bank communities live in fear of similar devastation. Despite global protests and Donald Trump’s Gaza plan, Shehadeh argues that only Israel’s formal recognition of Palestinian self-determination can end the cycle of perpetual war.

articles.title: Two years after 7 October and the kidnap of my parents, hate is in fashion. For all our sakes, we need compassion | Sharone Lifschitz
articles.trailText: So many were killed – yet on her release, my mother said ‘shalom’ to her captors. Let’s learn from that moment of grace, says Sharone Lifschitz, London-based film-maker and academic
articles.summary: Sharone Lifschitz recounts the Oct 7, 2023 Hamas assault on Kibbutz Nir Oz that abducted her 85-year-old mother and 83-year-old father, killed 23 members and traumatized the community. Her mother was freed after 17 days, greeting captors with “shalom”; her father’s remains were returned 502 days later. Two years on, with 48 hostages still held and Gaza’s devastation visible from her destroyed kibbutz, she decries rising hate—from death chants at festivals to antisemitism in the UK—rejects revenge, and honors her parents’ peace activism by urging compassion, empathy, and bridge-building across divides to end the war.

articles.title: In Spain, what once seemed impossible is now widespread: the young are turning to the far right | María Ramírez
articles.trailText: Migration is barely mentioned – instead, failed policies on housing, wages and employment are driving young voters into the arms of Vox, says María Ramírez, deputy managing editor of elDiario.es
articles.summary: Polls show nearly 40% of Spanish men and 20% of women under 34 support Vox, driven less by migration than frustration over housing, wages, employment and the perceived incompetence of mainstream parties during floods and wildfires. Vox’s anti-establishment brand appeals to disillusioned youth, despite its push to expel immigrants, curtail abortion and trans rights and weaken EU institutions. Experts argue the Socialist and Popular parties must shift from partisan bickering to deliver affordable homes, higher wages and genuine crisis management if they hope to win back younger voters. Although Spain’s economy is among Europe’s fastest-growing, young adults struggle with high rents and stagnant incomes, heightening intergenerational tensions.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s Gaza plan: the bloodshed must end, but this proposal betrays Palestinians | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: An end to the annihilation, and the release of Israeli hostages, is urgently needed. But lasting peace cannot be built on the denial of basic rights
articles.summary: After two years of Gaza war since Hamas’s October 2023 attack that killed 1,200 Israelis and Israel’s Gaza campaign killing over 67,000 Palestinians, there is urgent need for ceasefire, hostage release and resumed aid. Donald Trump’s 20-point plan—immediate ceasefire, full hostage and Palestinian prisoner exchange, aid flow, and a vague “board of peace” led by Trump–Blair—gains traction but both Netanyahu and Hamas reject key clauses. The proposal sidelines Palestinian rights by treating statehood as an “aspiration,” risks entrenching occupation, and demands sustained external pressure to avert further betrayal.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Tory conference: history’s revenge on Conservatism | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Speeches from the conference floor reveal a party out of ideas. Its leadership team is mistaking slogans for policy and nostalgia for purpose
articles.summary: At the Tory conference, leader Kemi Badenoch and shadow chancellor Mel Stride delivered fervent but vacuous speeches—recycling austerity and Thatcherite slogans without viable strategies. Facing polls that place the Conservatives potentially fourth and enduring historic lows, the party confronts an existential crisis born of its centrism’s failure. Successive leaders—Cameron’s market-first Triangulation, May’s duty-based minimalism, Johnson’s theatrics, Truss’s ill-fated gambit, Sunak’s caution—have faltered. Badenoch now proposes a harsh 150,000-deportation “immigration hit squad” as drama over design. The editorial warns that declared “the end of history” has rebounded on modern Conservatism.

articles.title: It starts with Palestine protests. But where will the crackdown on Britain’s democratic freedoms end? | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: In making dissent a privilege, not a right, Labour is crafting a repressive toolkit. Imagine it in the hands of a Farage government, says Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: In Britain, Labour’s new rules would turn protest from a right into a privilege, giving police power to restrict pro-Palestinian demos or jail dissenters. Successive governments have eroded freedoms; now a Manchester synagogue attack is used to justify curbs on anti-Israel protests, conflating criticism of genocide and war-crimes with antisemitism. Non-violent groups like Palestine Action are banned, thousands arrested. Owen Jones warns this toolkit could be seized by a future Farage government, marking a dangerous slide towards authoritarianism and the destruction of democratic protest.

articles.title: It’s Badenoch’s Tory show, 2025: like Britain seeing an old flame and remembering why we blocked their number | Frances Ryan
articles.trailText: The conference offers a flailing leader, Trumpite policies and rivals jockeying for position. It is comical, but also worrying, says Guardian columnist Frances Ryan
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s debut as Tory leader at the 2025 Manchester conference felt like watching Britain’s ex fling a tantrum. Her radical pledges include quitting the European Convention on Human Rights, scrapping the Climate Change Act, shredding treaties on immigration and human rights, and creating a £1.6bn “removals force” modelled on US ICE. Shadow chancellor Mel Stride proposed £23bn in benefit cuts for non-citizens. Meanwhile rivals such as Robert Jenrick and Katie Lam jostle for post-Badenoch succession. With MPs halved and Reform rising, the party’s Trumpite turn underscores the rightward pull and signals the progressive fight ahead.

articles.title: Enjoying the implosion of the Tories? That’s understandable – but completely wrong | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: The world’s most successful democratic party is in a death spiral of its own making – leaving no moderate bulwark between the moderate and truly far right, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Zoe Williams argues the UK Conservative Party is in a self-inflicted ‘death spiral’ after Kemi Badenoch’s uninspiring conference address, reflecting a shift toward far-right rhetoric to counter Reform UK’s surge. Potential alternatives like Robert Jenrick or newcomer Katie Lam, who couples traditional Tory imagery with anti-migrant posts, underscore this radical drift. Williams warns that celebrating the Tories’ collapse misunderstands democracy’s need for a stable mainstream right – a lesson from Weimar Germany. By embracing xenophobic soundbites and nationalist pageantry, the party sacrifices moderation and weakens civil society’s bulwark against extremism.

articles.title: Cycle tracking isn’t woo-woo or a tradwife tool. It’s essential education for everyone – no matter the gender | Freya Bennett
articles.trailText: The 24-hour day might be perfectly synced to men’s hormonal cycle – but the menstrual cycle takes a longer view
articles.summary: Freya Bennett recounts monthly slumps in motivation aligned with her menstrual phases, illustrating how cycle tracking reveals clear hormonal patterns that shape mood, energy and productivity. Dismissing it as “woo-woo” in youth, she later used the fertility awareness method—daily temperature and cervical fluid charting—to predict ovulation and confirm early pregnancy. Bennett urges compulsory high-school menstrual education—not as contraception but as fundamental bodily literacy for all genders, enabling early detection of disorders like endometriosis or PCOS. She cautions against tradwife and anti-birth-control co-option, emphasizing cycle awareness should expand personal choice, gender equality and health empowerment.

articles.title: Good and bad news for Zack Polanski: the Green conference was a joy, but now hopes are stratospheric | Adam Ramsay
articles.trailText: Members loved hearing from a leader who boldly reflects their views and isn’t afraid of the rightwing press. How far can he take the party?, says journalist and Green party member Adam Ramsay
articles.summary: At Bournemouth’s Autumn conference, new Green leader Zack Polanski electrified members with bold messaging on nationalising utilities, taxing wealth, drug decriminalisation and anti-racism. Standing ovations replaced past caution as delegates cheered expansion from 58k to 86k members, polling above 10%, 900 councillors and four MPs. Deputies Millward and Ali united the party, endorsing LGBT inclusion and a toolkit against racism. Controversial motions to phase out landlords and proscribe the Israeli military passed. Greens now target Welsh Senedd seats, London elections and mayoralties in Hackney, Norfolk & Suffolk and Brighton, facing high expectations and media scrutiny.

articles.title: Why does the supreme court keep bending the knee to Trump? | Steven Greenhouse
articles.trailText: As a new term begins, the justices have continually failed to provide a check on presidential power – with disastrous consequences
articles.summary: Despite life tenure and US checks and balances, the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority has ruled overwhelmingly—over 90% of emergency docket cases—in Donald Trump’s favor, akin to judges in Hungary and Turkey under Orbán and Erdoğan. Since his return to office, conservatives have allowed Trump to gut agencies, fire independent regulators, cut foreign aid, deport immigrants, and shrink Congress’s spending power. Critics accuse Chief Justice Roberts and colleagues of appeasement, embracing a unitary executive theory to let Trump dismiss officials at will. With approval ratings at an all-time low, many legal scholars warn the court’s deference endangers American democracy.

articles.title: One Bladder After Another: why bros are finally having to queue for the loo | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: There are few things more irritating than waiting outside the Ladies while men sail in and out of their own facilities. A new, very long film has changed all that, writes Guardian columnist Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Beddington explores the unexpected phenomenon of men queuing for bathroom breaks during Paul Thomas Anderson’s nearly three-hour film One Battle After Another. With predominantly male audiences, lengthy runtime prompts long lines at men’s lavatories, a rarity compared to the usual women’s loo queues. Social media and Reddit users strategize “pee breaks” around plot points. Beddington notes gender-neutral toilets could slash waiting times but remain unpopular. She invokes comparisons to hockey games, Oasis gigs and Reddit’s “One Pee Bottle After Another” tactics, joking she might bring earplugs to witness this men-only queue phenomenon.

articles.title: A united Labour party is making Britain work better for all. We cannot allow our mission to be disrupted | Bridget Phillipson
articles.trailText: I’ve delivered for tens of thousands of schoolchildren, lifting them out of poverty – as deputy leader I can deliver for all, says education secretary Bridget Phillipson
articles.summary: Education secretary and deputy leadership hopeful Bridget Phillipson argues that a united Labour has delivered free breakfast clubs, revived Sure Start, reinstated maintenance grants and expanded free school meals to lift 100,000 children from poverty. She urges members to back her bid for a stronger mandate to tackle child poverty and broaden youth opportunity, warning that internal division fuels Tory critics and risks Labour’s second term. Phillipson promises to champion achievements, challenge privately where needed and unite the party to deliver for working people.

articles.title: The fury at home left me terrified of anger. Until a teacher showed me how to use it as a force for good | Marisa Bate
articles.trailText: In an eye-opening drama class, Miss Smith taught me that rage didn’t only belong to men, says journalist Marisa Bate
articles.summary: Marisa Bate recounts how living under her stepfather’s terrifying rages made her fearful of anger until her A-level drama teacher, Miss Smith, used an improv exercise on homelessness to show her that anger can be a positive force. This safe context awakened a sense of injustice and permission to feel and harness rage constructively. Miss Smith’s parting advice—“stay angry”—empowered Bate to reclaim anger from its abusive associations and channel it into activism. Today, she uses that deliberate, considered anger in her journalism on women’s rights, donations, marches and organizing, while still fearing male aggression.

articles.title: The real goal of 'Make America Healthy Again'? Woo-woo treatments for the rich, shrinking healthcare for the poor | Alexander Avila
articles.trailText: A new coterie of advisers around Robert F Kennedy Jr is shaping the US’s already exclusionary health system for the worse, says video essayist Alexander Avila
articles.summary: Under Trump’s new ‘Make America Healthy Again’ (Maha) push, RFK Jr-backed advisers Calley and Casey Means have reshaped US health policy to favor unproven ‘root cause’ wellness solutions. They cancelled $500m in vaccine research, fired thousands of agency staff and spread conspiratorial mistrust of mainstream medicine. Through HSA expansions and their Truemed platform, they aim to redirect trillions in public funds into a $6.3 trn wellness marketplace—selling saunas, cold plunges and supplements—while slashing $1 trn from Medicaid and Medicare, deepening inequities and weakening care for the poor.

articles.title: Don’t despair, Tories: look upon Reform and see your rightful and fitting legacy | Nesrine Malik
articles.trailText: If Kemi Badenoch wonders why her party conference looks and feels like a sideshow, perhaps she should reflect on the Conservatives’ 14 years in power, says Guardian columnist Nesrine Malik
articles.summary: As Tory conference opens in Manchester, Nesrine Malik argues the Conservative party’s 14 years of culture wars, Brexit-fuelled jingoism and punitive immigration policies laid the groundwork for Nigel Farage’s Reform UK. What remains of the Tories has morphed, not died: their normalisation of separatism, anti-immigrant rhetoric and spectacle politics created a more extreme heir free from traditional Tory constraints. Economic stagnation among younger voters drove Conservatives toward culture-war diversions, undermining their governing ideology. Kemi Badenoch’s provocative pledges on net zero, CRT and an ICE-style removals force exemplify this legacy. Rather than lament Reform’s rise, Badenoch should “rejoice” in her party’s inheritance of the Tories’ efforts.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Jaguar Land Rover cyber-attack: ministers must pay more attention to this growing risk | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Cybercriminals pose a seismic and increasingly sophisticated threat to businesses and national security. Yet Britain seems remarkably ill-prepared
articles.summary: Jaguar Land Rover’s recent ransomware attack forced factory shutdowns and computer blackouts, exposing weaknesses in the UK’s corporate and public cybersecurity. While JLR’s deep pockets and profits shield it, thousands of smaller supply-chain firms face layoffs, debt burdens and bankruptcy without faster government support or direct funding. The incident echoes big-game hunting hacks on major brands and state-backed threats, highlighting underinsured businesses, an underfunded National Crime Agency, outdated public IT and stalled cybersecurity legislation. Ministers must strengthen defences, impose software liability and prioritise resilience across critical infrastructure.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the first female archbishop of Canterbury: a choice that offers renewal and hope | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The appointment of Dame Sarah Mullally is a historic moment for the Anglican church, and a cause for wider celebration
articles.summary: Dame Sarah Mullally's appointment as the 106th archbishop of Canterbury marks the first female in the role, completing decades-long fight for gender equality in the Church of England. Amid secularisation, abuse scandals, falling attendance and financial strain, her background as former chief nursing officer and London’s first female bishop lends credibility to efforts on safeguarding youth, advancing “prayers of love and faith” for same-sex couples and restoring moral authority. Facing resistance from traditionalists and international conservatives, she pledges inclusive leadership, countering extremism with tolerance and hope at a pivotal moment for church renewal.

articles.title: The next archbishop of Canterbury has no time to waste in making change – this is what she will be up against | Martine Oborne
articles.trailText: Sarah Mullally is known to be wise, intelligent, courageous and compassionate. That should serve her well in the battles ahead, says vicar Martine Oborne
articles.summary: Martine Oborne outlines the hurdles for Sarah Mullally, the first female archbishop of Canterbury: entrenched misogyny, dissent over her support for same-sex blessings and a past safeguarding lapse, plus seven traditionalist bishops who won’t take communion from her and nearly 600 parishes legally barred from women clergy. Globally, some Anglican provinces and Gafcon reject female leadership. With just six years until retirement, Mullally must pursue clear, process-driven decisions at General Synod to end alternative oversight, challenge institutional misogyny and foster genuine unity.

articles.title: Positive thinking can make success feel like the only acceptable option. But humility allows for grace | Jackie Bailey
articles.trailText: Being humble isn’t about shame or self-loathing: it is the act of being present, of knowing there is room to grow
articles.summary: Jackie Bailey critiques the neoliberal myth of a level playing field and 1990s-style ‘just think positive’ campaigns, arguing self-confidence alone ignores systemic barriers. She invokes St Augustine’s triple call to humility—not shame but pride tempered by openness—and psychiatrist Ravi Chandra’s eight humility types (cultural, intellectual, intergenerational, etc.) with proven boosts to resilience, tolerance and relatedness. As an aged-care pastoral practitioner, Bailey sees humility as presence: listening to residents’ repetitive stories to learn and stay grounded. Drawing on Taoist creative quietude and Rebecca Giggs’s whale-focused narrative, she argues humility reconnects us to a larger whole, allowing failure, grace and sustainable growth.

articles.title: 996 work culture is sad and inhumane. Whatever’s wrong with 888 – or even 000? | Emma Beddington
articles.trailText: Silicon Valley is keen, once more, on a working pattern of 12-hour days, six days a week. It really is time for a new approach, says Emma Beddington
articles.summary: Emma Beddington critiques the 996 work model—twelve-hour days six days a week—resurging in Silicon Valley after gaining notoriety in Chinese tech. She contrasts this grind culture with the utopian 888 (“work, sleep, recreation”) slogan from the early 19th century and modern four-day week trials. Despite evidence that shorter hours boost productivity and well-being, big tech re-embraces “grindcore.” Beddington whimsically proposes alternatives—from 0/0/0 to 1:12 Teams-to-tea ratios—to spark a new work paradigm beyond inhumane 996.

articles.title: Blue states should come together to declare an emergency. Here’s how | Thomas Geoghegan
articles.trailText: States opposed to Trump can create a compact – a new prototype for American government – even if it’s perceived as political theater
articles.summary: In this op-ed, Geoghegan urges anti-Trump “blue” states to form an emergency compact, mirroring colonial-era tactics, by convening a limited interstate convention (NY, CA, MA, IL…) to draft a proto-constitution and budget. It would establish a preamble affirming citizens’ duties and rights—adequate food, healthcare, social security, work, climate and AI safeguards—list Trump and Supreme Court abuses for redress, allocate state/federal funding for mandated programs, and invite DC/PR and other states to join. He frames this legal-political theater as a catalyst for real reform.

articles.title: Why Trump’s speech to US military top brass was such a disaster | Sidney Blumenthal
articles.trailText: The president of the United States seemingly does not understand what the military is for
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s unprecedented address to all senior US military officers at Quantico was a fiasco: he mocked their appearance, humiliated them with threats, and sought applause like in a rally, only to be met with disciplined silence reflecting their constitutional oath, not loyalty to him. He attempted to enlist the military in partisan domestic policing against ‘antifa’ under new executive directives, defying the 1878 Posse Comitatus Act. Preceded by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s vulgar campaign against diversity, gender-neutral standards and legal safeguards, the event underscored Trump’s misunderstanding of military purpose, civilian control and presidential limits under law.

articles.title: I had to flee the US – as a foreign, Black, pro-Palestinian activist, I tick every box on Ice’s list | Amandla Thomas-Johnson
articles.trailText: I’ve never been accused of any crimes, let alone prosecuted. My experience sums-up the draconian plight of non-citizens in the US, says journalist Amandla Thomas-Johnson
articles.summary: Amandla Thomas-Johnson, a Black British PhD student at Cornell, attended a five-minute pro-Palestine protest in Sept 2024 targeting arms-supplier booths and was banned from campus. Facing ICE threats under Trump’s executive orders, she hid before self-deporting to Canada and moving to Switzerland in April. Cornell’s termination of her student visa and Google’s handover of her data to DHS, received 90 minutes apart, revealed likely surveillance via AI tools—Babel X’s “persistent search” and Palantir’s ImmigrationOS. No criminal charges have been filed. Amnesty International warns these pre-crime technologies sweep up non-citizen students, amplify racial and Islamophobic bias, and sidestep due process, exposing migrants to arbitrary expulsion.

articles.title: Trump’s bullying of Latin America isn’t part of any plan – he doesn’t have a clue what he’s doing | Simon Tisdall
articles.trailText: The president’s threats to attack Venezuela are regressive, dangerous and almost certain to backfire, says Guardian foreign affairs commentator Simon Tisdall
articles.summary: Despite vowing isolationism, Trump has ordered air and naval strikes on Venezuelan vessels, threatened to seize the Panama Canal, placed a $50m bounty on Maduro and deployed Monroe Doctrine–style rhetoric, while planning commando raids on drug cartels in Colombia and Mexico. A US military buildup—warships, F-35s, subs, 2,200 marines—signals possible regime change, yet critics say there’s no coherent plan. His heavy-handed approach bolsters Maduro’s emergency powers, prompts Latin American backlash—mass protests in Brazil under Lula, warnings of renewed “Yankee” meddling—and risks ceding influence to China as US credibility collapses.

articles.title: Some people have a choice about whether or not to vote Labour. I wish I did too | Polly Hudson
articles.trailText: I’m disillusioned with Keir Starmer’s government. But my late father’s passion for his political career makes it difficult to imagine putting my cross in another box, writes Polly Hudson
articles.summary: Freelancer Polly Hudson, daughter of a long-serving Labour MP and life peer, grapples with disillusionment towards Keir Starmer’s 2025 government amid successive controversies—winter-fuel-cuts, Mandelson, ‘golden ticket’ and Rayner scandals. She envies ex-Labour candidate Matthew Syed’s freedom to join the Tories, lamenting her inherited loyalty: her late father’s impassioned campaign career ingrained an unwavering party allegiance she feels psychically bound to honour. Despite doubts and autonomous adulthood, Hudson can’t imagine voting elsewhere and wonders how her father would judge Labour’s performance and the viability of a Green vote today.

articles.title: In a world where techlords rule us by whim, Australia’s stance against deepfakes is reason to celebrate | Van Badham
articles.trailText: Could courage be contagious? Let’s hope so, because in the absence of powerful regulation, the normalisation of awful blooms
articles.summary: Australia’s federal court slapped Anthony Rotondo with A$343,500 in civil penalties for posting non-consensual deepfake pornographic images of women, reinforcing image-based abuse as criminal under eSafety legislation. Rotondo’s defiance—emailing the prohibited content to 50 addresses—underscored the need for robust enforcement. After a Bacchus Marsh school incident prompted swift bipartisan anti-deepfake laws, Australia has now scored two regulatory “skirmishes,” alongside its under-16 social media ban lauded by Ursula von der Leyen. Amid global AI misuse—from stolen actor performances to violent AI videos and political propaganda—Van Badham argues for proactive, sandbox-style regulation like early water sanitation to curb techlords’ unchecked harms.

articles.title: The rise of digital money poses significant challenges for regulators
articles.trailText: Bank of England is at crossroads over the use of crytocurrencies and establishing a financial framework for transactions
articles.summary: The shift to digital money—cryptocurrencies, stablecoins and potential central bank digital currencies—is forcing regulators, notably the Bank of England under governor Andrew Bailey, to balance innovation with financial stability. Private issuers promise lower fees and instant, weekend payments but carry moral-hazard, tracking and crash risks. In the US, Trump’s Genius Act creates a Wild West stablecoin market; the EU and nine banks plan a CBDC. The UK now aims for a ‘mid-Atlantic’ model that combines Brussels-style safety with US-style competition.

articles.title: US prosecutors keep charging women with ‘pregnancy-related crimes’ | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: In the two years after Roe v Wade was overturned, hundreds were charged amid growing acceptance of ‘fetal personhood’
articles.summary: In the two years after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, prosecutors in 16 states have charged 412 pregnant people—predominantly low-income women—with "pregnancy-related crimes" for behaviors like substance use or even taking Tylenol, according to Pregnancy Justice. Using child-protection statutes to enforce "fetal personhood," these prosecutions worsen maternal-fetal health by deterring prenatal care and normalizing surveillance of gestational behavior. Advocates warn the U.S. could mirror El Salvador’s zero-tolerance model—where miscarrying women face incarceration—signaling a punitive, authoritarian shift in reproductive policing.

articles.title: After Manchester, progressives should know this: Jewish people feel very alone. We need you to stand with us | Dave Rich
articles.trailText: There’ll be sympathy and heightened security, but in the 1960s when Jewish communities faced attack, there was also solidarity. We need that back, says Dave Rich, director of policy at the Community Security Trust
articles.summary: In his Guardian column, Dave Rich reflects on the October 4 attack at Heaton Park Synagogue in Manchester, on Yom Kippur, as part of a long history of anti-Jewish terror—from 1960s UK neo-Nazis and Palestinian militants to contemporary jihadists, neo-Nazis and online lone actors. He details the extraordinary security burden—reinforced doors, drills, cameras—that Jewish communities bear worldwide, and warns that increased policing only treats symptoms. Progressives must restore the solidarity shown in the 1960s against far-right antisemitism and stand unequivocally with Jews when they’re targeted by jihadists or other extremists.

articles.title: Every American should read this judge’s stirring rebuke to Trump | Austin Sarat
articles.trailText: The court’s opinion in a case on immigrants’ right to free speech is a powerful lesson in civics
articles.summary: Judge William Young of the US District Court for Massachusetts issued a landmark ruling in American Association of University Professors v Rubio, affirming that non-citizens share First Amendment free speech rights and condemning the Trump administration’s detention and deportation of pro-Palestinian scholars—citing high-profile cases like green-card holder Mahmoud Khalil and graduate student Rümeysa Öztürk—as unconstitutional. Young’s opinion lambasts Trump for ignoring constitutional limits, framing immigrant speech rights as integral to American democracy and urging citizens to defend these shared freedoms.

articles.title: Why does Reform seem unassailable? Because this is party conference season, when politicos always lose the plot | Simon Jenkins
articles.trailText: They wrote off Margaret Thatcher in 1981 when the SDP – like Reform today – was ascendant. They were wrong about her; they could also be about Starmer, says Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Simon Jenkins warns that the excitement around Reform’s 27% poll in party conferences repeats the 1981 SDP surge: fleeting hysteria inflated third-party hopes. He argues first-past-the-post and a split opposition fuel Reform’s prospects, but its internal chaos presaged the SDP’s collapse. Keir Starmer’s strategy of playing up Nigel Farage’s threat and tolerating Kemi Badenoch in the Tory ranks could help Labour. Jenkins criticizes Starmer’s timidity on Brexit and migration. He forecasts Reform falling below 25% and Starmer in Downing Street by 2029, while conferences remain pandemonium.

articles.title: There are plenty of ways to humanely control British borders. So why isn’t Keir Starmer using them? | Enver Solomon
articles.trailText: Labour’s incoherent asylum policies are vilifying refugees. A better and more compassionate route is possible, says the Refugee Council’s Enver Solomon
articles.summary: Labour leader Keir Starmer’s plan to curb refugee crossings by ending the asylum “golden ticket” family reunion right, banning benefit or criminal record claimants from settled status, and restricting citizenship is unlikely to deter Channel journeys, argues Refugee Council chief Enver Solomon. He notes refugees follow existing diaspora links, not policy changes, and warns punitive measures will vilify vulnerable people and harm integration. Solomon urges focus on effective humane controls: a “one in, one out” deal with France, ending expensive hotel accommodation through limited-permit schemes, and expanding safe, legal routes.

articles.title: I bought my cat a lead – and I was quickly humbled | Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.trailText: The news that one in six UK cat owners use them baffles me: who are all these cooperative, compliant cats trotting down the street beside their owners, asks Guardian columnist Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett
articles.summary: Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett describes buying a harness for her reluctant cat Mackerel, only to discover via her cat’s dramatic protest that Cats Protection warns leads cause feline stress. Embarrassed by the image of a compliant cat on a leash, she ponders which cats happily stroll beside owners, contrasts with her indoor-averse rescue who still won’t venture out six years later. Reflecting on feline autonomy versus modern “fur baby” culture, she argues that true love requires letting cats choose their own freedom.

articles.title: It hurt when I crashed my bike into a pothole – and it taught me the true price of austerity | George Monbiot
articles.trailText: Fixing that hole could have cost under £100; the cost of not doing so is limitless. My prang highlights the neoliberal folly of false economies, says Guardian columnist George Monbiot
articles.summary: Guardian columnist George Monbiot recounts crashing into an unfixed pothole that cost him £450 in damage though repair would have been £45–90, illustrating the broader ‘false economies’ of austerity. He links neglected road repairs to NHS expenses, highlights two-child and household benefit caps fueling poverty and temporary housing costs of £2.3 bn per year, and exposes chronic underfunding of social care that forces NHS bed-blocking and unpaid carers. Monbiot argues governments ignore non-provision costs while shifting austerity burdens onto the poor, urging fairer taxation of the ultra-rich to fund essential services.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Conservative party conference: Kemi Badenoch’s last shot at relevance | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The Tory leader’s warped analysis of why her party is unpopular has lead her into strategic misjudgments and terrible policy choices
articles.summary: The Guardian’s editorial warns that Kemi Badenoch’s first conference as Tory leader exposes her flawed premise—that her party ‘talked right but governed left’—and has led to strategic blunders. By misreading voter concerns on Brexit, immigration and public services, she has championed extreme policies—repealing the 2008 Climate Change Act, threatening to quit the ECHR and courting Reform UK–style rhetoric—while tolerating hard-right voices like Robert Jenrick. With polls worse than a year ago and defections looming, Badenoch needs a credible recovery plan or risks accelerating her party’s decline.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Tilly Norwood: she’s not art, she’s data | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: The first 100% AI actor is a cause for alarm. But the human connection of great acting can never be replaced
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that Tilly Norwood, unveiled at the Zurich Film Festival as the first fully AI-generated actor, threatens human artistry and actor livelihoods. Critics like Emily Blunt and SAG-AFTRA decry her "jeopardising performer livelihoods" after her face was synthesized from real actors without consent. While creator Eline Van der Velden pitches AI as a novel tool to democratise filmmaking, the piece argues true acting hinges on human empathy and connections. With AI already creeping into Oscar-winning productions and posthumous cameos, the editorial calls for swift legislation to safeguard performers and creative norms.

articles.title: In a time of hate and rancour, two Jews sought to pray – and were killed. Let Manchester be a turning point | Jonathan Freedland
articles.trailText: This was a horror but with so much intolerance and antisemitism, no one can say it was a surprise. There are lessons to learn, and that must start now, says Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland
articles.summary: In his Guardian column, Jonathan Freedland reflects on the fatal Yom Kippur synagogue attack in Manchester that killed two Jews and the assailant, Jihad al-Shamie. He argues that, amid rising global political violence and entrenched antisemitism, British Jews have long lived under stringent security. Freedland issues three calls: unequivocal condemnation of all political violence; caution against opportunistic exploitation by politicians; and urgent progressive reckoning with antisemitism’s blind spots. He warns that anger at Israel can slip into Jew-hatred. Despite vulnerability, Jewish worship continued, reflecting resilience and communal solidarity, with a hope that next year may be truly safer.

articles.title: When will US generals stand up to Trump? | Moustafa Bayoumi
articles.trailText: The president has been rapidly intensifying military operations on United States soil during his second term. Generals need to say something
articles.summary: Bayoumi warns that under Trump the US military is being politicized and deployed domestically in violation of the Posse Comitatus Act. Troops and National Guard have patrolled the southern border, Los Angeles and DC despite legal rulings against such uses. Trump, aided by Pete Hegseth, rebranded the Pentagon as 'War' Department, publicized plans to treat US cities as training grounds, and ousted top brass deemed insufficiently loyal. He notes Trump’s sparse 250th Army parade turned birthday spectacle, overshadowed by mass 'No Kings' protests, and highlights firings of judge advocate generals to enforce loyalty. With illegal strikes against alleged drug smugglers underway, Bayoumi asks when generals will uphold the constitution over presidential edicts.

articles.title: Michelle Mone told us ‘business isn’t easy’ during Covid. How are things now, your ladyship? | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: After a company she was linked to was ordered to repay £122m it made from pandemic deals, the baroness has embarked on a masterclass in victimhood, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Marina Hyde critiques Tory peer Michelle Mone’s self-styled victimhood after her PPE company was ordered to repay £122m over defective pandemic contracts. Detailing Mone’s dramatic letter to Keir Starmer, her grandiose Range Rover analogy and the liquidation of £80m-plus in assets amid an NCA probe, Hyde positions Mone not as a unique scapegoat but as emblematic of the wider VIP lane profiteering scandal.

articles.title: Suddenly, it hit me: I’ll never have children | Shanti Nelson
articles.trailText: I always figured it would just happen at some point. Talk about an immaculate misconception
articles.summary: Shanti Nelson, 55, realizes menopause has sealed her chance at motherhood after years of assuming children would simply happen. She now wrestles with grief, envy and fury—alternating between tears over baby-animal videos and anger at social media’s mother-child reminders. Observing mothers with children in cafes, parks and stores stirs intense longing for a maternal bond she’ll never have and mourning for the grandchildren her late mother won’t meet. Despite friends’ advice to “purge” through menopause or date partners with kids, Nelson feels trapped by hot flashes and midlife regret, yet remains grateful for the mothers who did have children.

articles.title: Disillusionomics: the US economy isn’t serving gen Z | Alice Lassman
articles.trailText: My generation is struggling for stability in a system that no longer feels fit for purpose. It’s time to take that seriously
articles.summary: Gen Z Americans have come of age amid relentless crises—online schooling during COVID, soaring living costs, stagnant wages and looming AI job threats—leaving traditional stability markers (homeownership, pensions, family) out of reach. With college ROI diminishing, childcare unaffordable and mortgages unobtainable, they adopt ‘disillusionomics’: survival tactics ranging from fast-track careers in tech, finance and consulting to passive-income hustles (crypto, subleases, OnlyFans) and AI startups. Deep economic insecurity drives their voting choices, political polarization and a push for systemic redesign of work, social contracts and the economy itself.

articles.title: If you liked Brexit, you’re going to love what the Conservatives want next | Polly Toynbee
articles.trailText: Leaving the ECHR could mean higher food prices and an even bigger blow to trade. The Tories’ new proposals will end the party for good, says Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee
articles.summary: Polly Toynbee warns Conservatives’ push to leave the European Convention on Human Rights doubles down on Brexit’s legacy, deepening trade barriers, border delays and economic damage. From October 12th’s EU entry-exit system imposing fingerprints, visas and 90-day limits, to hauliers, holiday coaches and service firms like Rolls-Royce facing gridlock, the OBR predicts 15% lower trade and 4% productivity loss. Exiting the ECHR would spike food prices, sever data-sharing, risk the Good Friday Agreement and hamper extraditions. Business remains silent; Labour must articulate opposition to avert further turmoil.

articles.title: Migration is Britain’s superpower. Our future depends on embracing that truth, not denying it | Zack Polanski
articles.trailText: Labour has lost its nerve. At our party conference this weekend, we’re gathering to set things right, says Green party leader Zack Polanski
articles.summary: Green leader Zack Polanski argues migration is Britain’s ‘superpower’ and criticizes Labour’s embrace of anti-migrant messaging echoing Reform and Nigel Farage. He traces Britain’s housing, wage and service crises to austerity, privatisation and tax breaks favoring the wealthy, not migration. At the Green conference in Bournemouth he outlines alternatives: a wealth tax on the top 1%, public ownership of utilities, universal free childcare, rent controls, social housing investment, and a Green New Deal to create green jobs. He urges voters ahead of May 2026 to reject division and build a fair, sustainable economy.

articles.title: What a £5 coffee (or a £100 Pizza Express) tells us about a changing Britain | Gaby Hinsliff
articles.trailText: For many Gen Xers, it feels like we’re sliding back towards the land of our childhoods: where eating out was for special occasions, and Thermoses were king, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff highlights how surging everyday prices—takeaway oat-milk lattes north of £5 and a family meal at Pizza Express breaching £100—are eroding ordinary small pleasures for Gen X and beyond. She traces this "bill shock" to post-pandemic inflation, energy and climate pressures, war-linked commodity costs and tax rises, noting growers, chain bakeries and supermarkets are passing higher national insurance and wage bills onto customers. As budget-wary Brits skip little treats—magazines, cinema trips, wine—and cling to Thermoses, public mood sours, dampening optimism and complicating Labour's economic message ahead of the election.

articles.title: The Irish language is a joy not a burden: in what other tongue is a penis a wild carrot? | Una Mullally
articles.trailText: Record numbers of pupils are seeking opt-outs from compulsory learning. This is misguided – Irish is a portal to a world of imagination, says journalist Una Mullally
articles.summary: Una Mullally laments a record 14% of post-primary pupils exempting from compulsory Irish despite a 6% rise in speakers and over 200 Gaelscoileanna. She traces opt-outs to perceived difficulty, rote teaching, and exam pressures, noting even many Ukrainian students embrace Gaeilge. Reflecting on her Gaelscoil education and career at TG4 and The Irish Times’ new Irish supplement, she celebrates Irish’s nature-rich lexicon—from Ogham tree letters to playful words like bliúcán (penis) and blathscaileadh (menstruation)—and highlights Kneecap’s punk reinventions. A 25,000-strong march, pub discounts for Irish orders, and revived dialect accents signal growing grassroots momentum.

articles.title: Working these school holidays? Lower your expectations, ditch the plans and embrace the ‘good enough’ parenting approach | Sarah Ayoub
articles.trailText: I hadn’t expected the holidays to go downhill so fast. But a funny thing happened when I started taking it day by day
articles.summary: Journalist Sarah Ayoub reflects on her frazzled first day of juggling work-from-home with school holidays—early wake-ups, lost devices and a spoiled birthday plan—before embracing ‘good enough’ parenting. Guided by expert Genevieve Muir, she lowers her expectations, accepts compromises (more take-aways, screen time, village help) and focuses on small daily connections: a quick dance party, a board game or a shared meal courtesy of a Dinner Ladies gift card. In relinquishing perfect plans, she rediscovers simple joys, spontaneous fun and the value of going day by day.

articles.title: The Guardian view on the Manchester synagogue attack: a tragic wake-up call for Britain | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: An assault of this kind was widely feared. Now that it has happened, Britain faces a choice between deeper division and greater tolerance
articles.summary: Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation synagogue attacked on Yom Kippur: attacker stabbed worshippers, killing two and injuring four before being shot dead, possibly with an explosive. Modern UK’s most lethal antisemitic terror assault. Occurred amid a 204% surge in antisemitic incidents since October 2023. Police and community guards responded quickly; fuller details pending. Britain faces a choice between division and decency: must strengthen state protection for Jewish communities beyond routine guards, and foster collective responsibility and tolerance. The attack is a tragic wake-up call demanding urgent national action to safeguard vulnerable faith groups and prevent further violence.

articles.title: The Guardian view on climate policy: Britain needs clean power, not culture wars | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Kemi Badenoch’s plan to scrap the Climate Change Act is reckless. Ed Miliband offers a bolder, fairer vision. The future must be built on renewables
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch’s energy strategy to repeal the 2008 Climate Change Act, lift legally binding carbon targets and prioritise oil and gas extraction risks higher bills, lost investment and undermines a globally admired industrial strategy. The Guardian warns her culture-war stunt—mirroring Trump and Reform UK—shifts blame from volatile gas prices after Russia’s Ukraine invasion onto climate laws, retreating from 17 years of Conservative leadership. In contrast, Labour’s Ed Miliband defends net zero as an economic and moral mission, rejecting trickle-down and austerity, promising unionised green jobs, lower bills and a fairer social democracy.

articles.title: The theatre police have endless grievances about audience behaviour. I’m just thrilled you’ve made the effort to be here | Melanie Tait
articles.trailText: I haven’t always been as relaxed a theatre-maker. But one woman falling asleep in my play changed my view
articles.summary: Playwright Melanie Tait challenges theatre-etiquette obsessives who villainize phones, loud snacks or audience napping, insisting these are minor distractions compared with the bigger crisis of post-pandemic audience collapse and rising ticket prices. She shares her superstitious lore of seat A43—a ‘sleepy curse’—then recounts a matinee where a frail, seriously ill woman limped to A43, dozed through much of her play and still cheered loudly at the end. That attendee’s courageous effort to leave home, dress up and support live theatre, Tait argues, is the true measure of success, making small lapses forgivable.

articles.title: Labour’s new candid and confrontational mood could be the thing that saves this government | Andy Beckett
articles.trailText: For once, Starmer’s premiership seems energised – the task will be building this into a campaign for next year’s crucial local elections, says Guardian columnist Andy Beckett
articles.summary: At its October conference Labour, under Keir Starmer, has adopted a more candid, confrontational stance in response to plunging poll ratings — a shift evident in open criticism at fringe events, from Andy Burnham’s push for a broader left-wing agenda to Peter Hyman’s call to equip voters with skills rather than hollow security promises and Jonathan Hinder’s attack on privatisation. Drawing on crisis-driven reinvention parallels with Thatcher’s premiership, the party aims to harness this energy into coherent strategies ahead of next May’s elections and the looming budget, though risks of a muddled platform remain.

articles.title: Starmer can help shape the future of the world at Cop30. He can’t let fear of Farage stop him |  Michael Jacobs
articles.trailText: The battle inside No 10 about whether the PM should attend an absolutely crucial climate summit in Brazil is ludicrous. He must assert himself – and go, says economist Michael Jacobs
articles.summary: Labour aides fear Starmer attending COP30 in Belém will alienate Reform-leaning voters, yet foreign policy advisers warn absence amid Trump’s UN climate denial and Kemi Badenoch’s threats to scrap the 2008 Climate Change Act would undermine his green credentials. COP30 is the Paris agreement’s crucial five-year stocktake: current NDCs still predict ~2.5°C warming, risking catastrophic impacts. President Lula and António Guterres want leaders to commit to stronger targets, a streamlined UN climate council, halting deforestation and mobilising $1.3 trn annually by 2035. Starmer’s presence could signal UK leadership; no-show risks emboldening climate sceptics and weakening global decarbonisation momentum.

articles.title: James Comey’s real ‘crime’? Daring to put the law before loyalty to Trump | Lawrence Douglas
articles.trailText: The former FBI director prioritized fidelity to his office. The case against him is flimsy – but that’s cold comfort
articles.summary: In an op-ed comparing James Comey to Hans Litten, Lawrence Douglas argues that Comey’s “crime” was prioritizing legal duty over loyalty to Donald Trump. After complaints the case was baseless, Trump’s new EDVA appointee, personal lawyer Lindsey Halligan, secured a two-count indictment for alleged false statements before Congress, just before the statute of limitations expired. Trump’s handpicked team and his public interference exemplify an authoritarian tactic of punishing independent justice officials. Unlike Siebert, Halligan lacked prosecutorial experience but delivered the indictment Trump desired, underscoring how the DOJ has been repurposed to settle scores rather than uphold the rule of law.

articles.title: Do you know about shitposting? It’s cheap humour, rage bait – and now, it seems, US government policy | Robert Topinka
articles.trailText: Donald Trump’s White House reveals a new ‘portrait’ of Joe Biden – and in his world, if you don’t laugh, the joke’s on you, says Robert Topinka of Birkbeck, University of London
articles.summary: Robert Topinka argues that 'shitposting'—a style of low-effort, provocative online content pioneered on 4chan—has become US government policy under Trump’s second term. Examples include a White House video replacing Biden’s portrait with an autopen photo and a DHS Pokémon-themed ICE-abduction clip. These posts blend cheap humor with rage bait to rally supporters and outrage critics, eroding discourse norms, emboldening ‘own the libs’ cruelty, and even fueling political violence through irony-poisoned provocation. Vice-President JD Vance’s insults and the deletion of a satirical Theo Von clip underscore its reach, showing how this cruelty-driven tactic undermines good-faith debate and even licenses extreme actions.

articles.title: Democrats finally have some leverage in the shutdown fight. They should use it | Robert Reich
articles.trailText: The government has effectively been shut down since Trump returned to office, as officials clamp down on work they oppose
articles.summary: Since Oct 1 the US government is shut down as agencies lose funding, furloughing up to 750,000 workers; mandatory spending like Social Security continues. The shutdown stems from Republicans using reconciliation in July to pass a $1 trn “big ugly” bill cutting healthcare (Medicaid, ACA), nutrition, environment, boosting immigration enforcement, and extending tax cuts for the wealthy without any Democratic support. Now Republicans must secure Democratic votes to fund the government, giving Democrats leverage to restore health-care provisions and force a public fight where GOP would be blamed for rising premiums. Reich argues Dems should hold firm.

articles.title: Heard of aztec broccoli? Let me tell you about my favourite new superfood ... | Adrian Chiles
articles.trailText: A few months ago I was unaware of this leafy, fast-growing vegetable. Now I’m growing it, recommending it – and giving away as much as I can, writes writes Adrian Chiles
articles.summary: Adrian Chiles recounts his conversion to ‘aztec broccoli’ (huauzontle/Chenopodium nuttalliae), a Mexican goosefoot relative of quinoa and amaranth. After his neighbour Sharon gifted him six plants, they grew head-high in weeks. He eats its leaves and stalks like spinach—tender with extra texture—and its broccoli-like flower shoots steamed simply. Though a metre-wide bush yields only a pan of greens, it regrows in days. Readers will note its fast growth, all-edible superfood status and Chiles’s enthusiastic evangelism as he gifts armfuls to friends.

articles.title: There were two paths for America and Lilith Fair was one of them. Sadly it chose the other | Emma Brockes
articles.trailText: The all-female music festival from the 90s was a counterpoint to that era’s misogyny. Trump’s US could do with some of that hope and promise today, says Guardian columnist Emma Brockes
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Emma Brockes revisits Lilith Fair, the groundbreaking all-female touring festival of 1997-99 that confronted late-90s misogyny and offered a radical alternative to Woodstock ’99’s violence and today’s Trump-era polarization. Based on Ally Pankiw’s new Disney+ documentary Lilith Fair: Building a Mystery (co-produced by Dan Levy), Brockes celebrates Sarah McLachlan’s vision, the solidarity of artists from Sinéad O’Connor to Missy Elliott, its record-breaking box office, $10m charitable giving, and the festival’s inclusive, mentor-like spirit. She argues that America could use Lilith Fair’s hopeful feminist template again.

articles.title: Farage, Trump, Musk: your boy Javier Milei just took one hell of a beating. Why so quiet? | Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.trailText: The wild politics and chainsaw made Argentina’s president an economic hero for the right. And now, with his nation’s finances in chaos: silence, writes Guardian columnist Aditya Chakrabortty
articles.summary: Javier Milei, Argentina’s libertarian president celebrated by Nigel Farage, Donald Trump, Elon Musk and other hard-right figures for his radical ‘chainsaw’ cuts and anti-elite rhetoric, has presided over a financial meltdown: a plunging peso, capital flight, IMF and pledged US$20bn rescue, looming midterms defeat and a corruption scandal implicating his sister. Once lauded as a ‘man-made miracle’, his promises of dollarisation and ‘super peso’ fizzled, disillusioning poor and young voters and leaving erstwhile international backers conspicuously silent.

articles.title: American democracy might not survive another year – is Europe ready for that? | Alexander Hurst
articles.trailText: Trapped between Putin and Trump, EU citizens understand the grave dangers facing the continent. Their leaders urgently need to face reality, too, says Guardian Europe columnist Alexander Hurst
articles.summary: Alexander Hurst warns that under Trump’s authoritarian, even fascist-tinged agenda—militarizing against domestic opposition, undermining voting rights, weaponizing state power—the US may collapse into illiberalism within a year. European leaders have shifted from denial to cautious appeasement, fearing to alienate Washington and risk loss of support for Ukraine, but must now reckon openly with a hostile administration. EU citizens already demand stronger, unified security, finances and a tougher stance toward Trump. Without candid leadership, Europe risks being pinched between Washington and Moscow.

articles.title: The Guardian view on working-class representation in the arts: Manchester can lead the way | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: A pioneering inquiry in the north-west can help deliver fresh solutions to a national problem. Amid deepening social divisions, it takes on a vital task
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial warns that working-class representation in creative industries fell from 26% to 19% between 2020 and 2023, reinforcing social stratification and depriving culture and economy of diverse talent. It welcomes Manchester’s regionally based “class ceiling” inquiry, led by Nazir Afzal, as a practical model to drive local change and inform national policy. The piece urges reinstating maintenance grants—especially for arts students—and reversing cuts in cultural funding, arguing that better support and devolved strategies can spur growth, cohesion and genuine opportunity for underrepresented working-class artists.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Trump’s Argentina bailout: it’s a political play, not an economic plan | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Washington’s $20bn lifeline for rightwing populist Javier Milei isn’t about stability or sovereignty, it’s about winning an election
articles.summary: The US announced a $20bn bailout for Argentine president Javier Milei to shore up his right-wing government after electoral losses, but markets remain unconvinced as the peso plunged over 6%, stocks fell, and debt risk premiums spiked. Critics say the aid is driven by Trump’s political calculus ahead of midterms, not sustainable economic reform, risking deeper foreign dependence and undermining Argentina’s sovereignty. The Guardian suggests alternative measures—sovereign wealth fund, export taxes, state-led growth—were rejected in favor of shock liberalisation, leaving wages, industry and social support in crisis.

articles.title: What do Trump and Hegseth’s inflammatory speeches to military generals signal? | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: The Trump administration evidently seeks to transform the US military into a partisan tool of the president’s regime
articles.summary: Pete Hegseth’s unprecedented Quantico summons of all US generals evoked Nazi parallels as he and Trump used marathon speeches to purge ‘wokeness,’ dissolve DEI offices, equal-opportunity, inspector general and whistleblower protocols, ban identity months and beard waivers often used by Black soldiers, and raise fitness standards to a ‘male level.’ By ending anonymous, repeat or frivolous harassment complaints and sexual-assault reporting, they signaled a rollback of 2010s reform. Trump framed domestic dissent as an ‘invasion’ and urged the military to target Americans, signaling a drive to politicize the armed forces as a partisan tool.

articles.title: The joy of The Traitors is in rooting for real people. Does anyone care about celebrities in that way? | Zoe Williams
articles.trailText: Having famous contestants is a betrayal of all that’s great about the show – and a misunderstanding of what makes humans tick, says Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams argues that Celebrity Traitors undermines the original show’s appeal by replacing everyday contestants—whose intense, unselfconscious stakes and personal motivations fuel genuine drama—with well-known figures like Stephen Fry and Paloma Faith. Reality TV thrives on participants losing themselves in technical challenges, revealing flaws and desires tied to a £100,000 prize. But celebrities pledging charity, aware of performance, can’t dissolve self-consciousness or financial desperation. By assuming fame alone suffices for engagement, Celebrity Traitors sacrifices authenticity and suspense, even if Williams admits she might still tune in.

articles.title: Once again, Netanyahu has outplayed Trump |  Mohamad Bazzi
articles.trailText: Trump considers himself a master deal-maker. But he’s been regularly outmaneuvered by strongmen like Netanyahu and Vladimir Putin
articles.summary: Donald Trump unveiled a 20-point Gaza 'peace plan' demanding Hamas’s disarmament and hostage release in exchange for limited Israeli withdrawals—an ultimatum drafted without Palestinian input. Benjamin Netanyahu, having prolonged the war since 2023, secured near-total victory conditions, using flattery, a Nobel prize nod and US military support to deepen siege tactics that have killed overwhelmingly civilian Palestinians. Trump was repeatedly outmaneuvered by Netanyahu, who shaped last-minute plan revisions while Trump floated US-run “Riviera” schemes and endorsed occupation. This dynamic has deepened Washington’s complicity in Israel’s war crimes and undermined any genuine ceasefire prospects.

articles.title: Trump’s H-1B visa fee is a death sentence for US healthcare | Eram Alam
articles.trailText: Trump’s $100,000 visa fee will gut the immigrant workforce that keeps US hospitals – and patients – alive
articles.summary: Trump administration’s new $100,000 H-1B visa fee, framed as a Silicon Valley crackdown, will gut the immigrant physician pipeline that supplies one in four US doctors, especially in rural and underserved hospitals. By raising costs from a few thousand to $100k, the policy risks vacant residency slots, shuttered clinics, longer wait times and lives lost. Long-term shortages stem from decades of capped medical school and residency funding, not immigration. Alam argues this measure weaponizes immigration instead of investing in structural reform: expand training capacity, fund primary care and secure permanent pathways for immigrant physicians.

articles.title: Trump’s peace plan is everything Israelis dreamed of. But it’s a fantasy | Roy Schwartz
articles.trailText: The president’s intervention promises a return to ‘normality’ – one that appeals to Israelis unconcerned with Gaza’s future, says senior Haaretz editor Roy Schwartz
articles.summary: Trump’s 20-point, one-page Gaza “peace plan,” hailed by Netanyahu, promises hostages’ return, Hamas’s removal and a swift “return to normality,” but is largely fantasy: Hamas hasn’t signed on, while Netanyahu’s approval omits key elements like a Palestinian state. Critical gaps—funding sources for humanitarian aid and reconstruction, the mandate and composition of an international stabilization force, and enforcement mechanisms—are unexplained. Political calculations may prefer perpetual war over compromise, and the Israeli public remains indifferent to Gaza’s humanitarian catastrophe. Without answers to these questions, the plan risks becoming a symbolic promise rather than a realistic roadmap.

articles.title: Big pharma is at war with the UK, and the government can’t back down now | Nick Dearden
articles.trailText: The industry has always wanted the NHS to pay more for its drugs; now it is pulling research and investment out of Britain, says director of Global Justice Now Nick Dearden
articles.summary: Big pharma has withdrawn around £2bn in UK investment so far this year—Merck scrapped a £1bn R&D facility; AstraZeneca axed a £450m vaccine lab; BMS cancelled 34 NHS partnerships—and is threatening to withhold new medicines to force higher NHS drug prices. Companies oppose NICE and the VPAG rebate scheme, and are coordinating a capital strike amid US pressure from Trump to equate global prices. Dearden warns that conceding would enrich already highly profitable firms, and calls for publicly controlled research, EU and global south collaboration, and expanded public manufacturing capacity.

articles.title: Why I have had it with entitled dog owners | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: You know the types – they let their hound jump all over you and don’t clear up after them. Bring on their poo-nishment, writes Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi, a self-professed dog lover, rails against inconsiderate owners whose pets trample strangers and whose waste litters pavements. She notes the pandemic surge in pet ownership has worsened public rudeness—47% of Americans say people are ruder post-Covid. Bolzano, Italy, will impose a €1.50 daily dog tourist tax and €100 annual levy on locals to fund street-cleaning; it already mandates DNA profiling to fine offenders. Previous solutions—from Paris’s motorised scooper to LA’s poop-flags—failed. Mahdawi argues that a levy might succeed where shame and technology haven’t. Poo-nishment, she quips, could be next.

articles.title: Colon cancer is on the rise among young people – and research points to one major culprit | Devi Sridhar
articles.trailText: If smoking was the cancer villain of the 20th century, eating ultra-processed food may be its 21st-century counterpart, says Prof Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh
articles.summary: Prof Devi Sridhar warns of a sharp rise in early-onset colorectal cancer among adults under 50—cases soared from 94,700 in 1990 to 225,736 in 2019, with rates rising up to 7.9% annually in 20–29-year-olds. Genetics explain just 25% of cases; environmental factors point squarely at ultra-processed foods, now over half of Western diets. A BMJ analysis of 46,000 US men found highest UPF consumers had a 29% greater risk independent of BMI. Emulsifiers, additives and low fiber disrupt the gut microbiome, insulin signaling and cause inflammation. Sridhar recommends cutting UPFs, boosting yogurt, for cancer prevention.

articles.title: My calls and emails to family in Afghanistan go unanswered. The Taliban’s internet shutdown has left us all helpless | Shadi Khan Saif
articles.trailText: From the safety of Australia, I watch in despair as my loved ones in Kabul navigate this digital darkness – a calculated effort to silence dissent
articles.summary: Taliban’s October 2025 nationwide shutdown of internet and telecom services in Afghanistan, decreed by leader Hibatullah Akhundzada under the guise of curbing “immorality,” has severed the digital lifeline connecting millions—including diaspora families like the author’s in Australia—to loved ones in Kabul. This deliberate blackout halts girls’ online education, silences journalists exposing atrocities, isolates activists, and cripples banking, aviation and healthcare operations. The UN warns it deepens an already dire humanitarian and economic crisis. Framed as a moral intervention, it is in reality a calculated effort to consolidate power and stifle all dissent, leaving relatives unreachable.

articles.title: The European Union was designed for peace – it is never going to be a war machine | Anand Menon
articles.trailText: Reacting to the Russian military threat would require the bloc to be agile and decisive. It is many great things, but it is not that, says Anand Menon, director of UK in a Changing Europe
articles.summary: Anand Menon argues that the EU, conceived as a peace project to bind former rivals through economic integration and diffuse sovereignty, lacks the institutional agility and decision-making speed to function as an effective defence organisation. Its consensus-driven, power-sharing structures prevent rapid military responses or centralized control over force. While EU mechanisms can advance defence procurement and collaboration, they cannot coordinate military action. Facing Russia’s aggression in Ukraine and uncertain US support, Europeans must seek or build new defence frameworks beyond the EU without undermining its core peace-building strengths.

articles.title: My conference pass was revoked for asking difficult questions: this is Keir Starmer’s Labour | Owen Jones
articles.trailText: I was told it was a ‘safeguarding’ issue. This speaks to a party that has not only lost its soul, but is scared of the truth, writes Guardian columnist Owen Jones
articles.summary: Owen Jones criticizes Labour’s 2025 conference as a soulless, corporatized, and authoritarian event under Keir Starmer. Corporate lobbyists—from arms manufacturers to Uber—sponsored key zones, while Heathrow expansion was hawked on conference walls. Dissenters face suspensions, members risk bans for liking rival tweets, Gaza protestors are arrested under a terrorism ban, and leftwing journalists had passes revoked under “safeguarding” for asking hard questions. With record unpopularity, benefit cuts and no clear vision, Jones warns Labour has abandoned its moral purpose and risks collapse in pursuit of power.

articles.title: The Guardian view on Starmer’s conference speech: national renewal needs more than rules-bound growth | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Labour’s leader framed his fight with Reform as decency against grievance. But without pledges on improving living standards, his rhetoric risks ringing hollow
articles.summary: Sir Keir Starmer framed his conference speech as an existential battle with Reform UK – decency vs grievance, renewal vs decline – delivering a clear, moral, passionate address that won applause. But he sidestepped pledges on improving living standards, left untouched everyday economic insecurity, NHS waiting lists, and local decline. His commitment to rules-bound growth and fiscal discipline risks sounding hollow without bold redistribution, visible investment in left-behind communities, and urgent measures to lower bills and bolster public services. Without fiscal firepower, renewal rhetoric alone may not shift voters.

articles.title: The Guardian view on child poverty: the scrapping of the two-child benefit cap can’t come soon enough | Editorial
articles.trailText: Editorial: Extra services for poorer families are welcome, but real progress requires the raising of incomes
articles.summary: The Guardian editorial hails the promised scrapping of the two-child benefit cap as overdue, condemning it as “spiteful” and responsible for worsening child poverty and normalising food-bank reliance. With 4.5 million UK children in poverty, ending the cap could lift half a million youngsters out of deprivation instantly. The paper notes extra services—breakfast clubs, a slimmed-down Sure Start successor and wider free school meal eligibility—are welcome but insufficient. It urges Rachel Reeves to fully remove the cap and pair it with broader income reforms—eg benefit tapers and social housing expansion—to tackle entrenched poverty.

articles.title: Was this Starmer’s best speech? Yes. But he’ll need a new battle plan to convince a doubting Britain | Martin Kettle
articles.trailText: The era when a barnstorming address would turn political fortunes is gone. The PM is out of step with modern digital politics and needs to catch up, says Guardian columnist Martin Kettle
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Martin Kettle argues Keir Starmer’s Liverpool conference address—his most forceful and engaging in five years—finally set out clear ambitions (national renewal, justice for workers and minorities, post-school training, digital NHS upgrades) in a battle for Britain’s soul against division. Yet it comes too late—this blueprint needed airing before the 2024 election to manage expectations. In today’s digital age, polished speeches are relics; Starmer and Rachel Reeves require a modern, viral campaign to reshape the national argument and win back sceptical voters.

articles.title: Ear seeding: can an ancient wellness technique really de-puff your face? | Antiviral
articles.trailText: Experts weigh in on the needle-free form of acupuncture some TikTokers are crediting with creating their ‘snatched’ jawlines
articles.summary: TikTok’s latest beauty hack, ear seeding, uses adhesive beads on auricular pressure points to ‘de-puff’ and sculpt jawlines. Rooted in traditional Chinese acupressure, it claims to link ear zones with body parts. Experts acknowledge some trials show ear seeding eases post-surgical pain and anxiety but find no solid evidence for facial de-puffing or cosmetic lifting. Deemed low-risk, improper use can irritate skin or cartilage. Persistent swelling should prompt medical review, while simple elevation or massage often suffices for routine morning puffiness.

articles.title: Unions are handing Democrats a golden opportunity amid the shutdown battle | Judith Levine
articles.trailText: Federal workers’ move offers Democrats a chance to win the budget battle – and their identity
articles.summary: Federal Unionists Network and 35 national, state and local unions representing tens of thousands of federal workers have urged Senate leader Schumer and House leader Jeffries to resist GOP budget cuts—even at the cost of a government shutdown and lost pay—demanding adequate funding for critical services and enforcement of congressional appropriations. Their unprecedented solidarity—mirroring a 1946 general strike—positions unions as heroes advocating economic justice, democracy and public welfare, offering Democrats a pivotal chance to reclaim their base and define GOP cuts as threats to security and prosperity.

articles.title: It’s the art of the dodgy deal, Middle East edition: author Donald Trump, updated by Jared Kushner | Marina Hyde
articles.trailText: Does the Donald know that there’s a new master negotiator in town? Of course he does, he taught the apprentice everything he knows, says Guardian columnist Marina Hyde
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Marina Hyde skewers Jared Kushner’s ‘dealpolitik’, highlighting his dual Monday coups: engineering a $55 billion Saudi-backed leveraged buyout of EA through his investment firm—using his CFIUS sway—and unveiling the Trump–Blair ‘Board of Peace’ for Gaza, to be chaired by Donald Trump with apolitical Palestinian technocrats. Once a senior White House adviser and Ivanka’s husband, Kushner now operates from the deepest backrooms, blurring business and foreign-policy realms.

articles.title: Sperm racing is all the rage among the tech bros. Why am I not surprised? | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: It started as a gag, but Eric Zhu’s sperm races are doing good work in putting male fertility under the microscope – literally, writes Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Arwa Mahdawi critiques ‘sperm racing,’ a viral concept by teen entrepreneur Eric Zhu whose startup, valued at $75m and backed by $10m seed funding, gamifies male fertility via real-time sperm races and supplements (‘Sperm Worms’). Framed as a health initiative to spark conversation on declining sperm counts, it also underscores Silicon Valley’s fixation on hyper-masculinity, body optimization and eugenics. Mahdawi warns that turning reproductive health into competition follows broader tech trends—testosterone obsession, pronatalism and flashy fertility fixes—while neglecting systemic causes of infertility.

articles.title: While world leaders dither over a Gaza peace plan, I’m sailing with supplies, hoping to break Israel’s blockade  | Naoise Dolan
articles.trailText: It’s not likely we will reach Gaza. But until Palestine is free, we will show what solidarity we can from our vessel, says writer Naoise Dolan
articles.summary: Naoise Dolan joins the Thousand Madleens flotilla from Sicily to Gaza aboard Milad, carrying medicine, baby formula and prosthetic limbs to challenge Israel’s blockade. Renamed for Palestinian Milad Walid Daqqa, the vessel’s seven international volunteers follow strict routines—sailing, cooking, cleaning—to maintain seaworthiness.
